convolvendo, &longs;ive ope rotæ dentatæ Vertebram &longs;triatam cy­
lindro circumpo&longs;itam moventis; &longs;ive fune cylindrum bis aut
ter arctè complexo, & in &longs;e&longs;e redeunte, ubi majoris alicu­
jus tympani orbitam pariter complexus fuerit; &longs;ive pondere
funem cylindro involutum explicante: &longs;ed po&longs;tremus hic
modus non ni&longs;i breve temporis &longs;patium exigit; duo priores,
&longs;i paulo longior futurus &longs;it motus, non ni&longs;i à potentiá vi­
vente commodè exhiberi po&longs;&longs;unt.

Quare &longs;atius fuerit tro­
chleas, ut in &longs;uperiore propo&longs;itione, di&longs;po&longs;itas adhibere, at­
que loco flabellorum &longs;olis di&longs;cum Axi adnectere; &longs;ic enim
fiet, ut & celeriter in gyrum agatur, & diu per&longs;everet
motus.

Similiter ad fingendum mare, & undarum motum vehe­
mentiorem, &longs;tatuuntur horizonti & invicem paralleli ali­
quot axes, quos ambiunt &longs;piræ profundiùs excavatæ colore
marinam undam imitantes: dum enim huju&longs;modi axes con­
volvuntur, marini æ&longs;tûs cur&longs;um &longs;pectatoribus repræ&longs;entant.

Ut autem axes illi citra cuju&longs;quam laborem volvantur tro­
chleas duas binis, aut ternis orbiculis in&longs;tructas (prout diu­
turnior motus requiritur) compone, & proximas &longs;tatue, al­
teram firmans in &longs;uperiore loco: Tum funis ductarius per
omnes Trochlearum orbiculos trajectus &longs;ingulorum axium ca­
pita ex ordine ambiat unâ &longs;altem aut alterâ &longs;pirâ, & demum
ad peculiarem alium axem deveniat, quem totus plures in
&longs;piras complicatus circumplectatur, ita tamen, ut facilè
evolvi queat.

Ubi igitur tempus advenerit, inferiori tro­
chleæ congruum pondus adnecte; hoc enim licèt lentè de­
&longs;cendat, velociter tamen axes convolvit funem evolvens.

Procellam verò mite&longs;cere aut exa&longs;perari mentieris, factâ
ponderis aliquâ detractione aut acce&longs;&longs;ione, id quod difficile
non fuerit.
PROPOSITIO III.
Se ip&longs;um ope trochlearum in altum evehere, aut promovere.

SElla paretur hinc & hinc habens fulcra, quibus brachia
innituntur, & in huju&longs;modi fulcrorum extremitate ante­
riore aptetur Sucula manubriata, quam &longs;edens commodè ver­
&longs;are valeat: &longs;ella autem quatuor funibus in nodum cum an­
nulo coëuntibus &longs;u&longs;pendatur ita, ut inferioris trochleæ uncus
annulo indatur, & funis ductarius per cunctos trochlearum
orbiculos trajectus demum &longs;uculæ alligetur.

Nam in &longs;ellâ &longs;e­
dens, & &longs;uculæ manubria convertens, funem ductarium
trahit, atque ip&longs;e &longs;e in altum evehit eâ facilitate, quam in­
fert Ratio compo&longs;ita ex Rationibus trochlearum, & Suculæ:
e&longs;t &longs;iquidem Potentia ip&longs;a virtus animalis mu&longs;culorum con­
tentione ver&longs;ans manubria, pondus autem e&longs;t in&longs;ita corpori
gravitas, quæ eò minor apparet, quo majores &longs;unt, hoc e&longs;t
pluribus in&longs;tructæ orbiculis, trochleæ, & major e&longs;t Ratio
manubriorum ad &longs;emidiametrum Axis, qui fune obvolvitur.
Sit enim ex.

gr. inferior trochlea, cui pondus movendum ad­
nectitur, & funis ductarij extremitas alligatur, orbiculorum
duorum; &longs;uperior autem trochlea, quæ &longs;tabilis manet, tres
habeat orbiculos: utique Ratio motûs potentiæ ad motum
ponderis e&longs;t quintupla: manubria autem Suculæ &longs;int quadru­
pla &longs;emidiametri Axis: Ratio compo&longs;ita ex quadruplâ & quin­
tuplâ e&longs;t vigecuplâ; igitur conatus Potentiæ manubria ver&longs;an­
tis &longs;atis e&longs;t, &longs;i re&longs;pondeat vige&longs;imæ parti ponderis.

Similiter &longs;i cymba adver&longs;o flumine non procul à ripâ dedu­
cenda &longs;it, & qui in eâ &longs;unt nautæ, ita pauci &longs;int, ut non va­
leant eam adversùs vim profluentis remo agere, aut è ripá fu­
ne nautico trahere; &longs;ub&longs;idium ex trochleis petere poterunt;
ex&longs;cen&longs;u &longs;cilicet in terram facto, atque defixo in ripâ paxil­
lo alligatur trochlea una, altera adnectitur proræ cymbæ,
in qua nautæ duo funem ductarium trahentes illam adver&longs;o
flumine promovent perinde, atque &longs;i e&longs;&longs;ent octo aut duode­
cim homines, &longs;i trochleæ binos aut ternos habuerint orbicu-
los.

Quod &longs;i trochleis illi careant, utantur artificio &longs;equentis
propo&longs;itionis, unà cum iis, quæ cap.
5. dicta &longs;unt.
PROPOSITIO IV.
Trochlearum defectum &longs;upplere.

EX his, quæ cap.
2. hujus libri indicata &longs;unt, &longs;atis con&longs;tat
etiam &longs;inè orbiculis haberi po&longs;&longs;e momentum Trochlea­
rum: quare his deficientibus annulos &longs;ufficere facile erit.
Et primo quidem &longs;ingulis annulis uti po&longs;&longs;umus: nam cùm
cymba communiter adnexum proræ annulum habeat, ut
medio fune, aut catenâ ad ripam religetur, funis ducta­
rius unus AB adnectatur paxillo A in ripâ defixo, & per
cymbæ annulum B trajiciatur; illius alteri extremitati C an­
nulus alius adnectatur, per quem alter ductarius funis DEF
trajectus & paxillo D alligatus &longs;i à Potentiâ in F con&longs;titutâ
trahatur, illa habebit momentum quadruplum, perinde at­
que de orbiculi, &longs;uperiùs dictum e&longs;t cap.
5. At &longs;i con&longs;i&longs;tentes
in cymbâ trahere illam velint nautæ, adjiciatur paxillo D an­
nulus G &longs;tabilis, per quem productus funis EF tran&longs;eat, &
veniat in H ad nautarum manus in cymbâ; nam illum trahen­
do cymbæ prora ex B accedet ad A.

Porrò annuli nomine notatum volo quicquid eju&longs;modi e&longs;t,
ut funis per illud trajici po&longs;&longs;it, & liberè excurrere, &longs;ive &longs;it
ligni fru&longs;tum foramen habens politum & &longs;atis amplum, ut
per illud funis facilè moveri valeat, &longs;ive etiam &longs;it flexilis
bacilli particula in arcum vel modicè &longs;inuata; modò illa non
&longs;it fractioni obnoxia.

Illud autem in annullis ob&longs;ervandum
e&longs;t, quod faciliùs excurrit funis, &longs;i illi cra&longs;&longs;iores fuerint & po­
liti, quàm &longs;i exiles & a&longs;peri.

Quod &longs;i annulis Trochleas propiùs æmulari placuerit, duos
annulos R & S alliga paxillo V, duó&longs;que alios H & G ad­
necte in M ponderi trahendo: Tum funem ductarium eidem
paxillo V alligatum trajice primùm per annulum G, deinde
per annulum S, hinc per annulum H, demum per annulum R.

Nam &longs;i extremitati I potentia trahens applicetur, movebitur
quadruplo velociùs, quàm pondus in M, adeóque etiam ha­
bebit momentum quadruplum.

Ne autem funes ob nimiam
propinquitatem &longs;ibi invicem impedimento &longs;int &longs;e mutuo con­
flictu atterentes, annulos tran&longs;ver&longs;is bacillis ON, & LP dis­
junge.
PROPOSITIO V.

Re&longs;i&longs;tentiam ex axium cum orbiculis conflictu in Trochleis
examinare.

QUoniam variarum Trochlearum u&longs;um indicavimus, mo­
dò trochleâ alterâ manente atque &longs;tabili, modò utra­
que commotâ, placet hìc examinare propo&longs;itas duas tro­
chleas, an aliquid impedimenti afferant ex conflictu axium
cum orbiculis, aut etiam trochleas comparare cum annulis
earum loco adhibitis, quantum videlicet præ trochleis afferat
impedimenti conflictus funis ductarij cum annulis.

Sit libræ jugum AB æqualium brachiorum aginam cum
examine habens in C;
adnectatur in A tro­

Quare in B tantum ponderis apponendum e&longs;t, quan­
tum &longs;ufficiat ad æquilibrium; proinde &longs;en&longs;im augendum e&longs;t
pondus in D, donec examen in C æqualitatem momentorum
indicet.

Hoc peracto adde adhuc ponderi D aliam atque aliam
gravitatem, u&longs;que dum brachium B deor&longs;um inclinetur: hu­
ju&longs;modi enim additamentum indicabit re&longs;i&longs;tentiam ortam ex
conflictu axium cum orbiculis.

Jam &longs;i trochlearum loco annulos &longs;ub&longs;tituas, eadémque me­
thodo invento primùm æquilibrio, deinde factâ in D ponderis
acce&longs;&longs;ione præponderantiam quæras, deprehendes, quanto
major re&longs;i&longs;tentia ex funis ductarij cum annulis affrictu oriatur,
quàm ex axium cum &longs;uis orbiculis conflictu in trochleis.

Simili ratione &longs;i in A &longs;it clavus, cui &longs;uperior trochlea &longs;tabi­
lis permanens affigatur; extremitas verò funis ductarij M ad­
nectatur brachio libræ ad æquilibrium con&longs;tituendum &longs;ufficit
in N quinta pars gravitatis trochleæ inferioris unà cum &longs;axo F,
& ductu funis MI.

Facto igitur in H additamento gravitatis,
ut tollatur æquilibrium, indicabitur quanta re&longs;i&longs;tentiæ acce&longs;&longs;io
fiat ponderi F ex axium cum orbiculis conflictu: atque &longs;imili­
ter repo&longs;itis loco trochlearum annulis, po&longs;t æquilibrium aucto
pondere N donec deprimatur, innote&longs;cet re&longs;i&longs;tentia orta ex fu­
nis cum annulis affrictu.

Hinc apparet primò &longs;atius e&longs;&longs;e hoc po&longs;teriore modo ope­
rari, quia longè minus pondus requiritur in N, quàm in D.

Secundò ad tollendum pondus F cum trochlea inferiore, &longs;i
&longs;uperior fixa maneat, tantam vim in potentiâ requiri, quan­
tâ opus e&longs;&longs;et ad attollendum ab&longs;que ullâ machinâ pondus N
præponderans; ad attollendum verò idem &longs;axum F cum
utrâque trochleâ, trahendo &longs;cilicet &longs;ur&longs;um trochleam A,
tantam vim exigi in potentia, quanta requiritur ad attol­
lendum pondus D præponderans.

Tertiò, retentis ii&longs;dem tro­
chleis, &longs;ed mutato pondere F, examinari po&longs;&longs;e, an, & quan­
to major re&longs;i&longs;tentia oriatur ex majore pre&longs;&longs;ione axium,
quando pondus e&longs;t majus.
Quartò.

mutatis trochleis, & pon­
dere eodem retento, di&longs;paritatem aliquam inveniri, quia non
omnium trochlearum axes &longs;unt æquè teretes, ac politi,
& &longs;uorum orbiculorum foramini congruentes.

Quod &longs;i, exa­
mine huju&longs;modi &longs;emel in&longs;tituto, orbiculos manu pauli&longs;per
convertas, & iterum idem examen in&longs;tituas, neque æqua­

&longs;imili examine in annulis inito deprehendi po&longs;&longs;e,
an faciliùs &longs;uccedat tractio fune cra&longs;&longs;iore, an verò te­

Non ita tamen nece&longs;&longs;e e&longs;t indicatâ methodo uti, ut, &longs;i
non placeat jugum libræ æqualium brachiorum adhibere,

brium: deinde longiùs reducto &longs;acomate, u&longs;que dum appa­
rere incipiat præponderatio, innote&longs;cet quantitas impedimen-
ti, quin opus &longs;it gravitatem aliam atque aliam addere, ut
in librâ.
PROPOSITIO VI.
Vim Retinaculi Trochlearum augere.

SÆpè contingit infixo parieti tigillo alligari &longs;uperiorem
trochleam; & ni&longs;i paries valdè firmus ac &longs;olidus fuerit,
cuju&longs;modi &longs;unt antiqui parietes, non leve periculum immi­
net, ne ponderis vi labefactetur ip&longs;e paries, maximè &longs;i recens
fuerit, & tigillus non admodum procul à &longs;ummitate infigatur;
ut &longs;i recentis parietis BC
foramini immittatur tigillus
brevior AH, ex quo in A
dependet trochlea, & ex illâ
pondus cum reliquâ tro­
chleâ: fieri enim pote&longs;t, ut
tigillus ip&longs;e qua&longs;i Vectis à
pondere adnexo depre&longs;&longs;us at­
tollat lateres impo&longs;itos, &
&longs;uperioris parietis compa­
gem di&longs;&longs;olvat.

Foramen igi­
tur ita fiat, ut paries pervius
&longs;it, illúmque pervadat lon­
gior tigillus AF, cujus ca­
put F fune FI connectatur
cum annulo in I parieti in­
fixo: &longs;ic enim ponderis gra­
vitas nullam inferre poterit
parieti labem quamvis re­
centi; & quò longior fuerit
tigilli pars HF &longs;upra partem HA, eò validius retinebitur tro­
chlea in A, tigillo rationem Vectis habente.
PROPOSITIO VII.
Trochleis vim Vectis augere.

QUamvis ex dictis obvium &longs;it Trochleas cum aliis Faculta­
tibus componere, placet tamen hìc eas cum Vecte com­
ponendas indicare.

Sit prælum in torculari, &longs;ed fortè di&longs;&longs;ipa­
ta fuerit Cochlea, qua illud deor&longs;um trahebatur, aut certè ad
&longs;ubitum u&longs;um properato prælo utendum &longs;it: trabem &longs;tatue
tran&longs;ver&longs;am, quæ altero capite retineatur objecto repagulo, ne
&longs;ur&longs;um attollatur.

Vectis e&longs;t &longs;ecundi generis in medio habens
pondus premendum.

Alteri trabis extremitati adnectatur tro­
chlea, ejú&longs;que compar in inferiore loco firmetur: nam funem
ductarium trahentes momentum habebunt, quod ex Ratione
Vectis, & ex Ratione Trochlearum componitur.

Simili methodo utendum e&longs;t, &longs;i Vecte &longs;ecundi generis at­
tollendum &longs;it pondus: loco enim potentiæ de&longs;tinato, hoc e&longs;t
Vectis extremitati attollendæ, adnectatur Trochlea, ejú&longs;que
compar in &longs;uperiore loco firmetur: hìc enim pariter Vectis at­
que Trochlearum Rationes componuntur.

Quòd &longs;i funem Su­
culâ traxeris, aut Ergatâ, tres erunt Rationes compo&longs;itæ; dua­
bus quippe illis addenda e&longs;t Ratio Suculæ aut Ergatæ.
MECHANICORUM LIBER SEPTIMUS.
De Cuneo & Percu&longs;sionibus.

MECHANICARUM Facultatum Quarta &longs;pecies,
Cuneus, præ&longs;entem di&longs;putationem exigit: neque
enim &longs;olam corporum gravitatem, ob id ip&longs;um
quia gravitas e&longs;t, vincere oportet, ac loco dimo­
vere, quemadmodum Vecte, Axe, & Trochleis,
&longs;ed etiam &longs;æpè conjunctas corporum partes, aut cohærentia
proximè corpora &longs;ejungere atque divellere: id quod Cuneo
poti&longs;&longs;imùm perficimus, & iis, quæ ad Cunei rationem &longs;pecta­
re videntur.

Quoniam verò in iis, in quibus præcipuè Cu­
nei vis elucet, percu&longs;&longs;ione utimur, quæ &longs;anè in paulò lon­
giorem &longs;ermonem nos vocat, non erit abs re aliquanto latiùs
Percu&longs;&longs;ionis naturam explicare, ut potentiæ Cuneo applicatæ
virtus manife&longs;ta fiat.

Quamquam non &longs;emper percu&longs;&longs;ione
indigeat Cuneus, &longs;ed non rarò impul&longs;ione contentus &longs;it, ne­
que &longs;emper ad divellenda ea, quæ conjuncta &longs;unt, illo uta­
mur, &longs;ed aliquando etiam ad deprimendum, aut attollendum
corpus aliquod, ut ex &longs;equentibus patebit.

Ea verò, quæ
Cunei figuram imitantur, quia in apicem de&longs;inunt, ut trian­
gula, ideóque Cunei nomine &longs;unt indicata &longs;æpiùs à Vitruvio
in Architecturæ libris, ad præ&longs;entem di&longs;putationem non atti­
nent; quemadmodum neque &longs;ub&longs;cudes, &longs;eu &longs;ecuriclæ, quibus
arctè duæ tabulæ compinguntur; licèt enim cunei formam
imitentur, non tamen &longs;imilem, &longs;ed cuneo oppo&longs;itam effectio­
nem habent, & inter retinacula connumerandæ &longs;unt.
CAPUT I.
Cunei forma, & vires explicantur.

CUneus, quo ad ligna findenda communiter utimur, &longs;atis
notum e&longs;t in&longs;trumentum, quod ex ampliori ba&longs;e fa&longs;tigia­
tur in acumen de&longs;inens; duas &longs;cilicet facies quadrangulas in li­
neam coëuntes, & duobus triangulis hinc atque hinc connexas
&longs;uper quadrilateram ba&longs;im erigit, adeò ut &longs;cindendo corpori
acies ip&longs;a applicetur, percu&longs;&longs;ionem excipiat ba&longs;is.

Nihil tamen
prohibet aliam cuneo figuram tribui: nam cum aliquando com­
planandus e&longs;&longs;et colliculus, cujus creta arenæ permixta in lapi­
deam quandam materiem concreverat, & ita obduruerat, ut li­
gonibus ægerrimè cederet, parari ju&longs;&longs;i longiu&longs;culos ferreos cy­
lindrulos digitorum duûm cra&longs;&longs;itudine extremitate alterâ capi­
tatos ad excipiendum mallei ictum, altera in planas duas &longs;uper­
ficies compre&longs;&longs;os atque exacutos, qui juxta lapidis intervenia ap­
plicati, ac tudite adacti lapidem penetrabant; qui demum rimas
agens di&longs;&longs;iliebat in fru&longs;ta &longs;atis con&longs;picua non pœnitendo labore.

Sed quæcumque demum figura cuneo &longs;tatuatur, illud omnibus
commune e&longs;t, quod ex minori latitudine in majorem procedant,
ut quibus corporibus Cuneus in&longs;eritur, magis atque magis alte­
rum ab altero &longs;ecedat, dum ille penitiùs adigitur.

Nunc verò &longs;ci&longs;&longs;ionem tanti&longs;per &longs;eponamus, & &longs;olum motum
corporis gravis ex cunei impul&longs;ione con&longs;ideremus, &longs;icuti &longs;i duro
plano incumbentem marmoreum cubum, cui vectis &longs;ubjici ne­
quiret, ut attolleretur, addacto cuneo disjungeremus à &longs;ub­
jecto plano: id quod faciliùs acutiore cuneo præ&longs;tatur, ut omnes
nôrunt, quàm &longs;i ille in mi­
nus acutum angulum de­
&longs;ineret.

Sit enim cubus H
marmoreus plano AB in­
cumbens; & applicatus
cuneus DE, atque tudite
in D validè percu&longs;&longs;us ita
cubo &longs;ubjiciatur, ut hic
elevetur ad altitudinem FI.

Cùm itaque citrà omnem dubi­
tationem is, qui tuditem movet, eóque cuneum percutit, illo
eodem conatu nequeat cubum attollere &longs;inè cuneo, quæritur,
unde vis tanta illi accedat, &longs;pectatâ præcisè cunei figurâ, nihil
interim ad percu&longs;&longs;ionem re&longs;piciendo.
Qui Ari&longs;toteli Mechan. quæ&longs;t.

17. in lateribus cunei ligno
&longs;cindendo interjecti duplicem Vectem agno&longs;centi adhærent,
illicò ad Vectis Rationes confugient, quas in latere DE re­
cogno&longs;cere conabuntur.
Verùm quærenti, primi ne?

an &longs;e­
cundi generis Vectis &longs;it DE? vix &longs;uppetet, quid re&longs;pondeant.

Si primi generis, ut volui&longs;&longs;e videtur Ari&longs;toteles; cum tria &longs;int
puncta D, & I, & E, atque primum D procul dubio potentiæ
a&longs;cribatur; reliquum e&longs;t medium punctum I e&longs;&longs;e hypomochlij,
extremum E ponderis.

Atqui nihil pror&longs;us apparet, quod cu­
bum H applicet puncto E, à quo neque &longs;u&longs;tinetur, neque tan­
gitur: igitur vectis non e&longs;t primi generis.

Quod &longs;i in E pon­
dus e&longs;&longs;e ultrò conce&longs;&longs;erim, illud certè ex hoc efficitur, atque
con&longs;equens e&longs;t, quod cuneo novâ percu&longs;&longs;ione ulteriùs adacto,
& Potentia ad hypomochlium, &longs;cilicet D ad I, accedat, & pon­
dus ab hypomochlio, &longs;cilicet E ab I, remotius fiat; igitur &
potentiæ momenta decre&longs;cerent, & ponderis momenta auge­
rentur; ac proinde hanc momentorum dece&longs;&longs;ionem, & acce&longs;­
&longs;ionem, major movendi difficultas, & quidem notabilis atque
con&longs;picua, con&longs;equeretur; quæ tamen cum experimentis non
con&longs;entit.

Adde in Vecte primi generis potentiam & pondus
oppo&longs;itis motibus circa hypomochlium, qua&longs;i circà centrum,
circulariter moveri; at hìc neque ullus intercedit circa
punctum I motus circularis, neque potentia de&longs;cendit pondere
a&longs;cendente.

At forta&longs;&longs;e, quod aliis magis placet, vectem ais e&longs;&longs;e &longs;ecundi
generis; pondus quippe in I &longs;u&longs;tinetur, & e&longs;t potentiæ in D
exi&longs;tenti proximum; quare hypomochlio relinquitur extre­
mum punctum E.

Id quidem aliquantò magis appo&longs;itè dictum
videretur, &longs;i, quæ vectis Rationibus conveniunt, hìc quoquè
in Cuneo locum habere po&longs;&longs;ent; Vectis &longs;iquidem quò longior
e&longs;t, & potentia magis abe&longs;t ab hypomochlio, cæteris paribus,
plus momenti tribuit potentiæ: at Cunei DE longitudo &longs;i au­
geatur, manente eodem angulo IEF, eádemque di&longs;tantiâ IE,
nullam facit momentorum acce&longs;&longs;ionem: nulla igitur ibi Vectis
Ratio intercedit.

Contrà verò manente eadem cunei DE lon­
gitudine, eademque di&longs;tantiâ IE, diminuto autem, &longs;ive aucto
angulo ad E eædem per&longs;everarent vectis Rationes; ergo & ea­
dem momenta movendi: id tamen longi&longs;&longs;imè à vero abe&longs;&longs;e
manife&longs;tis docemur experimentis, nam major angulus ad E
movendi difficultatem auget, minor minuit.

Cùm verò Cu­
neus, ex hypothe&longs;i, &longs;emper &longs;ubjecto plano incumbat, utique
potentia in D ab eo &longs;emper æqualiter di&longs;tat, & nunquam altiùs
a&longs;&longs;urgit, pondere tamen altiùs &longs;ublato, quo magis illi cuneus
&longs;ubjicitur: in Vecte autem &longs;ecundi generis potentia a&longs;cendit, &longs;i
pondus attollitur.

Non igitur cuneus habet rationem vectis &longs;e­
cundi generis; &longs;i maximè nullum hìc haberi circa hypomo­
chlium, tanquam circa centrum, motum circularem potentiæ
animadvertas.

Cùm itaque à Cuneo ab&longs;int Rationes Vectis, illius vires pe­
tendæ &longs;unt ex eo, quod olim con&longs;titutum e&longs;t, Facultatibus om­
nibus Mechanicis communi principio: videlicet, quia Cunei
forma ea e&longs;t, ut majore motu moveatur Potentia Cuneum im­
pellens, quàm pondus à Cuneo repul&longs;um ad latus; hoc minùs
re&longs;i&longs;tit, quàm &longs;i æquali motu cum potentiâ moveretur; atque
adeò impetus motum in potentiâ efficiens tantæ velocitatis, &
valens pari velocitate movere certum pondus, cui ine&longs;&longs;et æquè
inten&longs;us ac in potentiâ, poterit in majori pondere entitativè
æqualis, &longs;ed minùs inten&longs;us efficere motum tardiorem pro Ra­
tione minoris inten&longs;ionis, ita tamen, ut, quæ Ratio e&longs;&longs;et inten­
&longs;ionis majoris in minori pondere, ad inten&longs;ionem minorem in
majori pondere, ea pariter &longs;it Ratio majoris gravitatis ad mi­
norem gravitatem; &longs;ic enim contingit æqualem e&longs;&longs;e entitativè
motum tardiorem majoris ponderis, atque motum velociorem
minoris ponderis; quemadmodum aliàs in Vecte & in Tro­
chleâ explicatum e&longs;t.

Quoniam igitur cuneus, vi impetûs im­
pre&longs;&longs;i à potentia, dum promovetur &longs;ub pondus juxta lineam EF,
repellit pondus juxta lineam FI, linea EF motum potentiæ me­
titur, linea autem FI motum ponderis.

Atqui Cunei confor­
matio hoc habet, ut in triangulo EFI minimus angulus &longs;it ad
apicem E; igitur per 19. lib.
1 minimum latus e&longs;t FI, atque
proinde minùs movetur pondus per FI, quàm potentia per EF.
Quanto igitur major e&longs;t EF quàm FI, tanto majus e&longs;&longs;e pote&longs;t
gravitatis momentum in I vincendum, quàm e&longs;&longs;et momentum
gravitatis propellendæ in E juxta directionem FE motûs po­
tentiæ.

Hinc plani&longs;&longs;imè con&longs;tat, cur acutiores cunei majora habeant
movendi momenta, cæteris paribus.

Fac enim angulum E e&longs;&longs;e
adhuc minorem, utique oppo&longs;itum latus minus erit quàm FI;
eadem igitur linea EF ad lineam breviorem, quàm FI, habet
majorem Rationem, quàm ad eandem lineam FI; ac propterea
pondus adhuc multo tardiùs movetur quàm potentia, & pote­
rit e&longs;&longs;e majus; vel, &longs;i majus non fuerit, potentia indigebit mino­
re conatu, & faciliùs movebit.

Ob&longs;erva autem (quantum quidem ex Cunei Ratione e&longs;t) ut
&longs;e initium dederit, eandem &longs;emper e&longs;&longs;e facilitatem in proce&longs;&longs;u
motûs, quia eadem permanet Ratio motuum potentiæ cuneo
applicatæ, & ponderis: nam ex 4. lib.
6. ut EF ad FI, ita EG
ad CO, & IS, hoc e&longs;t FC, ad SO, propter triangulorum &longs;i­
militudinem, cùm &longs;it IS parallela ip&longs;i EC. Quantum, inquam,
e&longs;t ex Cunei Ratione; quandoquidem cubi H, dum manente
extremitate A elevatur ex I, momenta &longs;ubinde variari, &longs;uo lo­
co, &longs;uperiùs indicatum e&longs;t.

In &longs;cindendis autem corporibus,
prout variè contingit &longs;ci&longs;&longs;io, aliquando peculiaris intercedere
pote&longs;t cau&longs;a faciliorem vel difficiliorem in proce&longs;&longs;u &longs;ci&longs;&longs;ionem
reddens.

Et quidem in &longs;ci&longs;&longs;ione corporum vi cunei faciendâ non e&longs;t
ita proclivè Geometricas leges per&longs;equi, ad explicandam eo­
rum re&longs;i&longs;tentiam: neque enim &longs;icut gravitas loco dimovenda
facilè innote&longs;cit, certámque &longs;ub men&longs;uram cadit, ita corpo­
rum re&longs;i&longs;tentia, ne findantur, fieri pote&longs;t manife&longs;ta: E&longs;t &longs;iqui­
dem &longs;ci&longs;&longs;io partium conjunctarum &longs;eparatio; earum autem con­
junctionem adeò variam e&longs;&longs;e contingit, ut certam legem &longs;ubi­
re nequeat.

Nam quemadmodum inter lapides, ut monet Vi­
truvius lib.
2. cap.
7. alij ita molles &longs;unt, ut etiam &longs;erra dentatâ,
qua&longs;i ligna, &longs;ecentur, immò &longs;ecundùm oras maritimas ab &longs;al­
&longs;ugine exe&longs;a diffluant, & in locis patentibus atque apertis, prui­
ná & gelu frientur, ac di&longs;&longs;olvantur; alij duriores, &longs;ed qui inter­
veniorum vacuitates habeant, quapropter ab igne tuti non &longs;int,
quin rare&longs;cente aëre vacuitatibus illis interjecto di&longs;&longs;iliant & di&longs;-
&longs;ipentur; alii ita &longs;pi&longs;&longs;is compactionibus &longs;olidati, ut neque ab
tempe&longs;tatibus, neque ab ignis vehementiâ timeant: Ita pariter
inter ligna alia aliis &longs;olidiora &longs;unt, & unum præ alio faciliùs e&longs;t
fi&longs;&longs;ile, prout particulæ componentes cra&longs;&longs;iores, aut tenuiores,
&longs;unt magis aut minus exqui&longs;ite permi&longs;tæ, atque nimio, &longs;ive
modico, &longs;ive temperato humore concretæ, & prout juxta &longs;ta­
minum ductum, aut illa oblique &longs;ecando, in&longs;tituitur &longs;ci&longs;&longs;io.

Sunt autem corpora illa (quantum quidem ad præ&longs;entem
tractationem &longs;pectat) partium &longs;eparationi difficiliùs obnoxia,
quorum materia ita probè &longs;ubacta e&longs;t, ut eorum elementa in
minuti&longs;&longs;imas particulas conci&longs;a, & qua&longs;i individua corpu&longs;cula
in unam naturam inob&longs;ervabili permi&longs;tione temperata coalue­
rint eâ tantùm humoris copiâ, quæ &longs;atis fuerit ad illa firmiter
agglutinanda.

Ex quo fit, ut huju&longs;modi corpora &longs;olidiora &longs;int,
minú&longs;que con&longs;picuas inanitates admittant, atque proinde, &longs;i
expoliantur, &longs;uperficiem induant lævem & undique æquabi­
lem: id quod cæteris non accidit, quorum particulæ frequenti­
bus hiatibus interci&longs;æ, cùm aliæ emineant, aliæ &longs;uperentur,
&longs;emper aliquid habeant a&longs;peritatis; quemadmodum animadver­
tere poterit, qui&longs;quis lapides cum marmoribus comparaverit.

Si igitur ex &longs;olido corpore avellenda e&longs;t particula aliqua, hæc
i&longs;táque disjungenda e&longs;t à circum&longs;tantibus particulis, quibus
conjungitur, neque fieri pote&longs;t, ut illa moveatur, quin proxi­
marum particularum aliæ motui oppo&longs;itæ impellantur, aliæ
di&longs;trahantur; omnes autem ægrè à &longs;tatu &longs;ibi &longs;ecundùm natu­
ram debito recedentes repugnant: quò verò plures particulæ
vim &longs;ubire coguntur, eò major e&longs;t re&longs;i&longs;tentia plurium qua&longs;i col­
latis viribus &longs;imul repugnantium.

Hinc &longs;i duriora ligna &longs;ecan­
da offerantur, potior e&longs;t u&longs;us &longs;ubtilioris &longs;erræ minutos denticu­
los habentis; quia videlicet, quò exilior atque &longs;ubtilior e&longs;t den­
ticulus, minorem particulam obviam habet, quam impellat, &
pauciores particulæ, à quibus &longs;eparetur, illam circun&longs;tant;
ideóque ab iis faciliùs avellitur, quàm particula major, quæ à
pluribus disjungenda e&longs;&longs;et.

Contra verò quorum particulæ le­
vi impul&longs;u divelluntur, quia non adeò dura &longs;unt, cra&longs;&longs;iore &longs;er­
râ facilè &longs;ecantur, quæ in durioribus majorem re&longs;i&longs;tentiam in­
veniens parùm utilis accideret.

Hæc autem in limá pariter ob­
&longs;ervari po&longs;&longs;unt; quàm enim di&longs;&longs;ipari a&longs;peritate opus e&longs;t in limâ,
qua chalybs, aut qua lignum terendo expolitur?

Sed & in mar­
morum &longs;ectione mirantur aliqui &longs;erras adhiberi nullis dentibus,
&longs;altem con&longs;picuis, a&longs;peras, non &longs;atis animum advertentes ad
arenas aquâ a&longs;per&longs;as, quæ huju&longs;modi in opere interveniunt; ut
enim loquitur Plinius lib.
36. cap.
6. arená hoc fit, & ferro vide­
tur fieri, &longs;errá in prætenui lineâ premente arenas, ver&longs;andóque tractu
ip&longs;o &longs;ecante.

Expedit autem &longs;ubtiliore arenâ uti, cra&longs;&longs;ior enim are­
na laxioribus &longs;egmentis terit, & plus erodit marmoris, majú&longs;que
opus &longs;cabritiâ polituræ relinquit: Sunt &longs;cilicet arenæ granula tam
quæ premuntur, quàm quæ &longs;erræ adhærent, qua&longs;i denticuli
mobiles mordacis limæ eodem ductu tùm cru&longs;tarum faciem le­
viter expolientis, tùm &longs;ubjectum marmor &longs;ecantis.

E&longs;t autem manife&longs;tum non eâdem vi, qua &longs;uper lignum &longs;er­
ram adducentes & reducentes &longs;ci&longs;&longs;ionem inchoamus, idem pa­
riter obtineri, &longs;i cuneo lignum premamus citrà percu&longs;&longs;ionem:
quia nimirum cuneo prementes urgemus in directum &longs;ubjectas
ligni partes, quæ conjunctim re&longs;i&longs;tunt, ne comprimantur, at­
que à lateribus cohærentes particulæ repugnant, ne di&longs;trahan­
tur: &longs;erram verò ducentes obliquè urgemus ligni particulas
dentibus re&longs;pondentes, ac proinde pauculæ illæ tantùm, quæ
urgentur, re&longs;i&longs;tunt compre&longs;&longs;ioni, & illis attiguæ di&longs;tractioni.

Hinc fit cultro faciliùs aliquid &longs;cindi, &longs;i illius aciem quamvis
hebetem & obtu&longs;am adversùs corpus &longs;ci&longs;&longs;ile urgeas &longs;imul, atque
tran&longs;ver&longs;am agas; quia particulæ à cultro pre&longs;&longs;æ minorem in­
veniunt re&longs;i&longs;tentiam in tran&longs;ver&longs;o motu, ubi anteriores eâdem
cum po&longs;terioribus directione moventur, nec &longs;ibi adver&longs;antur,
quàm &longs;i &longs;olo pre&longs;&longs;u extimæ urgerent interiores, quæ comprimi
renuunt.

Huc pariter referenda e&longs;t cau&longs;a, cur adeò valida con­
tingat &longs;ci&longs;&longs;io, &longs;i Harpe ictus infligatur: &longs;ic huju&longs;modi genere
en&longs;is in &longs;ummitate falcati, & in exteriore latere exacuti u&longs;um
Per&longs;eum in amputando Medu&longs;æ capite, & Mercurium in occi­
dendo Argo centoculo refert Ovidius lib.
5. Metam. Vertit in
hunc Harpem madefactam cæde Medu&longs;æ: id enim non ex &longs;olâ
Harpes gravitate, &longs;ed ex ip&longs;o poti&longs;&longs;imùm flexu oritur, qui ef­
ficit, ut dum vi impetùs de&longs;cendit, acies etiam tran&longs;ver&longs;o mo­
tu ducatur &longs;upra partes corporis &longs;ci&longs;&longs;ilis; ex quo & facilior &longs;ci&longs;­
&longs;io.

Sic quidam vulgari en&longs;e, quo equitantes viatores non in
&longs;peciem, &longs;ed ad u&longs;um, præcingi &longs;olent, vituli caput uno ictu
amputabat; aver&longs;o &longs;cilicet ictu percutiens gladius circulum
de&longs;cribebat, adeóque non &longs;olùm premendo &longs;ecabat, verùm
etiam motu tran&longs;ver&longs;o: quo in negotio dexteritate potiùs,
quàm viribus opus e&longs;t.

Quòd autem alij re&longs;imum Harpes la­
tus in canaliculum excavant, eíque aliquid argenti vivi in­
dunt, quod à capulo ad cu&longs;pidem excurrat, id faciunt ad per­
cu&longs;&longs;ionem augendam, quia tran&longs;lata ad cu&longs;pidem gravitate
Mercurij, etiam percu&longs;&longs;ionis centrum transfertur longiùs à ca­
pulo, ideóque ictus fit validior, accedente præ&longs;ertim impetu,
quem Mercurius de&longs;cendens concipit.

Non e&longs;t itaque comparandus gladius motu tran&longs;ver&longs;o &longs;cin­
dens cum &longs;errâ &longs;ecante; hæc enim obvias particulas in &longs;cabem
abeuntes &longs;en&longs;im à ligno divellens illud demum &longs;ublatis omni­
bus intermediis particulis bifariam divi&longs;um relinquit: ille ve­
rò &longs;uâ acie premens atque penetrans, &longs;ed nihil abradens, inter­
ponitur partibus, quæ invicem &longs;eparantur.

Motus &longs;erræ motui
particularum ab&longs;ci&longs;&longs;arum planè æqualis e&longs;t; dens quippe parti­
culam, in quam incurrit, tangens impellit, &longs;uóque impul&longs;u vin­
cens nexum, quo particula &longs;ibi cohærentibus jungebatur, illam
avellit.

Tran&longs;ver&longs;us verò gladij motus &longs;i comparetur cum mo­
tu particularum compre&longs;&longs;arum, atque invicem divul&longs;arum,
multò major e&longs;t illo; nam culter manûs moventis motui ob&longs;e­
cundat; & particulæ compre&longs;&longs;æ in latus recedunt; ac proinde
multo velociùs movetur potentia gladium adducens aut redu­
cens, quàm id, cui hoc motu vis infertur: atque idcircò gladij
vis &longs;cindendi hoc motu refertur ad cuneum.

Quòd &longs;i gladius
non motu tran&longs;ver&longs;o ducatur &longs;uper id, quod &longs;cinditur, &longs;ed om­
nino motu recto pre&longs;&longs;ionis, &longs;it autem ferri cra&longs;&longs;ities &longs;en&longs;im exte­
nuata in aciem, quemadmodum cuneis omnibus commune e&longs;t,
idem planè dicendum erit, quod de vulgari cuneo, cui nomen
hoc præcipuè inditum e&longs;t.

Quare Cuneus in corpus &longs;cindendum adactus con&longs;iderandus
e&longs;t ratione habitâ ip&longs;ius corporis, quod tenerum ac molle e&longs;&longs;e
pote&longs;t, atque ita flexibile, ut &longs;equatur quocunque torqueas, aut
etiam durum, & minimè tractabile.

Si molle illud &longs;it, immi&longs;­
&longs;um cuneum recipit, séque illi accommodat, & comprimun­
tur tùm &longs;ubjectæ particulæ cunei aciem tangentes, tùm quæ à
lateribus cunei faciei congruunt: illæ omnino æqualiter pro-
moventur, ac adigitur cuneus, neque motus earum à cuneo
pendet, quâ cuneus e&longs;t, &longs;ed quâ corpus e&longs;t &longs;uâ mole objectam
molem trudens: hæ verò ad latus &longs;ecedentes magis & magis,
prout cunei cra&longs;&longs;itudo excre&longs;cit, minori motu moventur, quàm
promoveatur immi&longs;&longs;us Cuneus; quandoquidem major e&longs;t cunei
longitudo eju&longs;dem motum metiens, quàm cra&longs;&longs;ities dextras at­
que &longs;ini&longs;tras partes impellens.

Sin autem durum &longs;it corpus, cui
cuneus in&longs;eritur, illud quidem vix excogitari pote&longs;t ex adeò
con&longs;tipatis partibus inter &longs;e quàm apti&longs;&longs;imè cohærentibus con­
&longs;tare, ut nullius pror&longs;us compre&longs;&longs;ionis &longs;it capax, neque vel te­
nui&longs;&longs;imum cunei apicem admittat.

Comprimuntur igitur ini­
tio partes proximè cuneo &longs;ubjectæ multò magis, quàm quæ la­
teri adjacent; &longs;ed propter duritiem certum compre&longs;&longs;ionis mo­
dum natura finivit, extra quem &longs;ubjectas partes diffindi potiùs
patiatur, atque à &longs;e mutuò divelli.

Qua in fi&longs;&longs;ione ip&longs;æ etiam
&longs;uperiores partes majori compre&longs;&longs;ioni &longs;emper validiùs re­
pugnantes, quò penitiùs adigitur cuneus, plurimum habent
momenti, ut cunei vis, quâ cuneus e&longs;t, exerceatur: Quia vide­
licet &longs;uperiores partes cum inferioribus connexæ, neque flexi­
biles, dum ad latera cuneo urgente &longs;ecedunt, cogunt pariter in­
feriores ad dexteram & ad &longs;ini&longs;tram recedere; atque propterea
quæ adhuc connexæ erant, di&longs;trahuntur ita, ut demum di­
vellantur.

Sit cuneus HI in &longs;ubjectum lignum immi&longs;&longs;us inter B & C;
dum percu&longs;&longs;ione urgetur
intror&longs;um, partes B versùs
A, & partes C ver&longs;us D re­
cedunt, & cum illis pariter
inferiores BM, atque CM:
ex quo fit partes in M con­
nexas di&longs;trahi atque invi­
cem divelli, & &longs;ci&longs;&longs;ionem
longiùs promoveri.

Cum
igitur hoc &longs;it propo&longs;itum cuneo &longs;cindere &longs;ubjectum corpus, non
attendendus e&longs;t &longs;impliciter motus in B & C, &longs;ed etiam qui in M
efficitur, ibi quippe &longs;ci&longs;&longs;io contingit, &longs;emperque longiùs di&longs;tat
à punctis B, & C, locus &longs;ci&longs;&longs;ionis, quò magis intror&longs;um urge­
tur cuneus.

Ex quo fit attentè di&longs;tinguendam e&longs;&longs;e facilitatem
adigendi cunei, à facilitate &longs;cindendi: quandiu enim partes
faciem cunei tangentes non admodum repugnant compre&longs;&longs;io­
ni, facilè cedunt adacto cuneo; ubi verò ulteriùs comprimi
renuunt, tota vis exercenda e&longs;t in di&longs;tractione partium &longs;ejun­
gendarum; quam di&longs;tractionem quò majorem e&longs;&longs;e contingit,
augetur &longs;anè & cunei adigendi, & &longs;cindendi difficultas.

Hæc
tamen alio ex capite minuitur, quia, quò magis punctum M, in
quo di&longs;trahendæ &longs;unt partes conjunctæ, abe&longs;t à punctis B & C,
faciliùs con&longs;equitur &longs;ci&longs;&longs;io, nam, cæteris paribus, motus particu­
larum, quæ &longs;ejunguntur, minorem habet Rationem ad motum
punctorum B & C.

Sic fu&longs;tem cra&longs;&longs;iorem ab alterâ extremitate
fi&longs;&longs;um juxta notabilem longitudinem ulteriùs findimus etiam
&longs;olis manibus eò faciliùs, quò longior fuerit prior &longs;ci&longs;&longs;io: plu­
rimum &longs;iquidem intere&longs;t in lignis, quorum textura certum
quendam & rectum &longs;taminum ordinem habet, utrùm juxta eo­
rumdem &longs;taminum ductum in&longs;tituatur &longs;ci&longs;&longs;io, an hæc obliquè
&longs;ecentur; quemadmodum & in lapidibus præ&longs;tat cuneum in­
terveniis applicare, ut faciliùs &longs;cindantur: propterea nodo&longs;is
arborum partibus applicatus Cuneus ægrè illas findit, quia no­
dorum &longs;tamina non recto tramite, &longs;ed per anfractus & tortuosè
procedunt.

In hac autem ligni &longs;ci&longs;&longs;ione &longs;i placeat tum particu­
las, quæ in M di&longs;trahuntur, tum illis &longs;ubjectas atque adhuc im­
motas, puta in N con&longs;iderare, atque ve&longs;tigium aliquod dupli­
cis Vectis &longs;ecundi generis recogno&longs;cere, itaut commune hypo­
mochlium &longs;it in N, longitudines vectium BN, & CN, poten­
tia medio cuneo applicata in B & C, atque re&longs;i&longs;tentia vincen­
da in M; non me difficilem præbebo: &longs;ed & illud &longs;tatim ad­
dam, non e&longs;&longs;e hunc duplicem illum Vectem, quem alij in Cu­
neo quærunt; cum potiùs &longs;int duo vectes in diver&longs;a impul&longs;i ab
interjecto cuneo.

Quapropter ex his; quæ latiùs explicare placuit, illud confi­
citur, quod Cuneo aliquando re&longs;i&longs;tit gravitas, ut cùm ille cor­
pori gravi elevando &longs;upponitur, aut cùm disjunctorum quidem
corporum gravium, &longs;ed proximorum, &longs;altem alterum remove­
tur; aliquando re&longs;i&longs;tit partium nexus in M, qui ni&longs;i &longs;olvatur,
propelli nequeunt partes B & C cunei faciem tangentes: vis &longs;i­
quidem cunei proximè exercetur adversùs B & C, & propter
partium connexionem etiam adversùs M, quamvis hoc po&longs;tre-
mum &longs;it &longs;copus &longs;cindentis: quò autem validiùs partes in M
conjunguntur, etiam difficiliùs urgentur partes B & C: ligna
verò adhuc viridia, & lento humore plena, quia particulæ ma­
jorem di&longs;tractionem ferunt, nec facilè di&longs;&longs;iliunt, difficiliùs
&longs;cinduntur, quàm ligna arida.

Quæ itaque de Cuneo vulgari dicta &longs;unt, facilè innote&longs;cit
ea pariter convenire forficibus, cultris en&longs;ibus, novaculis, &longs;cal­
pris, dentibus hominis anterioribus, & &longs;imilibus, quibus ad
&longs;cindendum utimur; &longs;unt enim cunei diver&longs;imodè juxta varios
u&longs;us conformati; neque egent percu&longs;&longs;ione, quia res &longs;cindendæ
non admodum re&longs;i&longs;tunt, & &longs;olus impul&longs;us &longs;æpè &longs;ufficit.

Forfi­
ces autem &longs;unt quidem cunei, &longs;ed vectem conjunctum haben­
tes, adeò ut potentia momenti augmentum acquirat ex Ratio­
nibus vectis juxta di&longs;tantias tùm potentiæ, tùm corporis &longs;cin­
dendi, à clavo, ubi decu&longs;&longs;antur.

An verò etiam &longs;calpra, qui­
bus Marmorarij a&longs;&longs;ulas ex operibus dejiciunt; Cuneorum ratio­
nem habeant, non admodum curo; videntur &longs;iquidem non in­
cidere marmor, &longs;ed partes &longs;uperfluas decutere: quod &longs;i per­
cu&longs;&longs;i &longs;calpri mucro penetrat, & dividit marmor, cuneus perin­
de e&longs;t atque &longs;calpra, quibus lignum cælatur.

Similiter acus, &longs;ubulæ, aculei, clavi ad cuneum referun­
tur: & quidem huju&longs;modi corpora quò &longs;ubtiliora &longs;unt, eò fa­
ciliùs penetrant, quia immi&longs;&longs;a, & juxta &longs;uam longitudinem
progredientia valdè moventur interea, dum corporis perforan­
di particulæ di&longs;trahendæ atque comprimendæ exiguo motu in
latera &longs;ecedunt.

Hinc con&longs;tat, cur terebellâ paulo minore ape­
riendum &longs;it foramen, cui immittatur clavus cra&longs;&longs;iu&longs;culus, &longs;i
præ&longs;ertim lignum tenue &longs;it; ne videlicet immi&longs;&longs;o clavo tot par­
tes adeò invicem comprimantur, ut ulteriorem compre&longs;&longs;ionem
recu&longs;antes cogant alias di&longs;trahi, ac demum rimâ factâ lignum
di&longs;&longs;iliat: &longs;ublatis autem terebrâ particulis aliquot, reliquæ com­
primendæ ut clavum arctè complectantur, cum pauciores &longs;int,
faciliùs compre&longs;&longs;ionem ferunt citrà periculum fractionis aut
&longs;ci&longs;&longs;ionis ligni.

Demum &longs;ecuris, & gladius cæ&longs;im feriens, cuneus e&longs;t, cui quo­
dammodo junctus e&longs;t tudes; illo &longs;iquidem percutimus: quid enim
intere&longs;t, quod cuneum manentem tudite percutiamus, &longs;ive cu­
neo velociter moto percutiatur corpus &longs;cindendum?
CAPUT II.
Cunei inflexi u&longs;us ad movendum.

PRæter vulgarem Cunei formam, quæ planis extremitatibus
circum&longs;cribitur, &longs;i non ad &longs;cindendum, &longs;ed ad movendum
adhibeatur, utilis e&longs;&longs;e pote&longs;t Cuneus inflexus, ita ut, qua &longs;al­
tem parte movendo corpori applicatur, faciem habeat non pla­
nam, &longs;ed inflexam, moveatur autem non circa eju&longs;dem circu­
laris curvitatis centrum.

In cra&longs;&longs;iore tabulâ a&longs;&longs;umpto A puncto
tanquam centro de&longs;cribatur pla­
cito intervallo AB pars arcûs
circuli BC, &longs;ive Quadrans, &longs;ive
Quadrante minor, &longs;ive major
fuerit.

Tum centro alio a&longs;&longs;ump­
to, & majore aliquo intervallo,
alia circuli pars de&longs;cribatur DC
occurrens priori arcui BC in
puncto C, &longs;ive ibi &longs;e contingant,
&longs;ive &longs;ecent arcus, prout tibi
commodius acciderit.

Re&longs;ecatis igitur &longs;upervacuis tabulæ par­
tibus, & retentâ parte curvilineâ, habetur cuneus BCD in­
flexus, qui &longs;uam vim exerceat non motu recto, ut cæteri cunei,
&longs;ed curvo: propterea illi ad firmitatem addantur tran&longs;ver&longs;aria
ab extremitatibus cunei exeuntia, & in unum punctum coëun­
tia, circa quod, tanquam centrum, moveri po&longs;&longs;it cuneus.

Ad
firmitatem, inquam, quia, ad motum, &longs;atis e&longs;&longs;et cra&longs;&longs;iori ex­
tremitati BD addere appendicem BM, in qua a&longs;&longs;umi po&longs;&longs;it
punctum, circa quod moveatur, quodcumque illud &longs;it, modò
non &longs;it centrum arcûs DC, &longs;i arcus ille impellat corpus moven­
dum, neque punctum D minùs di&longs;tet ab huju&longs;modi centro mo­
tûs, quàm punctum aliud extremum C.

Contra verò &longs;i cunei
conatus exercendus &longs;it trahendo, & corpori applicetur arcus
BC, oportet centrum motûs minùs abe&longs;&longs;e ab extremitate B,
quàm ab apice cunei C.

Hùc &longs;cilicet &longs;pectare videntur ferrei
uncini, quibus duo corpora fibulantur, aut refibulantur, ut
cum armaria, fene&longs;træ, aut cap&longs;ulæ clauduntur & recludun­
tur.

Quare intellectâ rectâ DM tanquam parte diametri cir­
culi, cujus arcus exerceat vim cunei, &longs;i hic &longs;it arcus DC,
oportet ejus centrum inter extremitatem D, & punctum M
centrum motûs, interjacere; &longs;in autem &longs;it arcus BC, inter A
centrum circuli, & extremitatem B, oportet interjici centrum
motûs H: ab illo quippe centro M in primo ca&longs;u removeri
oportet corpus movendum, & ad hoc centrum H accedere
oportet corpus trahendum.

Quod &longs;i recta DM non fuerit pars
diametri tran&longs;euntis per centra arcûs & motûs, &longs;altem oportet
illam huju&longs;modi diametro propiorem e&longs;&longs;e, quàm &longs;it recta ex
centro motûs ad C ducta; id quod ex 7.lib.3. manife&longs;tum e&longs;t.

Firmato itaque pro loci opportunitate centro motûs, & appli­
catum ad impellendum pondus cuneum BCD urgens poten­
tia in D, de&longs;cribit circa M centrum motûs arcum circularem
DE, &longs;ed pondus non propellitur ni&longs;i juxta differentiam linea­
rum à punctis arcûs DC ad M centrum motûs ductarum.

Ex
quo fit movendi facilitatem
&longs;ubinde augeri, cæteris pa­
ribus.

Hoc autem ut pla­
niùs explicetur, &longs;it arcus
LQ in quinque æquales
partes divi&longs;us, & &longs;ingulæ
&longs;int gr. 3. linea HL tran­
&longs;eat per centrum I, & ex H
ducantur rectæ HM, HN,
HO &c; Certum e&longs;t lineas
ha&longs;ce omnes ex Q ad L
&longs;emper majores e&longs;&longs;e, & ma­
ximam e&longs;&longs;e HL ex 7. lib.
3. atque a&longs;&longs;umptâ HF æquali ip&longs;i
HQ, differentiam totam e&longs;&longs;e FL.

Quare &longs;i LQ &longs;it latus cu­
nei inflexi, potentia de&longs;cribens arcum æqualem arcui LQ ha­
beret motum, qui ad motum ponderis e&longs;&longs;et ut arcus LQ ad
rectam FL, &longs;eu QS.

Sed quoniam centrum motûs e&longs;t H, po­
tentia circa illud de&longs;cribit arcum LS, cujus quantitas inno­
te&longs;cit, &longs;i dato IL, hoc e&longs;t IQ, Radio, atque di&longs;tantiâ IH,
cùm ex hypothe&longs;i notus &longs;it angulus LIQ, inve&longs;tigetur angu­
lus IHQ, quem metitur arcus LS; hujus autem quantitas
prodit ex datis partibus Radij HL.

Quare angulus LIQ &longs;it
gr. 15. IL partium 10000, IH partium 5000. Igitur in trian­
gulo HIQ angulus IHQ e&longs;t gr. 10. 0′.

45″: atque &longs;i ex Cy­
clometricis ineatur Ratio men&longs;uræ arcûs LS, invenietur in
partibus Radij IL 10000 ferè par arcui LQ hic e&longs;t partium
2618, ille 2621. Quapropter in tam exiguâ circuli portione
perinde e&longs;t arcum LQ, atque arcum LS con&longs;iderare.

Singu­
læ itaque partes quintæ arcûs de&longs;cripti &longs;unt particularum 524.

Jam verò per Trigonometriam, ex datis lateribus HI 5000,
& IM 10000, atque angulo comprehen&longs;o HIM, ut pote &longs;up­
plemento ad duos rectos noti anguli LIM ex hypothe&longs;i gr. 3.
(&longs;imiliter in reliquis triangulis eadem &longs;unt latera, & angulus
comprehen&longs;us &longs;en&longs;im per gr. 3. minuitur) inveniatur linearum
longitudo; & e&longs;t in ii&longs;dem Radij IL partibus 10000 linea
HQ 14885, HP 14927, HO 14959, HN 14981, HM 14995,
atque demum HL 15000. Sunt igitur linearum ex Q ad L in­
crementa inæqualia, videlicet 42, 32, 22, 14, 5, quibus re&longs;pon­
det motus ponderis cuneo propul&longs;i, qui &longs;emper decre&longs;cit, dum
potentia motus æquales perficit.

Ratio proinde motûs potentiæ
ad motum ponderis initio, dum cunei pars QP &longs;ubinde ponde­
ri applicatur, atque Potentia venit ex L in M, e&longs;t ut 524 ad 42,
deinde in PO ut 524 ad 32, in ON ut 524 ad 22, in NM ut
524 ad 14, in ML ut 524 ad 5. Cum itaque &longs;emper major fiat
Ratio motuum, augetur movendi facilitas; atque perinde fit,
ac &longs;i acutior &longs;emper atque acutior cuneus adhiberetur.

Hìc tamen ob&longs;ervandum e&longs;t ita temperandum e&longs;&longs;e movendi
facilitatem cum ip&longs;o ponderis motu, ut illam con&longs;ectando hoc
minùs moveri non contingat, quàm par fuerit: quò enim
punctum, quod e&longs;t centrum motûs, minùs abe&longs;t ab I centro
arcûs LQ, eò quidem faciliùs movetur pondus, quia ad hujus
motum potentiæ motus majorem habet Rationem, &longs;ed à pon­
dere minus &longs;patium percurritur.

Nam &longs;i centrum motûs &longs;it G,
& IG partium 2500, quarum IQ e&longs;t 10000, linea GQ e&longs;t
12432, GP 12456, GO 12475, GN 12489, GM 12497,
GL 12500: atque adeò linearum incrementa &longs;unt 24, 19, 14, 8, 3;
cum tamen quinta pars arcûs intervallo GL de&longs;cripti à poten-
tiâ &longs;it proximè 524; Major e&longs;t autem Ratio 524 ad &longs;ingula hæc
linearum incrementa, quàm cum motûs centrum e&longs;t H.

Cum
hac tamen movendi facilitate connectitur exiguus ponderis mo­
tus; nam inter 12432 & 12500, quæ &longs;unt extremæ lineæ GQ
& GL, differentia 68 minor e&longs;t quàm differentia 115 inter HQ
14885 & HL 15000, quæ differentia inter extremas lineas me­
titur ponderis motum: e&longs;t &longs;iquidem differentia inter aggrega­
tum laterum & ba&longs;im trianguli HIQ, aut GIQ, men&longs;ura, juxta
quam pondus promovetur impul&longs;u cunei.

Cum verò IQ & IL,
utpote &longs;emidiametri, æquales &longs;int, ba&longs;is autem HQ major &longs;it ba&longs;i
GQ (nam in triangulo HGQ amblygonio ba&longs;is HQ opponi­
tur majori angulo) fieri non pote&longs;t, ut eadem &longs;it motûs ponderis
men&longs;ura æqualis ip&longs;is FL aut QS, ni&longs;i ab a&longs;&longs;umpto motûs centro
de&longs;criptus arcus (intervallo u&longs;que ad Q punctum illi centro pro­
ximum) tran&longs;eat per extremitates ea&longs;dem Q & F, per quas tran­
&longs;iret arcus ex H intervallo HQ de&longs;criptus.

Quare duo circuli
&longs;e in duobus punctis &longs;ecantes communem haberent rectam li­
neam QF, ad quam bifariam &longs;ectam in V perpendicularis VH
tran&longs;iret per utriu&longs;que circuli centrum, ex 3. lib.
3. ac proinde,
cum ex.

5. lib.3. non habeant idem centrum H, alterius circuli
centrum e&longs;&longs;et extra rectam HI, puta in T.

Utrùm autem dato eodem motûs centro, & datâ pari arcûs
portione, præ&longs;tet arcum e&longs;&longs;e majoris, an minoris, circuli partem,
vix e&longs;t dubitandi locus.

Quando enim duo circuli idem planum
in eodem puncto contingunt, peripheria majoris interjicitur in­
ter planum datum & peripheriam minoris circuli; atque adeò
ab eodem motûs centro lineæ ad illam majoris circuli periphe­
riam ductæ omnes &longs;ecant peripheriam minoris, ac propterea, ut­
pote longiores, majorem efficiunt pre&longs;&longs;ionem, longiú&longs;que pro­
pellunt corpus, quod impellitur.

Hinc &longs;i viribus potentia abun­
det, & ad majus &longs;patium protrudere oporteat pondus, adhiben­
da e&longs;t peripheria majoris circuli; contra verò minore utendum
e&longs;t, &longs;i parum movendum &longs;it, & potentia imbecillior.
Porrò hìc exerceri cunei vires, quis ambigat?

neque enim
admodum intere&longs;t, plana-ne?
an inflexa?

&longs;it ejus facies, modò
ex ejus interjectu duo disjuncta corpora magis invicem remo­
veantur, &longs;ive utrumque &longs;imul in diver&longs;as partes abeant, &longs;ive al­
tero manente, alterum tantummodo moveatur.

Hìc autem im-
motum manet centrum, circa quod vertitur portio circuli ex­
centrici, quæ &longs;ive &longs;implici impul&longs;ione, &longs;ive etiam percu&longs;&longs;ione,
adacta urget corpus, quod contingit, neque aliter quàm &longs;i inter
validum &longs;tipitem humi defixum, atque pondus interjiceretur
vulgaris cuneus planus.

Verùm quamvis hactenus potentiam in ip&longs;a cunei inflexi ex­
tremitate po&longs;uerimus ad explicandum ejus motum, nihil tamen
refert: nam &longs;i etiam circa medium cuneum fuerit an&longs;a, qua ar­
reptâ ille valeat circumduci, perinde e&longs;t; motus &longs;iquidem po­
tentiæ ad ponderis motum eandem &longs;ervat Rationem.

Ex quo
manife&longs;tò deprehenditur nullam e&longs;&longs;e in Cuneo Vectis umbram;
in Vecte &longs;iquidem certus e&longs;t potentiæ locus, quo mutato etiam
momenta variantur: at in huju&longs;modi Cuneo non contingit mo­
mentorum mutatio, cuju&longs;cumque tandem cunei parti applice­
tur potentia, dummodo ea &longs;it di&longs;po&longs;itio, ut vires &longs;uas æquè exer­
cere valeat, &longs;ive in hac, &longs;ive in illâ arcûs extremitate, hoc e&longs;t ad
L aut Q, &longs;ive circa medium ad O, aut N, con&longs;tituatur.

Cave ta­
men putes æquè liberum e&longs;&longs;e in majore aut minore di&longs;tantiâ à
centro motûs H aut G potentiam collocare: id enim &longs;anè per­
peram fieret; pro Ratione &longs;iquidem di&longs;tantiæ à centro motûs
majorem aut minorem arcum potentia &longs;uo motu de&longs;criberet:
e&longs;to nihil inter&longs;it, cuinam parti applicetur, &longs;ervatâ eâdem à præ­
dicto motûs centro di&longs;tantiâ.

Propterea &longs;i ad Q applicetur po­
tentia cuneum trahens, an&longs;a eju&longs;modi apponenda e&longs;t &longs;ur&longs;um re­
curva, cui applicata potentia non minorem arcum de&longs;cribat,
quàm &longs;i illa applicaretur puncto L impellens cuneum: non e&longs;t
&longs;cilicet par potentiæ motus, qui fit intervallo HQ, ac interval­
lo HL.

Similiter autem Cuneo plano uti licebit, cujus latera &longs;i
ferreo paxillo hinc atque hinc extante trajeceris, ut arreptis
utrâque manu paxilli extremitatibus cuneum adducere valëas,
aut impellere, duo corpora, quibus cuneus interjicitur, disjun­
ges: immò &longs;i fi&longs;&longs;ili ligno bicubitali juxta &longs;taminum ductum cu­
neum eumdem ita per vim immi&longs;eris, ut cuneum elevatum &longs;e­
quatur pariter & lignum, tùm ligni calce &longs;axum percu&longs;&longs;eris,
cuneus &longs;ci&longs;&longs;ionem promovebit, quocumque tandem in loco &longs;ive
juxta ip&longs;ius cunei apicem, &longs;ive juxta ba&longs;im immi&longs;&longs;us fuerit pa­
xillus ille, cui potentia applicatur.
CAPUT III.
Cuneus perpetuus circulo excentrico effingitur.

CUneum Perpetuum voco non eum, qui perpetuâ, hoc e&longs;t
majore &longs;emper atque majore impul&longs;ione corpus propellat
longiùs atque longiùs; id enim, ut &longs;atis clarum e&longs;t, infinitam
exigeret cunei longitudinem: &longs;ed eatenus dico perpetuum, qua­
tenus potentia illi &longs;emel applicata in&longs;titutum motum juxta ean­
dem directionem perpetuare pote&longs;t: id quod neutiquam con­
tingit &longs;ecundùm rectam lineam, quæ &longs;patium requireret infini­
tum perpetuo illo motu percurrendum; &longs;ed potentia in orbem
progrediens, & cuneum contorquens, motus alternos perficit.

Et primùm quidem id fieri pote&longs;t circulo, cujus motûs cen­
trum ab&longs;it ab eju&longs;dem circuli centro; vis enim cunei erit ad
propellendum corpus intervallo duplo intervalli centrorum;
momentum verò potentiæ de&longs;umetur ex &longs;emiperipheriâ circuli,
cujus Radius æqualis &longs;it dati circuli &longs;emidiametro auctæ cen­
trorum illorum intervallo; &longs;i tamen extremitati à centro motûs
maximè di&longs;tanti ip&longs;a potentia applicetur.

Sit datus circulus BED, cujus centrum A: fiat motûs cen­
trum C, circa quod in gyrum
agatur con&longs;titutus circulus.

In hoc motu duo circuli con­
centrici de&longs;cribuntur; alter
quidem à puncto D, Radio
CD, alter verò à puncto B,
Radio CB.

Quare dum po­
tentia ex B per G venit in H,
punctum D per K venit in L,
& corpus, quod puncto D ap­
plicitum erat, à peripheriâ
circuli BED &longs;en&longs;im propel­
litur, donec veniat ex D in H.

E&longs;t autem DH æqualis ip&longs;i
BL, quia ex æqualibus CH & CB auferuntur æquales CD
& CL: inter diametros verò BD & LD differentia e&longs;t BL:
igitur quia diametrorum differentia dupla e&longs;t differentiæ &longs;emi­
diametrorum, BL e&longs;t dupla ip&longs;ius AC differentiæ &longs;emidiame­
trorum AD & CD.

Quapropter etiam DH &longs;patium, quod à
pondere propul&longs;o percurritur, duplum e&longs;t intervalli centrorum
AC Demùm potentia in B, ex hypothe&longs;i, applicata momentum
habet juxta Rationem &longs;emiperipheriæ BGH ad &longs;patium DH
duplum intervalli centrorum AC: hæc &longs;iquidem e&longs;t Ratio mo­
tuum potentiæ & ponderis.

Hinc &longs;i ponatur dati circuli Ra­
dius AB 100, & centrorum di&longs;tantia AC 13, erit DH 26: At
&longs;emiperipheria BGH ad &longs;uum Radium BC e&longs;t ut 355 ad 113;
igitur BGH ad DH e&longs;t ut 355 ad 26. Quare, cæteris paribus,
quò majus e&longs;t centrorum intervallum, eò majores requiruntur
in potentiâ vires; quia hujus intervalli duplum e&longs;t &longs;patium, per
quod impellitur pondus, manente eodem potentiæ motu.

E&longs;t autem attentè con&longs;iderandum, utrùm præ&longs;tet, cæteris paribus,
majore circulo uti: Cæteris, inquam, paribus, ut &longs;cilicet idem &longs;it
centrorum intervallum, & eadem potentiæ à centro motûs di&longs;tan­
tia.

Et primò ob&longs;ervandum e&longs;t cuneum e&longs;&longs;e LBED, cujus vertex
e&longs;t angulus contingentiæ factus à peripheriâ dati circuli, & à pe­
ripheriâ circuli, quem circa centrum C in motu de&longs;cribit extre­
mitas D.

Deinde &longs;emiperipheria BGH à potentiâ de&longs;cripta in
motu (& e&longs;t ex hypothe&longs;i partium 355, quarum Radius CB e&longs;t 113)
dividatur in partes æquales duodecim, ita ut &longs;ingulæ re&longs;pon­
deant gradibus 15, & &longs;ingulis competant partes 29 1/2. Similiter
&longs;emiperipheria DOL in 12 æquales partes &longs;ingulas gr.15. divi­
datur: adeò ut cùm linea BD circa punctum C circumacta an­
gulum gr. 15 de&longs;crip&longs;erit, potentia &longs;it progre&longs;&longs;a per partes 29 1/2.
Examinandum e&longs;t, quanto &longs;patio interim propellatur pondus,
quod erat in D, versùs H.

Sit angulus DCO, hoc e&longs;t arcus DO, gr. 15: ducta intelli­
gatur recta CO u&longs;que in N peripheriam dati circuli; e&longs;t igitur
ON motus ponderis ex D ver&longs;us H.

Quapropter inve&longs;tiganda
e&longs;t ip&longs;ius CN longitudo, ut appareat eju&longs;dem exce&longs;&longs;us &longs;upra
CD.

Ducatur dati circuli Radius AN notus partium 100; da­
tur item intervallum AC partium 13; notus e&longs;t angulus ACN
gr. 165: ergo per Trigonometriam innote&longs;cit primò angu­
lus CNA gr.1.55′. 41″; atque ex eo reliquus angulus NAC
gr.13.4′. 19″, hoc e&longs;t arcus ND: deinde habetur longitudo
CN partium (87 38/100), quarum CO, hoc e&longs;t CD e&longs;t 87: igitur
ON e&longs;t (38/100). Quod &longs;i arcus DO ponatur gr. 30, in triangulo
ACN dantur eadem latera AN 100, & AC 13, & angulus ACN
gr. 150: igitur invenitur CNA gr.3. 43′.

37″; atque angulus
NAC, hoc e&longs;t arcus ND gr. 26. 16′.

23″, & linea CN par­
tium (88 52/100): igitur ON e&longs;t part. (1 52/100). Atarcus DO &longs;it gr. 45;
e&longs;t angulus ACN gr. 135: datis ii&longs;dem lateribus AN 100, &
AC 13, invenitur angulus CNA gr. 5. 16′.

27″, atque angu­
lus NAC, hoc e&longs;t arcus ND gr. 39. 43′.

33″. & linea CN
part. (90 38/100): igitur ON part. (3 38/100). Similiter &longs;i DO &longs;it gr. 60:

9″: ac

Ex his manife&longs;tò con&longs;tat initio motûs in primo quadrante à
circulo majore paulò ampliùs propelli pondus ex D versùs H,
quàm à circulo minore, datâ angulorum motûs ad centrum C
paritate.

Verùm in circulo majoris diametri non &longs;olùm pari
graduum numero re&longs;pondet longior arcus pro Ratione diame­
trorum, &longs;ed etiam, ut ex &longs;uperioribus calculis con&longs;tat, major
circulus plures gradus ponderi coaptat, quàm minor.

Sic in
motu ad centrum C gr. 15, circulo minori, cujus Radius 100,
competunt gr. 13. 4′.

19″; at circulo majori, cujus Radius 200,
competunt gr. 14. 2′.

Quare præterquam quod duplex e&longs;t
longitudo arcus majoris, quia duplex e&longs;t Radius, adhuc &longs;u­
pere&longs;t longitudo gr. 0. 57′.

50″: cum tamen motus ponderis in
minore &longs;it (38/100), in majore (40/100); quod di&longs;crimen (2/100) longè minus e&longs;t
illo exce&longs;&longs;u arcûs.

Quapropter &longs;i Potentia peripheriæ dati circuli partibus &longs;ub­
inde applicetur (ut &longs;i extarent ad orbitam paxilli perpendicula­
res) patet in majore circulo haberi majora momenta; multo
magis, &longs;i applicetur juxta maximam à motûs centro di&longs;tantiam;
id quod fieri expedit, &longs;i nihil ob&longs;it: At &longs;i Potentia à centro mo­
tûs æquè ab&longs;it in majore atque in minore circulo, non habetur
hoc momentorum compendium, quod ex di&longs;tantia facilè obti­
neri po&longs;&longs;et.

Si itaque corpus ex D in H impul&longs;um aut vi ela&longs;ticâ re&longs;ti­
tuere &longs;e po&longs;&longs;it ex H in D, aut illud &longs;ublevatum (&longs;i circulus
fuerit in plano Verticali) &longs;uâ gravitate de&longs;cendere valeat ex H
in D, paulatim in priorem locum redibit, cum potentia tran&longs;­
gre&longs;&longs;a punctum H per I &longs;e re&longs;tituet in B: potentia igitur perpe­
tuò in gyrum circumactâ, circulum &longs;imiliter ver&longs;ando, corpus
illud in motu reciprocando &longs;ervabit con&longs;tantiam.

Quod &longs;i vir­
tute ela&longs;ticâ præditum &longs;it corpus impul&longs;um ex D in H, illa pa­
riter, præter in&longs;itam corpori gravitatem, movendi difficulta­
tem augebit, quippe cui vis inferenda e&longs;t, quam deinde excu­
tere valeat.

Quare &longs;atius fuerit omnem virtutem ela&longs;ticam amo­
vere (&longs;i id quidem fieri po&longs;&longs;it) ut &longs;ola gravitatis re&longs;i&longs;tentia &longs;u­
peranda &longs;it.

Ut autem corpus ultro citróque remeare po&longs;&longs;it ex D in H, &
vici&longs;&longs;im ex H in D, regula &longs;tatuatur in Verticali plano erecta,
&longs;ed ver&longs;atilis circa axem, aut annulum alteri eju&longs;dem regulæ
extremitati infixum, & reliqua regulæ extremitas mobilis oc­
currat circulo in B: Tum funiculo longitudine diametrum BD
æquante connectatur regula cum pondere movendo; &longs;ic enim
fiet ut regulæ extremitas devenerit in L, quando pondus fue­
rit in H; atque propellendo regulam ex L in B, pondus ex H
trahetur in D, & perpetua vici&longs;&longs;itudine tum regula, tùm pon­
dus à circumacto cuneo impellentur: &longs;emper verò re&longs;i&longs;tentia
orietur ex ponderis modò impul&longs;i, modò attracti gravitate; re­
gula &longs;iquidem per &longs;e nihil ob&longs;i&longs;tit, &longs;ed quatenus cum pondere
trahendo conjungitur.

Verùm qua po&longs;itione collocandus &longs;it fu-
niculus circuli diametro BD re&longs;pondens, an &longs;upra, an infra cir­
culum BED, quid opus e&longs;t explicare?

&longs;atis enim cuique mani­
fe&longs;tum e&longs;t attendendum e&longs;&longs;e, qua ratione ip&longs;i circulo applicetur
potentia movens; nam &longs;i illum Potentia agitet paxillo in &longs;upe­
riori aut inferiori facie extremæ orbitæ infixo, patet funiculum
adver&longs;æ faciei re&longs;pondere, ne in illum paxillus incurrat.

Sin
autem potentia circulo non proximè adhæreat, nec illum tan­
gat, quia ex centro C exeunti axi additum e&longs;t manubrium cir­
culo parallelum, aut Vectis, aut circulus alius eidem parallelus,
liberum erit funiculum alterutri circuli faciei re&longs;pondentem
collocare, ex neutrâ &longs;cilicet parte impedimento e&longs;&longs;e pote&longs;t
potentiæ &longs;e in gyrum contorquenti.

Ne me verò carpendum puta, quòd integrum circulum
FBED propo&longs;uerim, cum &longs;atis e&longs;&longs;e po&longs;&longs;it &longs;egmentum paulo
majus &longs;emicirculo BED (ut &longs;cilicet &longs;it locus axi infigendo in C
motûs centro) cui tota vis impellendi &longs;ive pondus, &longs;ive regu­
lam, tribuenda e&longs;t.

Eo con&longs;ilio integrum circulum FBED
propo&longs;ui, ut liberum potentiæ &longs;it &longs;ive in dexteram, &longs;ive in &longs;i­
ni&longs;tram motum in&longs;tituere, atque promi&longs;cuè uti modò cuneo
inflexo BED, modò BFD, prout commodius acciderit.

Dein­
de &longs;i &longs;emicirculo tantùm BED utamur, & vis ela&longs;tica interve­
niat, aut gravitas &longs;ublevata recidat, ubi potentia venerit in H,
& &longs;emicirculi BED &longs;it facta po&longs;itio HML, fieri non pote&longs;t, ut
potentia versùs I procedat, quin illicò & qua&longs;i momento pon­
dus redeat ad D; huju&longs;modi verò motus adeò velox vix contin­
gere &longs;æpiùs pote&longs;t citra aliquod detrimentrum; cui periculo
occurritur, &longs;i integer fuerit circulus FBED, &longs;en&longs;im enim fit
regre&longs;&longs;us ex H in D.
CAPUT IV.
Ex Cylindro construi potest Cuneus perpetuus.

ALtera &longs;pecies Cunei perpetui de&longs;umi poterit ex Cylindro
Recto obliquè &longs;ecto, erit &longs;iquidem &longs;ectio Ellip&longs;is; & poti&longs;-
&longs;imùm in&longs;erviet ad deprimendum, &longs;i cylindrus fuerit horizon­
ti perpendicularis, atque addito vecte circumagatur Ergatæ in
morem: Sin autem cylindrus &longs;it horizonti parallelus, in&longs;erviet
ad propellendum pondus, & Radios admittet quemadmodum
Sucula.

Sit cylindrus BC Rectus,
cujus &longs;cilicet Axis e&longs;t ad ba&longs;im
perpendicularis, & obliquè &longs;ece­
tur plano per DC; fit enim &longs;ectio
DECF ellip&longs;is.

Quod &longs;i huju&longs;­
modi Ellip&longs;is planities officere po&longs;­
&longs;it motui, interiores partes aliquan­
tulùm excavari oportebit, quando­
quidem &longs;ufficit limbus perimetri,
modò &longs;it &longs;olidus, & &longs;atis validus;
quem & ferreâ laminâ non ruditer
politâ munire operæ pretium fue­
rit.

Ut autem huju&longs;modi &longs;ectionis obliquitas major aut minor
opportunè fiat, &longs;tatuenda e&longs;t primùm men&longs;ura depre&longs;&longs;ionis aut
impul&longs;ionis, qua movendum e&longs;t pondus, & &longs;it ex.

gr. CA, cui
æqualis &longs;umatur ID: tùm ex D in C fiat &longs;ectio, & erit con&longs;ti­
tutus cuneus ADFC, cujus latus unum e&longs;t cylindri &longs;emipe­
ripheria AD, aliud DFC &longs;emiperimeter Ellip&longs;is, cujus partes
ponderi in D con&longs;tituto &longs;ubinde applicantur ex convolutione
cylindri, & quatenus ab AD recedunt, pondus deprimunt, aut
impellunt, donec demum à puncto C attingatur pondus propul­
&longs;um ex D in I.

Quoniam verò Ellipticum limbum ferreâ laminâ muniendum
dixi, non omninò abs re fuerit indicare, qua methodo illius
perimetrum indagare po&longs;&longs;imus, ut laminæ in ellipticam figu­
ram inflectendæ longitudo innote&longs;cat.

In circulo quidem nota
e&longs;t aliqua Ratio diametri ad peripheriam, &longs;ive ut 7 ad 22, &longs;i­
ve ut 71 ad 223, &longs;ive ut 113 ad 355, &longs;ive quæcumque alia ma­
gis arrideat majoribus numeris explicata: at in Ellip&longs;i nulla hu­
ju&longs;modi Ratio perimetri ad alterutrum Axem (quod quidem
&longs;ciam) deprehen&longs;a adhuc e&longs;t: quapropter ad inve&longs;tigandam
ejus perimetrum ex datis Axibus variæ tentatæ &longs;unt viæ, quas
inire nunc non e&longs;t operæ pretium.

Mihi hanc, utpote perbre­
vem, nec à veritatis formâ, quantum res Phy&longs;ica patitur, re-
cedentem ineundam &longs;u&longs;cepi.

Illud verò tanquam certum &
demon&longs;tratum pono, quod Ellip&longs;is, quæ ex Coni &longs;ectione, ab
ea quæ ex Cylindri &longs;ectione oritur, non differt, ut quidam mi­
nùs attenti perperam exi&longs;timârunt; proinde quælibet oblata
Ellip&longs;is ad aliquem Cylindrum &longs;pectare pote&longs;t.

Ad quem au­
tem cylindrum illa pertineat, facile e&longs;t determinare ex ip&longs;ius
Ellip&longs;is Axe minori, qui e&longs;t æqualis diametro Cylindri.

Datis
igitur, Axibus, Majore, & Minore, invenire oportet, quan­
ta &longs;it in huju&longs;modi Cylindro obliquitas &longs;ectionis Ellip&longs;im
con&longs;tituens: id quod obtinetur, &longs;i ex quadrato Axis Majoris
auferatur quadratum Axis Minoris; re&longs;idui enim Radix qua­
drata dabit in Cylindri latere longitudinem, qua di&longs;tant inter
&longs;e duo plana ba&longs;i parallela, inter quæ intercipitur &longs;ectio
obliqua.

Sit data Ellip&longs;is DECF, cujus major Axis DC 25, Minor
FE 20. Axi FE æqualis e&longs;t cylindri diameter CI.

Igitur pla­
num per axem cylindri ductum habet cum plano obliquè &longs;e­
cante communem &longs;ectionem DC Axem Ellip&longs;is, & cum cy­
lindri ba&longs;e &longs;ectionem facit CI, atque in &longs;uperficie dat latus DI.

Quare e&longs;t triangulum rectangulum CID, cujus datur hypo­
thenu&longs;a DC 25, & ba&longs;is CI 20: ex ip&longs;ius DC quadrato 625
ablatum quadratum ex CI 400, relinquit 225, quadratum per­
pendiculi DI, quod propterea e&longs;t 15. Plana igitur CI, & AD
parallela di&longs;tant intervallo CI 15. Cum itaque ex ba&longs;is dia­
metro CI 20 innote&longs;cat eju&longs;dem cylindricæ ba&longs;is periphe­
ria (62 84/100) proximè, &longs;uperficies cylindrica ACID manife&longs;ta e&longs;t
(942 60/100), cujus &longs;emi&longs;&longs;em (471 30/100) dividit bifariam &longs;emiperimeter
Ellip&longs;is DEC.

E&longs;t igitur triangulum rectangulum, cujus late­
ra circa rectum &longs;unt latus DI 15, & cylindricæ ba&longs;is &longs;emiperi­
pheria CHI (31 42/100): horum quadrata 225, & (987 2164/10000) in &longs;um­
mam colligantur, & quadrati (1212 2164/10000) Radix (34 82/100) ferè, e&longs;t
Ellip&longs;is &longs;emiperimeter DEC, integra verò DECF erit (69 64/100).

Quapropter cum plana per AD & CI ex hypothe&longs;i &longs;int pa­
rallela, etiam DI, & AC æqualia &longs;unt latera.

Igitur cum cy­
lindri dati nota &longs;it diameter 20, atque adeò &longs;emiperipheria
AD (31 42/100), &longs;it data obliquitas, quam metitur AC 15, ex &longs;um­
mâ quadratorum rectæ AC, & &longs;emiperipheriæ AD, cruatur
Radix quadrata, & dabit &longs;emiperimetrum Ellip&longs;is DFC proxt­
mam veræ, quæ ex jam datis e&longs;t illa eadem, quam paulo antè
invenimus (34 82/100).

Hinc igitur innote&longs;cunt momenta huju&longs;modi cunei, com­
paratis inter &longs;e lineis, quæ definiunt motum ponderis atque
potentiæ; pondus enim movetur juxta lineam AC, potentia
autem juxta &longs;emiperipheriam cylindri, quatenus videlicet præ­
cisè atque &longs;impliciter ratione ip&longs;ius cunei motus illi convenit.

Verùm quia non facilè potentia applicatur proximè &longs;uperficiei
cylindri, & &longs;æpius expedit potentiæ momenta augere; propterea
Cylindro infigitur Vectis MN, cujus longitudo de&longs;umitur à
puncto, ubi ille concurrit cum Axe Cylindri, u&longs;que ad extre­
mitatem N, cui potentia applicatur.

Hæc autem longitudo,
manente eodem cuneo, varia omnino e&longs;&longs;e pote&longs;t, atque adeò
potentiæ momenta repræ&longs;entabit &longs;emiperipheria circuli ab ex­
tremitate N de&longs;cripti, quæ comparanda erit cum motu ip&longs;ius
ponderis ab obliquitate &longs;ectionis definito, ut dictum e&longs;t.

At &longs;ubdubitare contingit, utrùm cra&longs;&longs;iore, an graciliore cy­
lindro uti expediat, manente eâdem obliquitatis men&longs;urâ, at­
que eâdem vectis longitudine; manet &longs;iquidem eadem mo­
tuum Ratio; &longs;ed augeri videtur corporum conflictus ex mutuo
tritu, nam in cra&longs;&longs;iore cylindro major e&longs;t elliptica &longs;emiperime­
ter, quàm in tenuiore, ut manife&longs;tum e&longs;t, &longs;i methodo paulò
antè indicatâ res ad calculos revocetur: quamobrem ex majore
hoc tritu augeri videtur difficultas movendi, cum maneat ea­
dem corporis gravitas, eadem potentiæ virtus, eadem motuum
Ratio.

Longè tamen aliter &longs;e res habet; quandoquidem duo­
rum corporum &longs;e &longs;e invicem in motu contingentium conflictus,
qui ex &longs;uperficiei a&longs;peritate oritur (hìc corporis unius conatum
adversùs aliud vi &longs;uæ gravitatis mente &longs;ecernimus à conatu,
quo illud repellit præcisè vi &longs;uæ molis tanquam objectum im­
pedimentum, etiam&longs;i adversùs illud non gravitet) con&longs;ide­
randus e&longs;t, quatenus corpus impul&longs;um adver&longs;atur directioni
motûs corporis impellentis.

Hinc e&longs;t minimum e&longs;&longs;e conflictum,
&longs;i ambæ facies &longs;e in plano Verticali contingant, & alterutrum
corpus in eodem plano Verticali moveatur; nam reliquum cor­
pus non repellitur, quia in illud non incurrit linea directionis
motûs alterius corporis, &longs;ed &longs;olùm prominulæ utriu&longs;que corpo-
ris particulæ, quatenus aliæ in alias incurrunt, impediunt mo­
tum pro earum magnitudine & numero: quoad impedimentum
maximâ ex parte tollitur, &longs;i pingui aliquo humore delibutæ fa­
cies lubricæ fiant; replentur &longs;cilicet inanitates inter prominulas
particulas interjectæ, quas intercapedines &longs;ubire non tam faci­
lè po&longs;&longs;unt corporis proximi particulæ.

Sic &longs;i integer e&longs;&longs;et cylin­
drus, &longs;uâ ba&longs;i aut limbo CHI contingens &longs;ubjectum corpus,
minimo tritu cum illo confligeret in motu circà &longs;uum Axem,
quia huju&longs;modi motui non opponitur corpus illud in I po&longs;itum.

At verò major e&longs;t conflictus, quando directioni motûs illud ad­
ver&longs;atur, ut cùm prope D e&longs;&longs;e intelligitur aliquâ &longs;ui parte &longs;ub­
jectum cylindro, qui obliquè &longs;ectus circumagi non pote&longs;t, quin
urgeat illud ex D versùs I.

Quò autem majore angulo planum
Ellipticum CEDF inclinatur ad ba&longs;is planum CHI, eò magis
conver&longs;ioni cylindri adver&longs;atur objectum corpus, adeóque ma­
jor invenitur difficultas.

Cùm itaque in majore cylindro, datâ æquali obliquitatis
men&longs;urâ AC (æqualem obliquitatem non dico) planum obli­
què &longs;ecans minorem angulum cum plano ba&longs;is cylindri con&longs;ti­
tuat, magi&longs;que ad ip&longs;am ba&longs;im accedat, minus habet re&longs;i&longs;ten­
tiæ ab objecto corpore, &longs;i particulæ &longs;ingulæ con&longs;iderentur,
quamvis cunctæ re&longs;i&longs;tentiæ &longs;imul collectæ demùm in æqualem
&longs;ummam à men&longs;ura AC definitam coëant.

Sit enim minoris cy­
lindri &longs;emiperipheria RS, men­
&longs;ura obliquitatis RO, &longs;emiperi­
meter Ellip&longs;is SO: Manente au­
tem eâdem RO, &longs;it majoris cy­
lindri &longs;emiperipheria RT, & el­
lip&longs;is &longs;emiperimeter TO; utique
angulus RSO, utpote externus,
major e&longs;t interno oppo&longs;ito RTO; ac proinde alternus SOX
major e&longs;t alterno TOX, quibus angulis repræ&longs;entatur plani
obliquè &longs;ecantis inclinatio ad ba&longs;im cylindri.

Quamvis igitur
ex cylindri convolutione &longs;emiperimeter Ellip&longs;is SO impellat
pondus juxta men&longs;uram RO, & juxta eandem men&longs;uram RO
impellatur pondus à &longs;emiperimetro Ellip&longs;is TO; item ab illius
quadrante SP, atque hujus quadrante TQ, æqualiter impella­
tur juxta men&longs;uram MP, & NQ, quæ æquales &longs;unt (utraque
&longs;cilicet e&longs;t quadrans ip&longs;ius RO, &longs;iquidem propter triangulo­
rum &longs;imilitudinem, ut OS ad PS, ita RO ad MP, & ut OT
ad QT, ita RO ad NQ; &longs;ed ex hypothe&longs;i OS e&longs;t quadrupla
ip&longs;ius PS, &longs;icut OT e&longs;t quadrupla ip&longs;ius QT; igitur RO e&longs;t
quadrupla ip&longs;ius MP, & ip&longs;ius NQ, quæ propterea &longs;unt æqua­
les) quia tamen QT major e&longs;t quàm PS, qua Ratione RT ma­
jor e&longs;t quàm RS, & OT major quàm OS; idcircò eadem re­
&longs;i&longs;tentia di&longs;tributa per plures particulas longioris QT, &longs;eu OT,
minor e&longs;t in &longs;ingulis particulis, quàm cùm di&longs;tribuitur per pau­
ciores particulas brevioris PS, &longs;eu OS.

Minùs igitur TO &longs;uis
particulis &longs;ubinde contingens corpus, quod impellit, cum eo
confligit, quàm confligat SO pertinens ad minorem cy­
lindrum.

Huju&longs;modi Cuneum inflexum ex cylindro obliquè &longs;ecto per­
petuum e&longs;&longs;e in reciprocando motu, &longs;atis
manife&longs;tum e&longs;t, &longs;i po&longs;tquam pondus ex
D propul&longs;um e&longs;t in I, iterum redeat ad
D; ab&longs;olutâ enim cylindri conver&longs;ione
iterum pondus ex D ad I propellitur.

Id
autem ut fiat, &longs;tatuatur jugum KL cir­
ca axem in V ver&longs;atile, ita tamen ut V
re&longs;pondeat axi cylindri: tùm in L ad­
nectatur pondus, quod ex D impelletur
in I, dum Cylindri dimidia revolutio ex
D per F in C perficietur: quia autem in reliquâ dimidiâ cylin­
dri revolutione jugi extremitas K jam repul&longs;a &longs;ur&longs;um versùs A,
impelletur iterum ad C, pondus re&longs;tituetur ex I in D, atque ita
deinceps reciprocando impul&longs;ionem tum ponderis adnexi in L,
tùm extremitatis K.

Hinc &longs;i ex laqueari pendeat &longs;tatua ventum
referens, & in &longs;peciem volantis ingentes das expandens junctas
jugo KL, atque in &longs;uperiore conclavi ad&longs;it qui cylindrum cir­
cumagat, alis reciprocantibus commovebitur aër, & aura exci­
tabitur ad refrigerandum.

Pro variis demum u&longs;ibus &longs;tatuetur cylindrus modò horizon­
ti, tanquam Ergata, perpendicularis, modò velut Sucula, paral­
lelus: Erítque expediti&longs;&longs;ima ejus conver&longs;io, &longs;i centrum Ellip&longs;is
nulli polo innitatur, &longs;ed cylindrus ip&longs;e congruo loculamento
ita in&longs;eratur, ut in eo &longs;it ver&longs;atilis, &, quam primò dederis, po-
&longs;itionem deinceps &longs;ervet, ac neutram in partem nutet. Id qui­
dem paulò longiorem cylindrum exigit; non tamen e&longs;t nece&longs;­
&longs;e unius perpetuæ cra&longs;&longs;itiei e&longs;&longs;e cylindrum; &longs;æpè enim nimis
cra&longs;&longs;um atque incommodum e&longs;&longs;e contingeret; &longs;ed fru&longs;to cy­
lindrico cra&longs;&longs;iori obliquè &longs;ecto firmiter in&longs;eri poterit gracilior
cylindrus, ita ut axis axi conveniat, & rectam lineam con&longs;ti­
tuant, atque hic in foramen immi&longs;&longs;us, in quo ver&longs;atilis e&longs;t, dum
contorquetur, cra&longs;&longs;iorem cylindrum pariter convolvit.
CAPUT V.
Cuneum perpetuum Circulus inclinatus imitatur.

TErtiam hanc cunei perpetui &longs;peciem duabus &longs;uperioribus
adjicere non inutile fuerit, ut legenti hujus libri cap.
ult.

prop.
6. con&longs;tabit, quanquam forta&longs;&longs;is alicui à &longs;uperiore parùm
di&longs;tare videatur; ibi enim Ellip&longs;im ex cylindri recti &longs;ectione
obliquâ, hìc circulum &longs;uo quidem centro in&longs;i&longs;tentem, &longs;ed in­
clinatum proponimus.

Ut autem res
clariùs exponatur, concipiamus circu­
lum à plano horizontali RS &longs;ectum
per centrum A, ita ut eorum commu­
nis &longs;ectio &longs;it diameter BC, &longs;emicircu­
lus autem &longs;uperior ad horizontem in­
clinatus &longs;it BDC; qui per AD bifa­
riam &longs;ecetur plano Verticali ad &longs;ub­
jectum planum RS horizontale recto;
sítque horum planorum communis
&longs;ectio recta AE.

Tum ex D Quadran­
tis extremitate demittatur per 11.lib.11. perpendicularis ad &longs;ub­
jectum planum recta DE; quæ propterea ex defin.

3. lib.11. fa­
cit cum rectà AE angulum rectum.

Accipiatur arcus DF, &
per F in circuli plano ductâ FG parallelâ ip&longs;i AD, per eam
ductum intelligatur planum parallelum plano tran&longs;eunti per
AD: Igitur planum horizontale plana illa parallela &longs;ecans, per
16. lib.
11. facit &longs;ectiones AE & GH parallelas, ac proinde,
cum duæ rectæ AD & AE duabus rectis GF & GH &longs;int pa-
rallelæ, etiam per 10. lib.
11 anguli DAE, & FGH (cum illæ
&longs;int &longs;imiliter po&longs;itæ) &longs;unt æquales.

Jam ex F demittatur in &longs;ub­
jectum planum perpendicularis FH, quæ cum rectâ GH
con&longs;tituit angulum rectum.

Cum itaque duo triangula AED
& GHF rectangula habeant angulum DAE angulo FGH
æqualem, & reliquus reliquo æqualis e&longs;t, atque &longs;imilia &longs;unt
triangula: Quapropter ut AD ad DE, ita GF ad FH, & per­
mutando ut AD ad GF, ita DE ad FH.

Eadem erit ratioci­
natio in triangulo KLI &longs;imiliter facto, quod erit reliquis &longs;imi­
le, & ut AD ad KI, ita DE ad IL: atque ita deinceps de cæ­
teris omnibus triangulis, quæ efformari po&longs;&longs;unt à lineis paral­
lelis Radio AD, tanquam hypothenu&longs;is, & à perpendiculari­
bus cadentibus in &longs;ubjectum planum ex peripheriâ circuli in­
clinati, & à rectis, quæ jungunt punctum, in quod cadit per­
pendiculum, cum extremitate altera hypothenu&longs;æ.

Quoniam
verò omnes lineæ parallelæ Radio AD &longs;unt Sinus arcuum à
puncto C incipientium (&longs;ic IK e&longs;t Sinus arcûs IC, FG e&longs;t Si­
nus arcûs FC) omnium illarum Ratio manife&longs;ta e&longs;t ex Canone
Sinuum, &longs;i arcuum quantitas in gradibus data &longs;it, vel nota;
quare etiam nota e&longs;t Ratio perpendiculorum DE, FH, IL.

Hæc autem, quæ de Quadrante DAC dicta &longs;unt, etiam de
reliquo Quadrante DAB intelliguntur; & quæ de hoc &longs;upe­
riore &longs;emicirculo demon&longs;trata &longs;unt, etiam de inferiore &longs;emicir­
culo vera &longs;unt, quatenus ille ad hoc idem planum horizontale
RS refertur, à quo circulus bifariam &longs;ecatur.

Jam verò integer circulus cum alio plano horizontali non
Secante, &longs;ed Tangente circulum inclinatum in puncto infimo,
comparetur: &longs;unt autem duo hæc plana horizontalia invicem
parallela; & perpendiculum à puncto D cadens in planum ho­
rizontale Tangens, e&longs;t duplum perpendiculi DE, quemadmo­
dum totius circuli diameter e&longs;t dupla Radij AD.

Quapropter
cum nota &longs;it dati circuli diameter &longs;ecundùm certam men&longs;uram,
& data &longs;it circuli inclinatio, &longs;ive perpendiculi longitudo, qui
e&longs;t Sinus anguli inclinationis, facile e&longs;t invenire &longs;ingularum
perpendicularium quantitatem.

Nam &longs;i datur angulus inclina­
tionis circuli ad planum Tangens (cùm hoc &longs;it parallelum pla­
no Secanti) angulus ille æqualis e&longs;t angulo DAE: quare &longs;icut
