in triangulo DAE rectangulo datur hypothenu&longs;a AD Radius
circuli, & angulus acutus adjacens DAE, ex quibus inveni­
tur latus DE, ita manife&longs;tum fit perpendiculum à &longs;ummo cir­
culi inclinati puncto D in planum horizontale Tangens, quod
e&longs;t duplum lateris DE inventi.

Sivè igitur detur puncti D à plano horizontali Tangente
di&longs;tantia, &longs;ivè inveniatur, di&longs;tantia hæc bipartitò dividatur,
ejú&longs;que medietas tribuatur perpendiculari DE.

Tum Qua­
drans DC in quotlibet partes æquales divi&longs;us intelligatur, puta
in decem, & ex Canone accipiantur &longs;ingulorum arcuum Sinus
gr. 81.72. 63.54. 45.36.27.18.9: deinde fiat ut Radius ad &longs;ingu­
los Sinus, ita notum perpendiculum DE ad aliud, & proveniet
&longs;ingulorum perpendiculorum in planum Secans cadentium
men&longs;ura: quibus &longs;ingillatim addenda e&longs;t quantitas ip&longs;ius DE,
hoc e&longs;t dimidia altitudo &longs;umma, ut habeatur &longs;ingulorum alti­
tudo &longs;uprà planum horizontale Tangens.

Ponatur &longs;umma cir­
culi elevatio à po&longs;itione horizontali, palmi unius: igitur DE
e&longs;t &longs;emipalmus, qui intelligatur di&longs;tinctus in particulas 100.000,
adeóque totus palmus in part.

200.000. Ideò in &longs;uperiori
Quadrante &longs;ingulis perpendiculis addito &longs;emipalmo perpen­
diculorum altitudo ea e&longs;t, quam adjecta tabella exhibet.
TABELLE WAR HIER

Pro inferiori autem Quadrante ponendo gr. 90. in puncto con­
tactûs circuli cum plano Tangente, lineæ perpendiculares ad
planum Secans auferendæ &longs;unt à &longs;emi&longs;&longs;e datæ elevationis, hoc
e&longs;t ex &longs;emipalmo part.

100000, & re&longs;iduum e&longs;t di&longs;tantia per­
pendicularis à &longs;ubjecto plano Tangente &longs;ingulis partium
punctis re&longs;pondens; quemadmodum adjectæ tabellæ pars alte­
ra o&longs;tendit.

His fundamentis po&longs;itis innititur &longs;pecies hæc cunei petita ex
circulo inclinato, qui eandem &longs;ervans inclinationem circa
&longs;uum centrum convertitur.

Sit enim circu­
lus BFED, cujus centrum C, ad horizon­
tem, &longs;ive ad planum Verticale inclinatus, &
&longs;it in D pondus impellendum.

Potentia in B
exi&longs;tens, circulumque retinens in eâdem in­
clinatione, &longs;i illum circa &longs;uum centrum C
circumagat, paulatim pondus impellit, prout
illud tangitur modò à puncto E, modò à
puncto F, donec demum à puncto B infimo
ad extremum motûs terminum deducatur.

Quare potentiæ
motus definitur à &longs;emicirculi peripheriâ BFED, motus verò
ponderis à rectâ DH.

Ut autem circulus in conver&longs;ione eandem &longs;emper inclinatio­
nem &longs;ervet, fru&longs;tum ligni G obliquè in parte &longs;uperiori &longs;ectum,
inferiùs affigatur circulo (aut contrà in parte inferiori &longs;ectum
&longs;uperiùs affigatur, prout commodius acciderit) atque in ligno
foramen fiat re&longs;pondens circuli centro C, per quod foramen
tran&longs;eat polus, cui centrum in&longs;i&longs;tit.

Cum enim foramen illud
perpendiculare maneat ad horizontem, circulus eandem reti­
net in conver&longs;ione inclinationem.

Verùm quia priùs &longs;tatuendum e&longs;t &longs;patium DH, per quod
ponderi commeandum e&longs;t, quàm circuli amplitudo definiatur,
non &longs;olùm ut Potentiæ motus ad ponderis motum Rationem
habeat majorem pro circuli &longs;emiperipheriæ longitudine, &longs;ed
etiam ut quàm minimum fieri po&longs;&longs;it, inclinatio ip&longs;a recedat à
paralleli&longs;mo cum plano, ad quod inclinari dicitur, &longs;ive illud
horizontale &longs;it, &longs;ive Verticale, quò enim minùs directioni mo­
tûs potentiæ opponitur pondus, eò minùs re&longs;i&longs;tit: Propterea
data linea DH &longs;tatuatur ut Sinus anguli inclinationis, & Ra­
dio re&longs;pondebit diameter circuli opportuni.

Sic &longs;i recta DH &longs;it
linea palmaris, & angulus inclinationis ponatur gr. 10: fiat ut
gr.10 Sinus 17365 ad Radium 100000, ita 1 palmus ad pal­
mos (5 76/100) ferè, quæ e&longs;&longs;et diameter circuli eam inclinationem
habentis; atque adeò motus potentiæ cum circulo in gyrum
actæ e&longs;&longs;et ad motum ponderis &longs;altem noncuplus.

Ex quibus &longs;a­
tis apertum e&longs;t ampliorem circulum præ minore utiliorem e&longs;&longs;e,
cæteris paribus.

At circulum ip&longs;um convolvere aut non placet, aut non licet,
quia forta&longs;&longs;e pondus illius peripheriæ adnexum e&longs;t, atque id­
circò non ni&longs;i in gyrum pariter cum circulo ageretur.

Idem
planè a&longs;&longs;equemur, &longs;i circulum horizonti, aut plano Verticali,
con&longs;titutum parallelum potentia urgeat in B; tùm puncto D
applicetur pondus; deinde potentia pergens in F & E percurrat
circuli ambitum illum deprimendo & inclinando; quandoqui­
dem utroque modo mutatur di&longs;tantia ponderis ab infimo
puncto circuli.

Ponatur enim punctum F æquè di&longs;tans à puncto
B, atque punctum E di&longs;tat à puncto D.

Si potentia manens ap­
plicata eidem puncto B convertat circulum ita, ut ip&longs;a poten­
tia di&longs;tet à pondere arcu BE, pondus non adnexum circulo
impellitur pro Ratione, quam arcus ille exigit: at verò &longs;i ma­
nente pondere applicato ad punctum D, cui adnectitur, poten­
tia pergat ex B in F, &longs;imiliter di&longs;tat à pondere arcu FD, qui
e&longs;t æqualis arcui BE; atque proinde æqualiter deprimitur, pro­
ut idem arcus exigit, juxta &longs;uperius explicata, & in tabellâ ex­
po&longs;ita; atque ita deinceps, donec potentia veniat in D: &longs;ingulas
autem impul&longs;iones metitur differentia perpendicularium.

Hìc igitur ubi pondus circulo adnexum ponitur, manife&longs;ta
e&longs;t motûs reciprocatio: potentia &longs;iquidem ubi per F & E vene­
rit in circuli punctum D, & impulerit pondus u&longs;que in H,
percurrendo reliquum &longs;emicirculum DIB iterum retrahit pon­
dus ex H in D.

At quando pondus non connectitur cum circu­
lo, & circulus ip&longs;e convertitur, tunc opus e&longs;t aliquo artificio,
ut pondus ex H remeet in D, quemadmodum indicatum e&longs;t
capite &longs;uperiori.

Porrò circulus i&longs;te non convolutus, &longs;ed à potentiâ ejus am­
bitum percurrente &longs;ecundùm alias atque alias partes inclinatus,
non e&longs;t à Ratione Cunei excludendus; quandoquidem parùm
intere&longs;t utrùm &longs;imili motu potentia atque organum moveantur,
an verò di&longs;&longs;imili motu.

Quando potentia in eodem puncto B
&longs;emper applicata in gyrum pergit, &longs;imili motu cum circulo in
gyrum acto movetur: quando verò potentia quidem circulari­
ter movetur, &longs;ed non &longs;ecum rapit circulum, quem &longs;olummodò
inclinat, e&longs;t quidem diver&longs;us potentiæ motus à motu organi,
&longs;ed ponderis motus idem planè efficitur in utroque ca&longs;u, &
æqualis e&longs;t potentiæ ip&longs;ius motus determinatus à Rationibus
Cunei, quamvis hic non promoveatur, &longs;ed &longs;olùm impellatur.
CAPUT VI.
Vnde oriatur vis Percu&longs;sionis.

CUnei vires, quatenus ex ejus formâ proveniunt, hactenus
con&longs;ideravimus; nunc ad id, quod poti&longs;&longs;imum in hac
tractatione videtur, tran&longs;eundum e&longs;t, videlicet ad percu&longs;&longs;io­
nem, qua dum adigitur Cuneus, multo faciliùs con&longs;equitur mo­
tus (&longs;ive &longs;ci&longs;&longs;io &longs;it, &longs;ive &longs;implex impul&longs;io, citrà corporis divi&longs;io­
nem) quàm &longs;i onere impo&longs;ito prægravaretur, aut Vecte &longs;eu aliâ
qualibet Facultate augerentur Potentiæ momenta.

Certè
Ari&longs;toteles Mechan. quæ&longs;t.

19. quærit, Cur &longs;i quis &longs;uper lignum
magnam imponat &longs;ecurim, de&longs;upérque illi magnum adjiciat pondus,
ligni quippiam, quod curandum &longs;it, non dividit: Si verò &longs;ecurim ex­
tollens percutiat, illud &longs;cindit; cum alioquin multo minus habeas
ponderis id, quod percutit, quàm id quod &longs;uperjacet, & premit? Id
quod in cæteris quoquè percu&longs;&longs;ionibus, ubi nulla intervenit
Cunei Ratio, manife&longs;tum e&longs;t; quemadmodum in &longs;implici com­
pre&longs;&longs;ione, ut cùm lamella aurea in &longs;ubtili&longs;&longs;imam bracteolam di­
ducitur repetitâ mallei percu&longs;&longs;ione; quod enim, licèt immen­
&longs;um, pondus vi &longs;uæ gravitatis tantumdem præ&longs;tare po&longs;&longs;et?

Per­
cu&longs;&longs;ionis igitur natura inve&longs;tiganda e&longs;t, ut ejus vires in Cuneo
innote&longs;cant.

Certum autem e&longs;&longs;e debet, & extra omnem controver&longs;iam
po&longs;itum nihil e&longs;&longs;e in hac rerum univer&longs;itate, quod vacet cor­
pore, &longs;ed corporibus omnem ob&longs;ideri locum, nullúmque e&longs;&longs;e
inane, in quod &longs;e recipere valeant, ac propterea corpora om-
nia ita &longs;ibi vici&longs;&longs;im &longs;uâ mole ob&longs;i&longs;tere, ut nullum moveri va­
leat, quin alterius in locum &longs;uccedat; quod proinde loco pelli
nece&longs;&longs;e e&longs;t, quantum &longs;atis fuerit, ut &longs;ubeunti corpori &longs;patium
concedat; &longs;ive id contingat, quia ob&longs;i&longs;tens corpus inter an­
gu&longs;tias deprehen&longs;um &longs;e comprimi patiatur, &longs;ivè quia divi&longs;um
in latera &longs;ecedat, &longs;ive quia circumfu&longs;a corpora circumpellat,
quæ abeuntis ve&longs;tigia &longs;equantur.

Cum itaque nec omnia pla­
nè corpora perpetuò quie&longs;cant, nec omnia æquali pror&longs;us agi­
tatione commoveantur, fieri non pote&longs;t, quin aliquibus vis
aliqua &longs;altem aliquando inferatur, &longs;eu quia non licet diu juxta
naturæ in&longs;titutum quieta con&longs;i&longs;tere, &longs;eu quia externo pul&longs;u ad
velociorem motum incitantur.

Quare nullius corporis ex loco
in locum migratio excogitari pote&longs;t, cui nullum aliud corpus
adver&longs;etur & repugnet, vel ut &longs;uo &longs;e tutetur in loco juxta præ­
&longs;criptum à natura ordinem, vel ut partium nexum, & natura­
lem earum po&longs;itionem &longs;ervet citrà divi&longs;ionem, aut compre&longs;&longs;io­
nem, aut di&longs;tractionem.

Ex quo & illud con&longs;equens e&longs;t, quod
nullum reip&longs;a (quicquid animo finxeris) quie&longs;cit corpus ad
omnem omninò motum adeò indifferens, ut nihil pror&longs;us re­
tundat impetûs ab alio corpore commoto &longs;ponte concepti, aut
extrin&longs;ecùs impre&longs;&longs;i: nullum quippe e&longs;t, quod neque quicquam
habeat proni, neque &longs;ur&longs;um &longs;ubvolare contendat, &longs;i di&longs;paris &longs;e­
cundùm &longs;peciem gravitatis corpori permeabili proximum
con&longs;i&longs;tat, ubi fortè ordinem perturbari contigerit: ac propterea
ad motum indifferens cen&longs;endum non e&longs;t, ni&longs;i ut exqui&longs;itam
circuli peripheriam circa centrum gravium percurrat externâ
vi impellente: id quod animo fingere facile e&longs;t, opere exequi,
ut miti&longs;&longs;imè loquar, difficillimum; certè &longs;emper incertum.

Hoc verò di&longs;crimen e&longs;t inter corpora (quantum quidem ad
præ&longs;entem di&longs;putationem attinet) quod aliqua ita liberè fluunt,
ut nu&longs;quam adhære&longs;cere videantur, quemadmodum aër, & ex­
tenuatus vapor: Alia liquida & fu&longs;a manant, atque labuntur,
ut aqua cæteríque humores, per quos tran&longs;ire & permeare li­
cet, dirempti enim iterùm coëunt.

Alia partibus con&longs;tant, quæ
junctione aliquâ tenentur, & &longs;ub certâ quidem conformatione,
atque figurâ con&longs;i&longs;tunt, quandiu nullo impellente urgentur;
quia tamen facilè comprimi queunt, in aliam figuram transfe­
runtur; cuju&longs;modi &longs;unt lutum, cera, & reliqua mollia ac tene-
ra, quæ aut ita tractabilia &longs;unt, ut quamcumque in formam
fingantur, aut ita flexibilia, ut &longs;equantur quocumque tor­
queas: Alia demum &longs;olida & dura &longs;unt, quæ figuræ terminos,
quibus circum&longs;cribuntur, non facilè mutant, & &longs;i fortè &longs;e ali­
quatenus comprimi patiantur, pri&longs;tinam formam &longs;ibi reparant:
Ex hi&longs;ce quatuor corporum generibus priora rationem medij
&longs;ubire po&longs;&longs;unt, in quo reliquorum corporum motus exercean­
tur, ut ex alio in alium locum commigrent; po&longs;teriora, &longs;i unum
in aliud incurrat, aut &longs;i &longs;ibi invicem occurrant, ea &longs;unt, per
quæ tran&longs;itus non pateat, &longs;ed aliorum corporum motui tanti&longs;­
per mole &longs;uâ unumquodque obluctatur, dum pul&longs;u externo re­
moveatur.

Porrò Impul&longs;ionem à Percu&longs;&longs;ione di&longs;tinguere opus e&longs;t, ni&longs;i
vocabulis abuti velimus; quamvis enim utraque objecti corpo­
ris re&longs;i&longs;tentiam inveniat, nemo tamen dixerit idem e&longs;&longs;e, ap­
prehen&longs;um manu Vectem impellendo, atque illum percutien­
do deprimere, innatans aquæ lignum conto propellere, atque
inflicto ictu illud à ripâ longiùs ab&longs;trahere, etiam&longs;i æquè &
Vectis deprimatur, & lignum promoveatur.

Simplex nimi­
rum Impul&longs;io nullum per &longs;e antecedentem corporis impellentis
motum exigit: at Percu&longs;&longs;io ob idip&longs;um, quia Percu&longs;&longs;io e&longs;t, cor­
poris percutientis motum requirit, qui ip&longs;orum corporum col­
li&longs;ionem præcedat.

Quare in Percu&longs;&longs;ione intervenit in&longs;tituti
jam & inchoati motûs interruptio ex novâ objecti corporis re­
&longs;i&longs;tentiâ.

Hinc Ari&longs;toteles lib.
4. Meteor. &longs;umma 3. cap.
2. ait,
E&longs;t autem Pul&longs;io, motus à movente, qui fit à tactu; Percu&longs;&longs;io autem;
cum à latione.

Hæc omnia conjunctim Percu&longs;&longs;io po&longs;tulat: Primò inchoa­
tum e&longs;&longs;e jam & in&longs;titutum motum oportet: quamvis etenim
impul&longs;io omnis vincat corporis urgendi aut &longs;cindendi re&longs;i&longs;ten­
tiam etiam primo motûs momento; quia tamen præcedens cor­
poris impellentis motus, quo antè acce&longs;&longs;it ad corporis impul&longs;i
contactum, quàm illud urgere incipiat, omnino præter Impul­
&longs;ionis naturam accidit (hæc &longs;i quidem eadem &longs;equetur, etiam
&longs;i priùs in mutuo contactu diuti&longs;&longs;imè quie&longs;cant) propterea non
&longs;atis e&longs;t re&longs;i&longs;tentiam invenire, &longs;ed hanc in&longs;tituto jam motui in­
tervenire nece&longs;&longs;e e&longs;t, ut &longs;it Percu&longs;&longs;io.

Deinde, licèt præce&longs;&longs;e­
rit motus, atque adhuc continuatus novam inveniat re&longs;i&longs;ten-
tiam, quia alias medij eju&longs;dem &longs;cindendi partes offendit; &longs;i ta­
men æquabilis per&longs;everet pri&longs;tinam velocitatem aut tarditatem
nulla ex parte imminutam continenter &longs;ervans, non e&longs;t cen&longs;en­
da nova re&longs;i&longs;tentia; &longs;ed quemadmodum continuus e&longs;t idem
motus aliis atque aliis partibus &longs;ibi &longs;uccedentibus, ita conti­
nuatur eadem re&longs;i&longs;tentia, nec po&longs;teriores medij partes percuti
dicuntur, &longs;ed, ut priùs, præcisè impelli, aut &longs;cindi: quia vide­
licet præcedens motus nihil confert ad novam hanc impul&longs;io­
nem prioribus omnino &longs;imilem.

Quod &longs;i corpus in motu ob id­
ip&longs;um quia movetur, majorem atque majorem adhiberet cele­
ritatem, adeò ut in medio, hoc e&longs;t aëre ip&longs;o, re&longs;i&longs;tentiæ mo­
dus augeretur, facilè acquie&longs;cam contendenti aërem verberari
& percuti: &longs;ed quia nimis facilem &longs;e præbet aër ad hoc, ut
&longs;cindatur, non de huju&longs;modi percu&longs;&longs;ione medij, in quo fit mo­
tus, mihi hìc e&longs;t &longs;ermo, &longs;ed potiùs de percu&longs;&longs;ione corporis, ad
quod per medium accedit corpus percutiens.

Hinc aquam per­
cuti non negaverim, quando en&longs;is bonitatem examinaturi,
utrùm &longs;cilicet ritè & æquabiliter in chalybem temperatum &longs;it
ferrum, horizontalem aquæ &longs;tagnantis &longs;uperficiem plano gla­
dio vehementer percutimus; per aërem &longs;cilicet, tanquam per
medium antecedentis motûs, ad aquam devenit gladius; quic­
quid &longs;it, quod & ip&longs;a aqua ad ulteriorem motum, quo en&longs;is
profundiùs immergatur, medij rationem habere po&longs;&longs;it.

Simi­
liter aërem ip&longs;um percuti à corpore, quod ex aquâ emergit,
haud ægrè conce&longs;&longs;erim, &longs;i id quidem ex vi præcedentis motûs
contingat: e&longs;to, minùs ob&longs;i&longs;tat aër, quàm aqua, ob&longs;i&longs;tit tamen,
&longs;i à quiete dimoveatur, aut velociùs moveri cogatur, quàm mo­
veretur, &longs;i huju&longs;modi nova impul&longs;io vi præcedentis motûs non
accideret: Neque aër, cum primùm emergens corpus in eum
incurrit, habet rationem medij, &longs;ed perinde &longs;e habet primo il­
lo momento, atque &longs;i tabella &longs;u&longs;pen&longs;a horizonti parallela fa­
ciem aquæ proximè contingeret, & in eam ex aqua emergens
corpus incurreret; quanquam ab hac majorem, quàm ab aere,
re&longs;i&longs;tentiam &longs;ubiret, atque adeo validiorem huic ictum infli­
geret.
Sed quid vocabula in quæ&longs;tionem fru&longs;tra vocamus?

De his
loquere, ut libet: per me &longs;anè licebit, quando corpus ab uno
fluido, per quod inchoatus e&longs;t motus, ad aliud fluidum tran&longs;it
(&longs;ive hoc magis, &longs;ive minùs cra&longs;&longs;um atque concretum fuerit)
hujus po&longs;terioris fluidi primum contactum cum impul&longs;ione
Percu&longs;&longs;ionem æquè appellare, atque &longs;i non fluidum e&longs;&longs;et, &longs;ed
durum; validiùs &longs;cilicet impetitur vi antecedentis motûs, quàm
&longs;i corpus incurrens tunc primùm à quiete recederet.

Hìc &longs;oli­
dorum atque con&longs;i&longs;tentium corporum percu&longs;&longs;iones per&longs;equi­
mur, quarum vim inquirimus, & modum recipiunt à re&longs;i&longs;ten­
tiâ corporis percu&longs;&longs;i, quæ quò major e&longs;t, validior quoquè cæte­
ris paribus efficitur percu&longs;&longs;io.

Sic &longs;i quis velit alteri alapam in­
fligere, nullus erit ictus, &longs;i æquè velociter ad ea&longs;dem partes
moveantur tum percutientis manus, tum is, cui de&longs;tinata e&longs;t
alapa; quia nulla e&longs;t re&longs;i&longs;tentia motum manûs impediens, aut
retardans: erit verò ictus genere ip&longs;o validi&longs;&longs;imus, &longs;i &longs;ibi oc­
currant, & quò majore impetu atque velocitate occurrent, eò
validior; quia nullum e&longs;t majus re&longs;i&longs;tentiæ genus, quàm &longs;i duo
oppo&longs;iti motus &longs;e invicem retundant.

Quod &longs;i demum percu­
tientis manus moveatur velociùs, quàm is, qui percutitur,
quamvis ad ea&longs;dem partes moveantur, ictus infligetur validus
pro Ratione exce&longs;sûs velocitatis, cui motus tardior re&longs;i&longs;tit, qua­
tenus corpus tardum tandem à velociore deprehenditur, atque
urgetur: antè ictum verò &longs;i corpus percu&longs;&longs;um quie&longs;cat, quo ve­
locior erit percutientis motus, validior quoquè erit ictus; ad
eandem enim re&longs;i&longs;tentiam major motus habet majorem Ratio­
nem, quàm minor.

Vim igitur percu&longs;&longs;ionis ex antecedenti motu originem duce­
re manife&longs;tum videtur; non quidem quâ motus e&longs;t ex loco in
locum tran&longs;itus, hic enim ante corporum contactum ictum
nullum infligere pote&longs;t, in ictu autem ip&longs;o motus omnis præce­
dens evanuit, nec jam extinctus quicquam efficere pote&longs;t,
etiam&longs;i motui præ&longs;enti vis aliqua efficiendi tribueretur.

Sed
quia cum motu illo antecedente acqui&longs;itus e&longs;t impetus, qui
adhuc durans ip&longs;o percu&longs;&longs;ionis momento longè plus habet vi­
rium, quàm &longs;i tunc omnino inciperet motus cum impul&longs;ione;
augetur &longs;iquidem in motu impetus ab eâdem cau&longs;a movente
productus &longs;ingulis momentis, &longs;emper enim ad agendum cau&longs;a
nece&longs;&longs;aria applicata e&longs;t, atque, &longs;i maneat, utilitate non caret
impetus, quem &longs;ub&longs;equi pote&longs;t motus.

Quid nimirum cau&longs;æ
e&longs;t, quare ligneus globus leniter aquæ impo&longs;itus innataret, &longs;i
verò ex editâ turri in &longs;ubjectam fo&longs;&longs;am dimittatur, aquam al­
tiùs penetrat?

ni&longs;i quia impetum in motu globus acqui&longs;ivit,
quo per&longs;everante terminos &longs;uæ gravitati à Naturâ præ&longs;criptos
tran&longs;ilit, eóque demum langue&longs;cente, aut illum aqua &longs;ur&longs;um
extrudet, aut vi &longs;uæ levitatis &longs;ponte a&longs;cendet.

Sic citrà nota­
bilem doloris &longs;en&longs;um &longs;u&longs;tinemus capiti impo&longs;itum lapidem for­
tè bipedalem, at non item &longs;crupuli duorum digitorum ex alti­
tudine centum cubitorum decidentis ictum ferre po&longs;&longs;umus ci­
trà incommodum non &longs;anè leve: id quod ex acqui&longs;ito impetu
contingere palàm e&longs;t, nulla quippe alia præter impetum in
promptu e&longs;t cau&longs;a, cui vis hæc efficiendi commodè, atque pro­
babili conjecturâ, tribuenda &longs;it.

Hunc impetum in motu acqui&longs;itum Gravitatis nomine indi­
gitare placuit Ari&longs;toteli, cùm propo&longs;itæ quæ&longs;tioni 19. &longs;atisfa­
cere contendens ait, An quia omnia cum motu fiunt, & grave
ip&longs;um gravitatis magis a&longs;&longs;umit motum, dum movetur, quàm dum
quie&longs;cit?

Neque enim adeò in rebus Phy&longs;icis Ari&longs;totelem,
ejú&longs;que peritiores a&longs;&longs;eclas cæcutii&longs;&longs;e dixerim, ut gravitatem
corpori in&longs;itam, quæ prima radix atque origo e&longs;t, cui motus
debeatur, in ip&longs;o motu revera augeri exi&longs;timaverint (quamvis
nullâ factâ naturæ, &longs;altem con&longs;tipatis partibus, mutatione)
haud &longs;ecus, ac calori calor addatur.

Sed idcirco plus gravitatis
a&longs;&longs;umi dicitur à corpore gravi dum movetur, quàm dum quie&longs;­
cit, quia in motu vi ac pote&longs;tate &longs;e movendi æquiparat corpora
graviora, atque adeò plus habet gravitatis non Formaliter, &longs;ed
Virtualiter & Æquivalenter, ut ip&longs;orum Peripateticorum vo­
cabulis utar.

Cæterùm gravitatis nomine non ip&longs;um pondus
intelligi ab Ari&longs;totele &longs;uadet ip&longs;a loquendi formula, qua gravi­
tatem a&longs;&longs;umptam dum movetur, confert cum gravitate a&longs;&longs;ump­
tâ dum quie&longs;cit, ut hæc illâ minor cen&longs;eatur: videtur enim
Ari&longs;toteles in corpore gravi ad motum prono agno&longs;cere a&longs;­
&longs;umptum impetum, quo fieret connata ip&longs;i corpori gravi mo­
tio, ni&longs;i impediretur, dum quie&longs;cit, & præter hunc impetum,
alium in motu acqui&longs;itum, adeò ut demum utroque impetu
moveatur, ac proinde dicatur in motu plus a&longs;&longs;umere gravitatis.

Quòd &longs;i hæc philo&longs;ophandi ratio placeat, qua corpori gravi
idcircò &longs;altem ad &longs;peciem quie&longs;centi, quòd removere non va­
leat ea, quæ ob&longs;tant, & motum, qui &longs;ub &longs;en&longs;um cadat, impe­
diunt, conceditur impetus Innatus, qui &longs;it ip&longs;a actualis gravi­
tatio in&longs;itæ gravitati addita, reip&longs;a connitens aut adversùs &longs;ub­
jectum corpus, aut contra vim &longs;u&longs;pendentem: Cùm gravitas
in motu alium atque alium adhibeat novum conatum ad
de&longs;cendendum, perinde videtur contingere, ac &longs;i toties mul­
tiplicata fui&longs;&longs;et eadem gravitas, quoties multiplicatus fuit co­
natus priori illi æqualis.

Hac autem ratione non ineptè dixit
Ari&longs;toteles grave ip&longs;um a&longs;&longs;umere plus gravitatis in motu, quia
&longs;ublato motûs impedimento & impetus Innatus &longs;uas omnes vi­
res exerit, & augetur Acqui&longs;ito: ac propterea minor gravitas
&longs;ic æquivalenter multiplicata longè plus efficit, quàm &longs;i major
gravitas incumberet, cujus impetus Innatus impediretur, ne
motum efficeret ullum neque compre&longs;&longs;ionis corporis &longs;ubjecti,
neque di&longs;tentionis corporis &longs;u&longs;pendentis.

Quando autem nul­
lus omnino motus, &longs;ivè qui &longs;ub &longs;en&longs;um cadat, &longs;ive qui aciem
omnem fugiat, tribuitur corpori gravi, nullus quoquè &longs;uperad­
ditus Impetus ip&longs;i connatæ gravitati re&longs;pondens concedendus
e&longs;t; neque enim deor&longs;um reip&longs;a connititur; quamvis in &longs;e ha­
beat principium & originem gravitandi, &longs;i impedimentum &longs;al­
tem ex parte removeatur.

Cùm itaque omne id, quod percu&longs;&longs;ionis ictum con&longs;equitur,
ab impetu oriatur, neque impetum gravitas, aut ulla moven­
di facultas, concipere valeat, quin aliquo &longs;altem motu ip&longs;a mo­
veatur; nil mirum, &longs;i ingens moles prohibita, ne prorsùs mo­
veatur, nullam labem inferat &longs;ubjecto lapidi, quem minor gra­
vitas cadens, atque percutiens in fru&longs;ta comminuit: minor &longs;ci­
licet gravitas liberè de&longs;cendens multum concipit impetum,
quem lapidi percu&longs;&longs;o communicans cogit eum in fru&longs;ta di&longs;&longs;ili­
re, &longs;i vis impetûs &longs;uperet partium nexum, aut &longs;altem cum con­
cutit.

Nullum autem effectum impetûs ab ingenti mole prorsùs
quie&longs;cente expectare po&longs;&longs;umus, quippe quæ nullum imprime­
re pote&longs;t impetum &longs;ubjecto corpori.

Hinc mirari ce&longs;&longs;ent, qui plumbeum globulum primo mallei
ictu certam compre&longs;&longs;ionem pati ob&longs;ervant, &longs;ecundo verò ictu
priori omninò æquali adhuc magis comprimi, quamvis minore
compre&longs;&longs;ione, quia particulæ jam per vim con&longs;tipatæ validiùs
rejiciunt majorem violentiam.

At &longs;i globulum &longs;imilem &longs;ubji­
ciant ponderi, quod illum æquè comprimat, ac prior ictus mal­
lei, addito adhuc æquali pondere non &longs;equitur compre&longs;&longs;io glo­
buli tanta, quæ re&longs;pondeat &longs;ecundo ictui mallei: ex quo &longs;atis
con&longs;tat duplicis percu&longs;&longs;ionis vires non æquari à duplici gravita­
te.

Si enim animum attentè advertant, videbunt mallei mo­
tus tam in primâ quàm in &longs;ecunda percu&longs;&longs;ione planè æquales
e&longs;&longs;e, tùm ratione velocitatis, tùm ratione &longs;patij, ac proinde
æquali impetu malleum percutere: At factâ jam primâ &longs;ubjecti
globuli compre&longs;&longs;ione, in qua gravitas incumbens motum ha­
buit illi compre&longs;&longs;ioni re&longs;pondentem, manife&longs;tum e&longs;t, propter
majorem globuli jam compre&longs;&longs;i re&longs;i&longs;tentiam, non po&longs;&longs;e &longs;ecun­
dam gravitatem priori æqualem additam æquali motu, nec
æquali velocitate moveri, atque propterea neque po&longs;&longs;e æqua­
lem impetum concipere, quo po&longs;&longs;it effectum &longs;ecundo mallei
ictui &longs;imilem producere.

Adde quod &longs;ecundum pondus addi­
tum priori, atque illi impo&longs;itum, &longs;uum habet gravitatis cen­
trum, & commune totius ponderis globulo incumbentis cen­
trum gravitatis transfertur in aliud molis compo&longs;itæ punctum;
ideóque linea directionis non &longs;imiliter incurrit in &longs;ubjectum
globulum, adversùm quem &longs;imiles exhibeat vires.

Neque mihi
facilè per&longs;uadebis tam accuratè &longs;ecundum pondus adjectum
priori, ut po&longs;terius gravitatis centrum in eadem &longs;it lineâ di­
rectionis, nec ab illâ quicquam deflectat.

Quare vel po&longs;terior
hæc gravitas addita priori, jam quie&longs;centi, ubi facta e&longs;t vis
comprimendi par virtuti re&longs;i&longs;tendi, omni pror&longs;us motu caret, &
nihil impetûs pote&longs;t concipere, aut imprimere; vel &longs;olùm te­
nui&longs;&longs;imum, & qui vix po&longs;t multum tempus con&longs;picuus fiat, mo­
tum habet, & non ni&longs;i levem impetum imprimit, quo &longs;ubjectus
globulus demum aliquantulo compre&longs;&longs;ior appareat: ideò, ut
compre&longs;&longs;io &longs;imilis illi, quæ fit à &longs;ecundo mallei ictu, habeatur,
nece&longs;&longs;e e&longs;t gravitatem additam e&longs;&longs;e adhuc majorem, ut gravi­
tas tota compo&longs;ita impetum efficere valeat, quem con&longs;equa­
tur motus æqualis &longs;ecundæ illi compre&longs;&longs;ioni à malleo factæ.

Cur itaque &longs;ecuris ligno incumbens, quamvis ingenti præ­
gravata pondere, vix levem fi&longs;&longs;ionem inferat &longs;ubjecto ligno,
quod tamen altiùs penetratur ab eâdem &longs;ecuri cadente & per­
cutiente, in promptu cau&longs;a e&longs;t: quia videlicet compre&longs;&longs;io, quæ
& impul&longs;io e&longs;t, cum motu quidem fit, &longs;ed ip&longs;o &longs;tatim initio &
in progre&longs;&longs;u ade&longs;t re&longs;i&longs;tentia, ne producatur totus impetus,
quem vis motiva po&longs;&longs;et efficere, & motus non e&longs;t, ni&longs;i quan­
tum impellitur objectum corpus; ideóque &longs;ecuris vi ponderis
incumbentis non valet in huju&longs;modi motu alium impetum con­
cipere præter illum, quem fert præ&longs;ens motus, qui valde exi­
guus e&longs;t: At percu&longs;&longs;io ea e&longs;t, ut cùm primùm &longs;ecuris cadens
applicatur ligno, jam multum habeat concepti impetus in aëre
libero, & nihil adhuc re&longs;i&longs;tente ligno, ac propterea po&longs;&longs;it ve­
lociùs moveri comprimendo & dividendo &longs;ubjectum lignum.

Ex quo fit onus &longs;ecuri impo&longs;itum tantæ gravitatis e&longs;&longs;e oportere,
ut quæ Ratio e&longs;t &longs;patij à &longs;ecuri cadente decur&longs;i ad &longs;patium, quo
illa penetrat lignum, ea &longs;altem &longs;it Ratio gravitatis conflatæ ex
&longs;ecuri & addito pondere ad gravitatem &longs;implicis &longs;ecuris, ut fieret
æqualis &longs;ci&longs;&longs;io ab eâdem &longs;ecuri: ut videlicet tantumdem im­
petûs concipiatur à magnâ gravitate in exiguo motu præ&longs;ente
re&longs;i&longs;tentiâ, quantum impetûs concipitur à &longs;ecuri in anteceden­
te motu longiore ab&longs;que re&longs;i&longs;tentiâ ullâ, præterquam medij.

Similiter nullum adhiberi po&longs;&longs;e pondus, quo aureæ lamellæ
impo&longs;ito hæc diduci po&longs;&longs;it in &longs;ubtili&longs;&longs;imam bracteolam, quem­
admodum vi mallei percutientis, ex ii&longs;dem principiis con&longs;tat.

Attende enim, quanto motu moveri po&longs;&longs;it illud pondus com­
primens; utique non ni&longs;i quantum e&longs;t altitudinis di&longs;crimen in­
ter lamellam & bracteolam: at tantillum &longs;patium, in quo exer­
cendus e&longs;&longs;et motus, quam Rationem habet ad toties multipli­
catum &longs;patium, in quo iteratis &longs;æpiùs ictibus liberè movetur
malleus?

Cùm itaque minimus motus, aut etiam forta&longs;sè nul­
lus, po&longs;t tenui&longs;&longs;imam auri compre&longs;&longs;ionem ingenti illi oneri con­
veniat, nil mirum &longs;i exiguo impetu ferè nihil efficiat, cùm ta­
men malleus novo &longs;emper impetu &longs;ingulis ictibus concepto ali­
quam, licèt &longs;emper minorem atque minorem, compre&longs;&longs;ionem
efficiat.

Ut autem res hæc pleniùs innote&longs;cat, ob&longs;erva impul&longs;ionem,
qua corpus urgetur, opponi tractioni, & compre&longs;&longs;ionem par­
tium di&longs;tractioni, atque &longs;icut corporis, quod urgetur, particu­
læ aliquando comprimuntur, ita corporis, quod trahitur, par­
ticulas aliquando di&longs;trahi, aut divelli, neque di&longs;&longs;imilem e&longs;&longs;e
re&longs;i&longs;tentiam corporum vi &longs;uæ gravitatis, ne impellantur, aut
ratione po&longs;itionis partium, ne comprimantur, ac ne trahantur,
aut particularum nexus di&longs;&longs;olvatur.

Quapropter ubi primùm
incipit impul&longs;io aut tractio, &longs;ive compre&longs;&longs;io aut di&longs;tractio, in­
cipit etiam re&longs;i&longs;tentia, quæ eò major evadit, quò majorem vio­
lentiam &longs;ubit corpus.

Hinc e&longs;t potentiam impellentem aut tra­
hentem &longs;emper minore impetu ferri, quàm &longs;i liberè moveretur,
dum nulla ade&longs;&longs;et re&longs;i&longs;tentia.

Sic &longs;i quis funiculum, quem re­
tinet clavus parieti infixus, arripiat, atque jam extentum
trahat, illum quidem multo ni&longs;u intendit, &longs;ed nec illum di&longs;­
rumpere valet, nec clavum revellere: &longs;ed &longs;i eodem conatu fu­
niculum languidum nec dum extentum trahat, celeriter mo­
vetur manus, antequam funiculus extendatur, & facilè aut hic
abrumpitur, aut ille revellitur.

Quia nimirum extenti jam fu­
niculi re&longs;i&longs;tentia, ne intendatur, impedit, ne potentia pro Ra­
tione &longs;ui conatûs moveatur, multo impetu ab&longs;umpto in vincen­
dâ illâ re&longs;i&longs;tentia; neque movetur potentia ni&longs;i cunctabunda,
& per brevi&longs;&longs;imum &longs;patium, quantum vi inten&longs;ionis funiculus
magis extenditur: At ubi languidus e&longs;t funiculus, potentia
ab&longs;que ullo retinente per aliquantum &longs;patij liberè movetur, &
totum impetum &longs;uo conatui re&longs;pondentem in efficiendo celeri
motu impendit, quem jam notabiliter auctum invenit funicu­
lus, cum primùm e&longs;t extentus, & adhuc magis augetur per&longs;e­
verante eodem conatu.

Quare cùm multò major &longs;it impetus,
&longs;atis e&longs;&longs;e pote&longs;t non &longs;olùm ad intendendum funiculum, verùm
etiam ad illum di&longs;rumpendum, aut, &longs;i, hujus particulæ validio­
re nexu jungantur, ad revellendum clavum.

Ex his habes, quid re&longs;pondeat docti&longs;&longs;imis viris vim percu&longs;­
&longs;ionis inve&longs;tigantibus.

Ut apparet, quantâ vi plumbeus globu­
lus unciarum duarum ex cubitali altitudine cadens percuteret
&longs;ubjectum corpus, exi&longs;timârunt &longs;atis innote&longs;cere, &longs;i globulus
ille funiculo cubitali adnecteretur chordæ arcûs medio loco in­
ter extremitates.

Tum &longs;ublatus globulus u&longs;que ad chordam
ip&longs;am, dimi&longs;&longs;us e&longs;t, atque ob&longs;ervatum e&longs;t punctum, ad quod
adducta e&longs;t chorda: proclive enim erat arguere, globulum
tantâ vi percu&longs;&longs;urum &longs;ubjectum corpus, quantâ vi inflectebat
bali&longs;tæ arcum.

Quare tentando varia pondera addiderunt
chordæ arcûs, donec demum pondus decem librarum chordam
ad idem punctum adduxit, ad quod adducta fuerat à globo ca-
dente, atque in eodem flexionis &longs;tatu chordam & arcum deti­
nuit.

Arguebant igitur percu&longs;&longs;ionem globi plumbei duarum
unciarum ex cubitali altitudine cadentis æquiparari pre&longs;&longs;ioni
decem librarum.

Ulteriùs autem progrediendo, adhibita e&longs;t ba­
li&longs;ta alia validior, cujus arcus ob duriorem ferri temperationem
minùs erat flexibilis: quapropter cum eju&longs;dem potentiæ eadem
&longs;it vis, eju&longs;dem globuli ex eâdem altitudine &longs;imiliter cadentis
non ni&longs;i eædem e&longs;&longs;e poterant vires ad vincendam æqualem re­
&longs;i&longs;tentiam: atque adeò durioris arcûs minor flexio æquè re­
&longs;i&longs;tens, ac major flexio arcûs mollioris, breviore termino de­
finivit de&longs;cen&longs;um globuli plumbei, & ad propius punctum ad­
ducta e&longs;t chorda.

Verùm, ut in eodem flexionis &longs;tatu fortior
hic arcus retineretur, non &longs;atis fuit decem libras appendere,
&longs;ed viginti librarum pondere opus fuit.

Hinc inferebant ean­
dem eju&longs;dem globuli duarum unciarum percu&longs;&longs;ionem æquare
non &longs;olùm vires librarum decem, &longs;ed & viginti: atque u&longs;que
eò argumentationem deducebant, ut a&longs;&longs;umpto robu&longs;tiore ali­
quo arcu concluderent, ne pondus quidem librarum mille &longs;atis
e&longs;&longs;e ad arcum illum in eâ po&longs;itione retinendum, ad quam fui&longs;­
&longs;et adductus à globo duarum unciarum cadente: id quod vim
quandam percu&longs;&longs;ionis infinitam indicare videbatur.

Verùm quamvis hos ingenio&longs;orum hominum conatus non
modò non improbem, &longs;ed multâ commendatione dignos exi&longs;ti­
mem, liceat tamen mihi argumentationis infirmitatem expo­
nere; tam enim non e&longs;t vis percu&longs;&longs;ionis duarum unciarum in­
finita, quàm infinita non e&longs;t vis pre&longs;&longs;ionis decem librarum.

Quando enim vi ponderis adnexi flectitur arcus, utique pon­
dus de&longs;cendit, & &longs;uâ gravitate &longs;uperat rigidi chalybis vires,
donec demum æqualitas quædam intercedat inter vim arcûs
ela&longs;ticam, & gravitatis conatum ad de&longs;cendendum; tunc &longs;cili­
cet fit con&longs;i&longs;tentia.

Prout igitur robu&longs;tiores &longs;unt arcus, minùs
permittunt de&longs;cendere pondus chordæ appen&longs;um, &longs;i omnia &longs;int
paria: Nam &longs;i brevior &longs;it arcus mollis & languidus, longior ve­
rò arcus durioris temperationis, fieri pote&longs;t, ut idem pondus
æqualiter adducat longiorem chordam atque breviorem, &longs;imi­
li planè ratione ac de ponderibus fune &longs;u&longs;pen&longs;is præponderan­
tibus atque æquilibribus dictum e&longs;t lib.3. cap.12: ideò ponendi
&longs;unt arcus ita &longs;imiles & æquales, ut &longs;olâ ferri temperatione di&longs;-
crepent.

Si igitur validioris arcus repugnantia, ut flectatur ad
duos digitos, tanta e&longs;t, quanta repugnantia mollioris arcûs, ut
flectatur ad &longs;ex digitos, patet non e&longs;&longs;e eumdem impetum de­
cem librarum de&longs;cendentium &longs;olùm per duos priores digitos,
atque per &longs;ex: ac proinde cùm decem libræ applicatæ arcui va­
lidiori &longs;olùm po&longs;&longs;unt per duos digitos (& quidem lentiùs
propter majorem re&longs;i&longs;tentiam) moveri, minus po&longs;&longs;ent, quàm
per impetum conceptum in motu &longs;ex digitorum; & propterea
neque po&longs;&longs;ent illius robu&longs;tioris arcûs chordam adducere ad
duos digitos; &longs;ed neque adductam ab aliâ potentiâ po&longs;&longs;ent reti­
nere in eo &longs;tatu ac po&longs;itione: quia etiam &longs;i vis ela&longs;tica arcûs ro­
bu&longs;tioris inflexi ad duos digitos par e&longs;&longs;et virtuti ela&longs;ticæ arcûs
imbecillioris inflexi ad &longs;ex digitos, cui reluctantur decem li­
bræ; hæ minùs repugnant, ne ad duos digitos, quàm ne ad &longs;ex
attollantur; igitur decem libræ minùs re&longs;i&longs;tunt virtuti ela&longs;ticæ
arcûs fortioris, adeóque nec po&longs;&longs;unt in eo flexionis &longs;tatu reti­
nere arcum fortiorem & chordam: &longs;i enim pares &longs;unt vires
ela&longs;ticæ arcûs inflexi ad duos digitos, & arcûs inflexi ad &longs;ex di­
gitos, pari impetu &longs;e re&longs;tituunt, ut parem violentiam excu­
tiant; at pondus par utrique chordæ adnexum non pari veloci­
tate movetur, &longs;i ad duos ac &longs;i ad &longs;ex digitos attollatur; igitur
minùs re&longs;i&longs;tunt decem libræ motui duorum, quàm motui &longs;ex
digitorum.

Porrò vis globi cadentis non e&longs;t comparanda cum pondere
quatenus retinente chordam in eadem flexione, &longs;ed quatenus
illam adducente & flectente, ut motus cum motu, non verò
motus cum quiete comparetur.

In eo autem motu ponderis ad­
ducentis chordam, & arcum inflectentis, quò major e&longs;t re­
&longs;i&longs;tentia, eò minor e&longs;t impetus & velocitas, qua pondus illud
movetur: igitur idem pondus non parem vim habere pote&longs;t,
ubi di&longs;pari impetu & velocitate movetur.

At globus cadens
antequam incipiat trahere chordam, nullum pror&longs;us habet im­
pedimentum, &longs;ed &longs;ivè fortior, &longs;ivè mollior &longs;it arcus, eodem im­
petu & velocitate movetur; ubi verò re&longs;i&longs;tentiam invenit, &longs;o­
lùm de&longs;cendit ulteriùs pro ratione repugnantiæ; & factä de­
mum æqualitate inter vim de&longs;cendendi à globulo acqui&longs;itam,
& vim ela&longs;ticam in arcu, ce&longs;&longs;at de&longs;cen&longs;us, atque extincto im­
petu acqui&longs;ito, vi ela&longs;ticâ vincente globuli gravitatem, hic &longs;ur-
&longs;um trahitur.

Cùm itaque quicquid vi extrin&longs;ecùs a&longs;&longs;umptâ
movetur, moveatur juxta exce&longs;&longs;um virtutis motivæ &longs;upra re­
&longs;i&longs;tentiam; &longs;i æqualis re&longs;i&longs;tentiæ men&longs;ura, quæ ex di&longs;&longs;imilium
arcuum majori aut minori flexione de&longs;umitur, eumdem exce&longs;­
&longs;um virtutis motivæ exigat, ut vincatur, & hunc exce&longs;&longs;um ha­
beat globulus cadens, nil mirum, &longs;i idem globulus cadens id
præ&longs;tare po&longs;&longs;it, quod &longs;uperat vires alicujus ponderis, cujus vis
movendi non eumdem &longs;emper exce&longs;&longs;um habet &longs;upra illam re­
&longs;i&longs;tentiam priori re&longs;i&longs;tentiæ æqualem; quia videlicet non æqua­
li impetûs inten&longs;ione aggreditur motum, ubi ip&longs;o &longs;tatim initio
major invenitur difficultas, & tardior e&longs;t motus.

Non e&longs;t igitur
vis infinita globuli duarum unciarum nullo impedimento prohi­
biti, quin ad trahendam cuju&longs;cumque arcûs chordam &longs;emper
afferat, exempli gratiâ, centum gradus impetûs in motu acqui­
&longs;itos, quando pondera majora & majora tractionem incipientia
à quiete non parem habent impetûs exce&longs;&longs;um, &longs;ed minorem &
minorem pro duriore arcûs temperatione.

An infinitam dixe­
ris equi virtutem, qui &longs;olus in liberâ planitie currum trahat, ad
quem trahendum in eâdem planitie altioribus atque altioribus
nivibus ob&longs;itâ requiruntur plures & plures equi?

igitur nec in­
finita e&longs;t vis decem librarum, qua flectitur arcus mollis, quia
ad flectendos arcus fortiores majus & majus pondus requiritur:
huic autem virtuti decem librarum æqualis e&longs;t vis globuli ca­
dentis; hæc igitur & ip&longs;a finita e&longs;t.

Nimirum aucta re&longs;i&longs;tentia
quodammodo imminuit virtutem agendi; ac propterea non &longs;a­
tis aptè comparantur decem libræ cum viginti libris perinde,
atque &longs;i utræque e&longs;&longs;ent omnino liberæ; &longs;ed unumquodque pon­
dus componi debet cum &longs;uâ re&longs;i&longs;tentiâ, ut demum habeatur
exce&longs;&longs;us virtutis motivæ &longs;upra re&longs;i&longs;tentiam.

At, inquis, arcus fortior retinetur à libris viginti, & infir­
mior à libris decem.

Ita planè e&longs;t: &longs;ed hìc pondera propriè non
habent rationem efficientis, &longs;ed potiùs re&longs;i&longs;tentis, quatenus
impediunt arcuum vim ela&longs;ticam, ne &longs;e re&longs;tituant: cùm verò
virtutes ela&longs;ticæ ex genere &longs;uo propter di&longs;parem temperatio­
nem inæquales &longs;int, nil mirum, &longs;i ab inæqualibus re&longs;i&longs;tentiis
impediendæ &longs;int, ne agant.

Hinc autem non e&longs;t de&longs;umenda
ulla comparatio cum virtute globuli cadentis, quippe qui ac­
qui&longs;itum impetum amittens non habet vim retinendi arcum in
eo &longs;tatu; ad quem illum adduxit: at ponderis adnexi gravitas
manet, & ibi retinet arcum, quò eum adduxit; ni&longs;i fortè ali­
quem impetum acqui&longs;ierit in de&longs;cen&longs;u, quo pereunte, aliquan­
tulum præpolleat vis ela&longs;tica, & &longs;ur&longs;um retrahat appen&longs;um
pondus.

Licet igitur globulo cadenti æqualiter re&longs;i&longs;tere dican­
tur arcus fortior qui minùs flectitur, & mollior qui magis flecti­
tur; po&longs;tquam tamen jam per vim inflexi &longs;unt arcus, naturali­
ter partes minùs flexibiles validiùs conantur &longs;e re&longs;tituere, quàm
flexibiliores: quemadmodum gravitas ut quatuor, & gravitas
ut duo, &longs;i moveantur per vim motu reciprocè &longs;ubduplo, æqua­
liter re&longs;i&longs;tunt moventi; &longs;ed &longs;i utraque &longs;u&longs;pendatur, inæquali­
ter conantur &longs;uos motus naturales.
CAPUT VII.

Quàm di&longs;pares ex motûs velocitate &longs;int
percu&longs;siones.

PErcu&longs;&longs;ionem ex ea parte, quatenus à &longs;implici Impul&longs;ione
di&longs;tinguitur, motum exigere antecedentem, quo impetus
acquiratur, &longs;uperiori capite definitum e&longs;t.

Nunc verò, quia pro
motuum velocitate diversâ di&longs;pares &longs;unt percu&longs;&longs;ionum vires,
quærendum e&longs;t, unde di&longs;&longs;imilitudo i&longs;ta procreetur, & quænam
&longs;ervari Ratio videatur, &longs;ivè inæquales eju&longs;dem corporis, &longs;ive
diver&longs;orum corporum percu&longs;&longs;iones inter &longs;e comparentur.

E&longs;t
autem con&longs;iderandum in Impetu, qui e&longs;t proximè efficiens mo­
tum, aliud e&longs;&longs;e ejus quantitatem, &longs;ivè entitatem accipere, aliud
in eju&longs;dem Inten&longs;ione con&longs;i&longs;tere: inten&longs;ionem con&longs;equitur ve­
locitas motûs, at ex entitate ipsâ magis extensâ, quamvis mi­
nùs intensâ, ac proinde ex motu tardiore, oriri pote&longs;t validior
ictus, de quo in &longs;equentibus.

Ex motûs autem velocitate, quæ
corpori vi præcedentis motûs congrueret, &longs;i nihil ob&longs;taret, per­
cu&longs;&longs;ionem fieri majorem tam certis experimentis con&longs;tat, ut vel
cæci, &longs;i quando præfidentes concitatiùs ambulando caput ad
objectum parietem allidunt, id abundè te&longs;tari valeant; corpus
&longs;iquidem, quod motui re&longs;i&longs;tit, majori & velociori motui ma­
gis re&longs;i&longs;tit, quare & percu&longs;&longs;io fit validior.

Ubi verò de motûs velocitate &longs;ermo e&longs;t, non videtur di&longs;&longs;imu­
landa medij &longs;cindendi re&longs;i&longs;tentia; hoc quippe tardiori motui
minùs, velociori magis ob&longs;tat.

Si enim ex lento & flexili vir­
gulto ab&longs;tractam virgam per aërem molli brachio huc, illuc,
&longs;ur&longs;um, deor&longs;um duxeris, hæc, aëre tenui&longs;&longs;imam aut ferè nul­
lam compre&longs;&longs;ionem &longs;ubeunte, vix, aut ne vix quidem, tantu­
lum à directâ &longs;uarum partium po&longs;itione deflectet: at &longs;i eam ve­
hementius agitaveris, aëre tantam particularum compre&longs;&longs;io­
nem renuente, manife&longs;tè inflexam videbis, & illatam &longs;ibi vim
aër acuto &longs;ibilo prodet.

Sic baculo aquam &longs;en&longs;im ac leniter di­
videns non admodum repugnantem experiris; at velociùs con­
citanti illa validè re&longs;i&longs;tit, eóque validiùs, quò cra&longs;&longs;ior fuerit
baculus.

Ex his liquidò conficitur de percu&longs;&longs;ione philo&longs;ophan­
tem fru&longs;tra medij re&longs;i&longs;tentiam mente ab&longs;trahere: Nam &longs;i nulla
e&longs;t &longs;ine motu percu&longs;&longs;io, nullus motus ni&longs;i per medium, neque
&longs;inè certa velocitatis aut tarditatis men&longs;urâ, cui medium inæ­
qualiter re&longs;i&longs;tit; utique & motum à percu&longs;&longs;ione ita mente pari­
ter &longs;ejungere poteris, ut nihil pror&longs;us de motu cogites, &longs;i nul­
lam cum medio rationem habendam exi&longs;timas: At motum, ejú&longs;­
que velocitatem attendendam e&longs;&longs;e in percu&longs;&longs;ione nemo negat;
igitur neque medij re&longs;i&longs;tentiam, quæ velocitati modum ali­
quem &longs;tatuit, omnino contemnere oportet.

Hinc duæ ferè ex diametro oppo&longs;itæ &longs;ententiæ cavendæ
&longs;unt, quarum altera gravium inæqualium motum &longs;tatuit ip&longs;o­
rum gravitatibus analogum, ut decuplò velociùs moveatur il­
lud, quod e&longs;t decuplò gravius: altera æqualem omnibus velo­
citatem tribuit.

Utramque manife&longs;ta experimenta fal&longs;itatis re­
darguunt, &longs;i ex congruâ altitudine in&longs;tituantur: Si enim ex val­
dè editâ turri inæqualia corpora, aut eju&longs;dem, aut diver&longs;æ &longs;e­
cundùm &longs;peciem gravitatis dimittas, illud, quod gravius e&longs;t,
terram citiùs attingere ob&longs;ervabis, &longs;ed tam brevi momentorum
di&longs;crimine, ut nulla &longs;ube&longs;&longs;e po&longs;&longs;it &longs;u&longs;picio &longs;ervatæ velocitatum
cum gravitatibus analogiæ, neque tamen de velocitatum inæ­
qualitati dubitari queat.

Meis &longs;cilicet auribus & oculis fidem
abrogare nequeo, quicquid obtrudant aliqui in contrarium &longs;ua
aut aliorum experimenta afferentes ex nimis brevi altitudine.
Nam & &longs;æpiùs in profundi&longs;&longs;imum puteum inæquales lapides
dimi&longs;i &longs;imul, & ictuum &longs;onitum alium alio priorem &longs;emper au­
divi; id quod &longs;atis e&longs;t ad illam velocitatum omnimodam æqua­
litatem rejiciendam, quamvis uter prior aquam attigerit, certò
digno&longs;cere non valeret auris; quòd &longs;i alter in &longs;ubjectam peluim
æneam, alter in vas ligneum decidi&longs;&longs;et, potui&longs;&longs;et auris dijudi­
care ex &longs;onitu: Et ex alti&longs;&longs;imâ turri Bononien&longs;i dimi&longs;&longs;a pondera
inæqualia ob&longs;ervavi initio qua&longs;i æqualiter de&longs;cendere ita, ut
oculus nullam velocitatum di&longs;&longs;imilitudinem adhuc digno&longs;ce­
ret; deinde procedente de&longs;cen&longs;u paulatim gravitas major præ­
currere notabiliter incipiebat, &longs;empérque magis augebatur ve­
locitas, adeò ut aliquando gravitas major terram attigerit,
quando minor adhuc aberat intervallo pedum quadraginta,
quemadmodum ex notâ in turris latere dimetiri licuit.

Verum
quidem e&longs;t brevi&longs;&longs;imâ temporis men&longs;urâ & hanc minorem in
terram decidi&longs;&longs;e.

Id quod forta&longs;&longs;e fucum fecit non animadver­
tentibus magnæ velocitati multum re&longs;pondere &longs;patij, quod
qua&longs;i momento percurritur; ac propterea æqualitatem veloci­
tatum utrique gravitati tribuendam cen&longs;uerunt, quia exiguum
erat temporum di&longs;crimen.

An vellus, quantum pugno com­
prehenditur, æquè velociter ac prægrande &longs;axum de&longs;cen&longs;urum
exi&longs;timas?

Figuræ dices tribuendum plurimum, non enim ab
omnibus corporibus æquè facilè dividitur aër nunquam non
fluctuans.

Ita &longs;ane: igitur &longs;i aër inæqualiter re&longs;i&longs;tit, inæqua­
liter moveri po&longs;&longs;unt corpora cadentia.

Adde non di&longs;&longs;imiliter
gravia & levia ad &longs;uos motus à naturâ incitari; atque adeò &longs;i,
ubi plus e&longs;t levitatis, velociorem motum &longs;ur&longs;um ob&longs;ervamus,
etiam, ubi plus e&longs;t gravitatis concitatiorem motum deor&longs;um
arguere debemus.

Aquam in longiore fi&longs;tulâ vitreá aliquan­
diu agita, ut aër fi&longs;tulæ inclu&longs;us aquæ admi&longs;ceatur: ubi ab agi­
tatione ce&longs;&longs;atum fuerit, majores aëris particulas citò a&longs;cenden­
tes videbis, dum minores cunctabundæ paulatim moventur: id
quod clariùs con&longs;tabit, &longs;i aquæ loco hydrargyrum in fi&longs;tulam
admi&longs;eris.

Quidni igitur gravia pariter deor&longs;um di&longs;pari velo­
citate moveantur, &longs;i inæqualia fuerint?

Non tamen &longs;ervandam e&longs;&longs;e gravitatum analogiam hinc
apertè con&longs;tat, quod in corporibus eju&longs;dem &longs;peciei Ratio gra­
vitatum eadem e&longs;t ac magnitudinum: magnitudines autem
&longs;unt in triplicatâ Ratione homologorum laterum: At impedi­
mentum, quod ex medio &longs;cindendo oritur, & velocitati mo­
dum &longs;tatuit, non e&longs;t ip&longs;is magnitudinibus analogum, &longs;ed ad
&longs;ummum ea e&longs;&longs;e pote&longs;t Ratio, quæ inter corporum &longs;uperficies
intercedit; hæ autem tantùm &longs;unt in duplicatâ Ratione late­
rum homologorum.

Non igitur velocitates, quatenus ab im­
pedimento temperantur, &longs;unt directè gravitatibus analogæ.

Ubi autem corpora non eju&longs;dem &longs;ecundùm &longs;peciem gravitatis,
habuerint gravitates magnitudinibus reciprocè analogas, atque
adeò æquali gravitate ab&longs;olutâ, &longs;eu pondere, prædita fuerint,
adhuc inæquales e&longs;&longs;e aëris re&longs;i&longs;tentias, &longs;i figuræ &longs;imiles &longs;int,
&longs;atis probabiliter concedimus, plus &longs;iquidem majori repugnat,
quàm minori: &longs;i verò & di&longs;&longs;imiles figuræ, & inæquales gravi­
tates ponantur, ex omnibus &longs;imul compo&longs;itis quodammodo
conflari re&longs;i&longs;tentiarum Rationem facile e&longs;t opinari; &longs;ed Ratio­
nis terminos temerè definire non au&longs;im.

Porrò certam legem, qua in re&longs;i&longs;tendo aër contineatur, om­
ninò afferre non po&longs;&longs;umus, &longs;i quemadmodum ille re&longs;i&longs;tat, per­
pendamus.

Non eadem e&longs;t aquæ & aëris re&longs;i&longs;tendi Ratio, ne
dividatur; aqua enim nondum in vaporem extenuata, & fu&longs;a,
con&longs;tipari &longs;e, & in angu&longs;tiora &longs;patia coarctari non &longs;init; &longs;ed ubi
locum de&longs;cendenti ex aëre corpori concedere cogitur, &longs;uper­
ficiem intrà vas, quo continetur, attollens tantumdem aëri,
quem impellit, &longs;urripit &longs;patij, quantum immer&longs;o corpori per­
mittit.

Aut &longs;i non de&longs;cendat corpus, &longs;ed obliquè feratur (ut &longs;i
baculum partim aquæ immi&longs;&longs;um, partim extantem tran&longs;ver&longs;um
agas, aut navis prora illam findat) tunc quæ motui opponitur,
aqua cri&longs;patur, & baculus &longs;ivè navis foveam ponè relinquit, in
quam deinde aqua refluat; quò autem cra&longs;&longs;ior baculus aut am­
plior prora, & vehementior atque concitatior fuerit motus,
aqua impul&longs;a altiùs a&longs;&longs;urgit, & magis depre&longs;&longs;a fovea apparet.

Ex quo &longs;atis apertè con&longs;tat à corpore, quod movetur, proximas
aquæ oppo&longs;itæ particulas impelli, & per has interjectas etiam
reliquas in aëris locum protrudi.

At verò aër, quem facilè comprimi & dilatari tam multis ex­
perimentis novimus, dum locum corpori commoto concedit,
neque opus e&longs;t, ut &longs;upremi ætheris regionem invadat locum
&longs;ibi quærens, neque in foveam excavatus vel ad momentum
hiat; &longs;ed tanti&longs;per dum ejus particulæ circumpul&longs;æ in abeun­
tis corporis relictum &longs;patium &longs;uccedant, quæ antè &longs;unt, com­
primuntur, quæ ponè, dilatantur; compre&longs;&longs;æ autem &longs;e expli­
cantes aërem lateribus adhærentem repellunt, quem dilatatæ
attrahunt &longs;e contrahentes.

Si tardus &longs;it motus, exiguâ aëris
con&longs;tipatione aut di&longs;tractione opus e&longs;t; at &longs;i velocior, oppo&longs;itæ
aëris particulæ magis comprimuntur, &longs;equentes magis dilatan­
tur; quæ proinde &longs;e re&longs;tituere vehementiùs conantes, etiam
velociorem efficiunt reliquarum particularum circumpul&longs;io­
nem.

Verùm quia &longs;apienti&longs;&longs;imo Naturæ in&longs;tituto ita compara­
tum e&longs;t, ut quàm minimum ejus ordo perturbetur, & mini­
mam, quoad fieri po&longs;&longs;it, corpora &longs;ingula patiantur violentiam,
hanc pluribus potiùs di&longs;pertiendam cen&longs;uit, quàm uni &longs;ubeun­
dam: propterea &longs;i digitale &longs;patium multo aëri &longs;urripiendum e&longs;t,
exigua contingit &longs;ingulis particulis naturalis &longs;patij jactura,
quam di&longs;&longs;imulanter ferunt, nec admodum repugnant; contra
verò &longs;i modicus &longs;it aër, & tantumdem de ejus &longs;patio demendum
&longs;it, reluctatur acriùs, ut pro viribus naturæ jura tueatur.

Hinc
&longs;i corpus, quod movetur, brevi intervallo ab&longs;it à corpore &longs;oli­
do & duro, quod ejus motum ob&longs;i&longs;tendo compe&longs;cet, atque
adeò etiam aërem impul&longs;um remoratur, hunc inter angu&longs;tias
deprehen&longs;um magis con&longs;tipari nece&longs;&longs;e e&longs;t, magí&longs;que re&longs;i&longs;tere.

Non e&longs;t tamen aëri denegandum, quod cæteris corporibus ul­
tro concedimus; nam & ip&longs;e jam commotus ex concepto per
impul&longs;ionem externam, aut ex vi &longs;uâ ela&longs;ticâ, impetu faciliùs
pergit in&longs;titutum iter conficere, quàm &longs;i tunc primùm à quie­
te recederet: Ex quo fit in motu corporis accelerato, licèt ra­
tione habitâ velocitatis augenda e&longs;&longs;et re&longs;i&longs;tentia aëris, hanc ta­
men non augeri ni&longs;i pro exce&longs;&longs;u velocitatis illius &longs;upra motum,
quo aër moveretur ad ea&longs;dem partes, ni&longs;i acriùs ab ip&longs;o corpo­
re urgeretur.

Hanc aëris re&longs;i&longs;tentiam paulò explicatiùs commemorare pla­
cuit eo con&longs;ilio, ut mihi ip&longs;e per&longs;uadeam non modò ip&longs;um
nihil omnino non officere motui, verùm etiam tam fieri non
po&longs;&longs;e, ut percu&longs;&longs;ionibus certi&longs;&longs;imam legem &longs;tatuamus, quàm
evidens e&longs;t adeò incon&longs;tantem & variam e&longs;&longs;e aëris re&longs;i&longs;ten­
tiam, ut ad calculos &longs;ubtiliter & exqui&longs;itè revocari nequeat,
quippe quæ ex tam variis cau&longs;is pendet: quemadmodum enim
aquæ, cæterorúmque liquorum di&longs;&longs;imilium re&longs;i&longs;tentia inæqua­
lis con&longs;picua e&longs;t, ita purum ac tenuem aërem non æquè re&longs;i&longs;te­
re atque cra&longs;&longs;um & concretum ratio &longs;uadet: quis autem &longs;ynce­
rum aërem ab aëre cum terræ expirationibus permi&longs;to di&longs;cer­
nat?

Quid &longs;i corpus in motu aërem aliò directum, aut in con­
trarias partes reflexum, aut turbine aliquo perver&longs;um atque
adhuc agitatum offendat?

an non aliquis velocitatis gradus im­
minuitur?

Sed quis certum habeat, utrùm quie&longs;cat aër, neque
corporis impetum frangat, aut reprimat aliena impre&longs;&longs;ione ad­
ver&longs;us, an verò ad ea&longs;dem partes delatus motui ob&longs;ecundet, &
velocitati faveat?

Quare laudandi quidem quicumque percu&longs;­
&longs;ionum naturam ve&longs;tigantes, & ea, quibus in ejus notitiam
deduci po&longs;&longs;ent, conjecturá pro&longs;picientes, in in&longs;tituendi expe­
rimentis &longs;edulò &longs;e exercuerunt; parùm tamen mihi de veritate
blandiri me po&longs;&longs;e arbitrarer, &longs;i hæc qua&longs;i Apodixes temerè reci­
perem; &longs;ed neque ore tam duro fuerim, ut ea prorsùs rejiciam.

Confirmatis igitur experimentis me duci &longs;inam, quatenus ad
veritatis &longs;imilitudinem me proximè acce&longs;&longs;urum &longs;pero.

Percu&longs;&longs;io itaque, &longs;i motum naturalem ex gravitate ortum &longs;ub­
&longs;equatur, certam aliquam Rationem ob idip&longs;um &longs;ortiri videtur,
quia cum velocitate con&longs;entit impetus: velocitas autem ex &longs;pa­
tio deprehenditur æqualibus temporibus re&longs;pondente; &longs;patia
verò cum temporibus comparata certis Rationibus definita vi­
deri, iterata experimenta docuerunt, quæ vix qui&longs;quam &longs;anus
neget; in iis &longs;iquidem tot docti&longs;&longs;imi viri po&longs;t Galilæum ver&longs;ati
&longs;unt pari exitu, & &longs;ummo con&longs;en&longs;u, ut in his omnibus in&longs;it
quidam, &longs;ine ullo fuco veritatis color.

Hujus rei &longs;pecimen
exhibeamus in globo argillaceo unciarum octo, qui &longs;patio unius
&longs;crupuli &longs;ecundi (quantus ferè e&longs;t pul&longs;us arteriæ hominis &longs;ani)
ob&longs;ervatus e&longs;t percurrere pedes Romanos 15; duplo autem
tempore incipiendo à quiete, hoc e&longs;t &longs;crupulis &longs;ecundis duo­
bus, pedes 60: quare &longs;i priori &longs;crupulo &longs;ecundo re&longs;pondent pe­
des 15, po&longs;teriori tribuendi &longs;unt pedes 45: igitur motus e&longs;t ce­
lerior, cùm majus &longs;patium pari tempore confecerit.

Plura hu­
ju&longs;modi experimenta (&longs;i te à tentando ab&longs;terreat labor) &longs;uppe­
ditabit Ricciolius tom.1. Almag. lib.9. &longs;ect.4. cap.16. ex quibus
demum infertur velocitatis incrementa fieri juxta incremen­
tum progre&longs;&longs;ionis Arithmeticæ numerorum imparium ab unita-
te incipientis 1.3.5.7.9.11.13, &c.

adeò ut, &longs;i quod &longs;patium pri­
mo momento percurritur, &longs;tatuatur ut 1, triplo velociùs movea­
tur corpus grave de&longs;cendens in &longs;ecundo momento, quintuplo
velocius in tertio, &longs;eptuplo velociùs in quarto, atque ita dein­
ceps.

Quoniam verò numerorum imparium &longs;eries ab unitate
incipiens hoc habet, quòd, &longs;i colligantur in &longs;ummam, nume­
ros quadratos con&longs;tituant; hinc e&longs;t, quòd collectis in &longs;ummam
omnibus incrementis velocitatis (hoc e&longs;t omnibus &longs;patiis, ex
his quippe digno&longs;citur velocitas) habeatur numerus quadratus
temporis, quod duravit motus.

Collatis igitur invicem duobus
motibus naturalibus eju&longs;dem corporis gravis, &longs;ed non i&longs;ochro­
nis, erunt ut quadrata temporum ita & &longs;patia, atque è conver­
&longs;o ut &longs;patia inter &longs;e, ita & temporum quadrata.

Hinc cognito &longs;patio, quod à dato corpore gravi percurritur
dato tempore, &longs;tatim innote&longs;cet, quantum &longs;patij conficere va­
leat alio tempore dato, vel quanto tempore aliud datum &longs;pa­
tium.

Quæratur enim, quantum &longs;patium de&longs;cendendo percur­
ret uno horæ quadrante globus idem argillaceus, qui uno mi­
nuto &longs;ecundo Romanos pedes 15 percurrit?

Datum tempus,
&longs;cilicet horæ quadran, &longs;crupula Secunda 900 continet, cujus
numeri quadratum e&longs;t 810000. Fiat igitur ut 1 ad 810000, ita
pedes 15 ad 12150000: qui pedum numerus in milliaria Itali­
ca re&longs;olutus dat milliaria 2430, quæ uno horæ quadrante con­
ficeret.

Vici&longs;&longs;im quæratur quantum temporis idem globus in­
&longs;umeret in primo milliari percurrendo, hoc e&longs;t ped. 5000. Fiat
ut 15 ad 5000, ita 1 quadratum dati temporis, &longs;cilicet unius
&longs;crupuli &longs;ecundi, ad 333 1/3 quadratum quæ&longs;iti temporis; cujus
quadrati Radix inve&longs;tiganda e&longs;t, & demum invenitur Scrup.

&longs;ec. 18 1/4 & paulo ampliûs; nam huic tempori præcisè re&longs;pon­
dent &longs;olùm pedes (4995 15/16).

Incrementa hæc velocitatis ex concepti impetûs incremento
de&longs;umenda e&longs;&longs;e nullus dubito; &longs;ed opero&longs;um videri po&longs;&longs;et au­
ge&longs;centis impetûs cau&longs;am exponere.

Cùm junior Ari&longs;totelem
interpretarer, & primas curas huju&longs;modi rerum contemplatio­
ni impenderem, hanc excogitavi hypothe&longs;im; videlicet impe­
tûs producti diuturnitatem maximam duobus tantùm momen­
tis circum&longs;cribebam, ita ut primo momento oriretur, &longs;ecundo
æqualem &longs;ibi impetum gigneret, in quo &longs;uper&longs;tes e&longs;&longs;et, tertio
periret: gravitati autem &longs;ingulis momentis vim producendi
certum impetûs gradum &longs;ibi congruentem tribuebam.

Hinc
corpus de&longs;cendens primo momento primum habebat impetûs
gradum à gravitate productum; &longs;ecundo momento primus ille
gradus alium gradum gignebat præter eum, qui à gravitate
tunc oriebatur; quare duo novi gradus cum uno antiquo tres
gradus con&longs;tituebant.

Tertio momento primus gradus peribat,
duo &longs;ecundi gradus duos pariter producebant, & gravitas &longs;uum
tertium gradum; quare quinque gradus erant.

Quarto mo­
mento duobus &longs;ecundis gradibus pereuntibus, tres gradus ter­
tio momento producti reliqui erant, & &longs;ibi tres alios gradus
addebant, quos producebant, atque gravitas &longs;uum quartum
gradum efficiebat, ut in univer&longs;um e&longs;&longs;ent &longs;eptem gradus.

Ex
his &longs;eptem quinto momento peribant tres tertij gradus; qua­
tuor reliqui item alios quatuor adjiciebant quinto gradui à gra­
vitate profici&longs;centi, & erant novem.

Atque ita deinceps, tot
pereuntibus gradibus, quotum erat momentum uno interjecto
præcedens, & tot productis, quotum erat ip&longs;ius motûs momen­
tum.

Sic momento vige&longs;imo nono peribant gradus 27 pro­
ducti momento vige&longs;imo &longs;eptimo, remanentibus gradibus 28
productis momento vige&longs;imo octavo, à quibus totidem produ­
cebantur unâ cum gradu proprio gravitatis, hoc e&longs;t gradus 29,
& tunc erat impetûs inten&longs;io graduum 57 momento vige&longs;imo
nono.

Quemlibet verò terminum in &longs;erie numerorum impa­
rium facilè invenies, &longs;i illi duplicato demas unitatem: &longs;ic quæ­
rens octavum terminum ex denominatore termini duplicato,
&longs;cilicet bis 8, hoc e&longs;t 16, deme unitatem, & 15 e&longs;t octavus ter­
minus: &longs;ic terminus &longs;eptuage&longs;imus habetur demptâ unitate ex
140, & e&longs;t 139.

Huic hypothe&longs;i cum Phenomeno optimè conveniebat, & ea
&longs;tatuebatur impetûs inten&longs;io, quæ velocitati efficiendæ par e&longs;­
&longs;et, &longs;ervatâ incrementorum Ratione, quæ ex iteratis experimen­
tis innotuerat.

Verùm commentitia, & fabulæ proxima vide­
batur tàm brevis impetûs vita, quam non ni&longs;i duo momenta
metirentur: in iis &longs;anè, quæ vi externâ moventur, & longiùs
projiciuntur, aut in gyrum aguntur, licet extinctâ effectrice
causâ impre&longs;&longs;us impetus diutiùs permanet; quidni & impetus
&longs;ponte &longs;uâ conceptus, &longs;uæque origini cohærens aliquandiu per­
&longs;everet?

quippe qui aut eju&longs;dem, aut &longs;altem non deterioris na­
turæ cen&longs;endus e&longs;t.

Adde nimis incertum e&longs;&longs;e, an impetus im­
petum producere valeat in eodem corpore, cui ine&longs;t, quamvis
impetum in alienis corporibus percu&longs;&longs;is efficiendi vis illi conce­
datur: nam & calor, & cæteræ qualitates effectrices, quas de­
perditas &longs;ibi forma &longs;ub&longs;tantialis reparare incipit, non alios &longs;imi­
les gradus &longs;ibi addunt, licèt eos in proximo corpore efficere va­
leant.

Præterquam quod, cur illo ip&longs;o momento, quò primùm
exi&longs;tit impetus, &longs;imilem gradum non producit?

nihil &longs;cilicet il­
li dee&longs;t, nullo impedimento prohibetur, neque cau&longs;am ætate
præcedere effectum, &longs;ed origine, nece&longs;&longs;e e&longs;t.

Si autem primo
momento & oritur impetus, & impetum efficit, hic pariter &longs;uam
vim primo eodem momento exerens alium impetum producit,
& infinita graduum impetûs æqualium multitudo con&longs;urgit;
cujus ne ve&longs;tigium quidem apparere pote&longs;t, cùm in cau&longs;arum
& effectuum &longs;erie &longs;emper ab infinitate natura di&longs;cedat.

Quare impetum à gravitate de&longs;cendente productum, ex tam
expedito interitu vendicandum, & virtute &longs;e novo impetu au­
gendi &longs;poliandum, longè probabiliore conjecturâ cen&longs;ui.

Im­
petum igitur certâ quadam men&longs;urâ gravitati corporis con­
gruente, &longs;tatim ac in motum erumpere pote&longs;t, produci exi&longs;timo,
& quandiu motus per&longs;everat, permanere; eadem enim gravi­
tas, quæ primo momento illum effecit, reliquis con&longs;equentibus
momentis con&longs;ervare valet; finis, quò refertur, & cujus causâ
productus e&longs;t, adhuc obtineri pote&longs;t, videlicet motus; liberè
de&longs;cendenti corpori nullum objicitur impedimentum; nihil
ade&longs;t, quod ip&longs;ius concepti impetûs interitum exigat: ergo im­
petum à gravibus de&longs;cendentibus conceptum non perire in mo­
tu &longs;i dixerimus, &longs;imilitudinem veri nos con&longs;ecutos arbitror.

Quoniam verò gravitas inter eas cau&longs;as enumeratur, in quibus
ine&longs;t efficiendi nece&longs;&longs;itas, & quandiu opus e&longs;t juxta naturæ pro­
po&longs;itum, quantum po&longs;&longs;unt, efficiunt; &longs;ingulis momentis, qui­
bus pote&longs;t de&longs;cendere, &longs;ingulos impetûs gradus æquales priori­
bus adjicit, adeò ut, quot momenta motum metiuntur, tot gra­
dus impetûs po&longs;tremo momento inten&longs;ionem con&longs;tituant, cui
motûs velocitas re&longs;pondeat.

Velocitatum igitur incrementa
fiunt juxta naturalem numerorum progre&longs;&longs;ionem 1.2.3.4.5, &c.
nam juxta hanc eandem &longs;eriem impetûs, velocitatis cau&longs;a, au­
getur, &longs;ingulis gradibus in &longs;ingula momenta additis.

Ab omni tamen infinitatis &longs;u&longs;picione recedendum e&longs;t hìc,
ubi momentorum vocabulum u&longs;urpo, qua&longs;i infinita puncta
temporis agno&longs;cerem, & ad vim percu&longs;&longs;ionis infinitam ad&longs;truen­
dam, infinitis momentis &longs;ingulis impetûs gradum tribuerem.

Quemadmodum enim corpora punctis prorsùs individuis non
con&longs;tare &longs;uadetur multiplici argumento præ&longs;ertim ex A&longs;ympto­
tis lineis de&longs;umpto, ita motui atque tempori puncta omnibus
omnino partibus carentia nunquam concedenda cen&longs;ui.

Sed
huic verbo, cum momentum dico, &longs;ubjecta notio e&longs;t, minima
temporis particula Phy&longs;ica, quæ licèt particulas alias adhuc mi­
nores contineat &longs;ibi ordine &longs;uccedentes, ex quibus illa con&longs;ti­
tuitur, tota tamen ad primi impetûs effectionem ita requiritur,
ut juxta naturæ leges nihil effici po&longs;&longs;et motûs, ni&longs;i integra illa
temporis particula &longs;uppeteret.

Huju&longs;modi autem non indivi­
duas particulas minimas certas atque æquales in tempore, aut
motu, finito non e&longs;&longs;e ni&longs;i certo numero definitas manife&longs;tum
e&longs;t: Quapropter &longs;icut momentorum, ita & graduum impetûs
æqualium multitudo finita e&longs;t.

Verùm nemo temerè hanc momentorum multitudinem ad
calculos revocare in&longs;tituat; res enim planè incerta e&longs;t.

Utique
tardi&longs;&longs;imos reperiri & languidi&longs;&longs;imos motus aliquos novimus,
qui diu latent, nec ni&longs;i po&longs;t tempus benè con&longs;picuum demum
innote&longs;cunt: Ex quo deprehendimus in tempore aut motu, qui
&longs;en&longs;ibus percipi po&longs;&longs;it, multas numerari huju&longs;modi momento­
rum myriadas: &longs;i enim in uno aliquo motu exiguo particulæ il­
lius &longs;ibi ex ordine &longs;uccedentes re&longs;pondent motui longi&longs;&longs;imè ma­
jori (cuju&longs;modi e&longs;t cælorum motus) ex quo definitur tempus,
& in hoc plurimæ partes notabiles, & &longs;ub Phy&longs;icam men&longs;uram
cadentes numerantur, utique & in illo plurimæ particulæ om­
nem &longs;en&longs;us aciem fugientes inveniuntur.

Et quidem &longs;i cum il­
lis A&longs;tronomis philo&longs;ophemur, qui cæle&longs;tium graduum minu­
ta u&longs;que eò in &longs;exage&longs;imas partiuntur, ut demum in &longs;crupulis
Decimis con&longs;i&longs;tant, cùm Æquatoris gradus quindecim in Pri­
mo mòbili uni horæ re&longs;pondeant, &longs;atis con&longs;tat, quantus &longs;it hu­
ju&longs;modi &longs;crupulorum Decimorum numerus, in quorum fluxum
unica hora re&longs;olvatur: ac proinde in uno horæ minuto Secun-
do, hoc e&longs;t in pul&longs;u arteriæ, continentur plu&longs;quam decies mil­
lies millena millia myriadum huju&longs;modi &longs;crupulorum Decimo­
rum, quæ momenta appellari po&longs;&longs;unt.

Quapropter illud uni­
cum generatim &longs;tatuere po&longs;&longs;umus, in quolibet tempore Phy&longs;i­
cè notabili plurima e&longs;&longs;e momenta, quamvis eorum certum nu­
merum explicare nequeamus: ideóque cùm incrementa velo­
citatum men&longs;uram de&longs;umant ex momentorum numero, qui
&longs;emper unitatis additione augetur, inten&longs;io autem impetûs ha­
beat graduum numerum parem numero momentorum; quàm
difficiles explicatus habet momentorum multitudo, tam ob&longs;cu­
ra e&longs;t impetûs inten&longs;io; &longs;i minutam &longs;ubtilitatem per&longs;equamur.

Sed &longs;i datum tempus in aliquot particulas no&longs;tro arbitratu
di&longs;tinguamus, quo plures fuerint huju&longs;modi particulæ, eò pro­
piùs accedemus ad id, quod experimentis deprehen&longs;um e&longs;t; vi­
delicet, etiam &longs;i &longs;patia in motu decur&longs;a juxta &longs;eriem naturalem
numerorum augeantur in motu, demum eorum collectiones in­
cipiendo à quiete habere inter &longs;e duplicatam Rationem tempo­
rum inveniemus.

Comparatis igitur invicem motibus alicujus corporis gravis
de&longs;cendentis, cujus motus unus jam innotuerit, quantum &longs;cili­
cet &longs;patij dato tempore confecerit, innote&longs;cet, quantus futurus
&longs;it alio tempore motus, &longs;i fiant ut quadrata datorum temporum,
ita & &longs;patia; vel quanto tempore percurrendum &longs;it &longs;patium de­
finitum, &longs;i fiant ut Radices quadratæ datorum &longs;patiorum, ita &
tempora.

Quia nimirum po&longs;ita illa incrementa impetûs, & ve­
locitatum, atque &longs;patiorum juxta &longs;eriem naturalem numero­
rum ab unitate incipientem con&longs;tituunt collectiones habentes
inter &longs;e proximè Rationem duplicatam temporum.

Habemus
experimento globum, argillaceum unciarum octo percurrere
uno minuto Secundo horæ pedes 15, & duobus Secundis pe­
des 60, hoc e&longs;t &longs;patium quadruplum, & quia tempora &longs;unt ut 1
ad 2, &longs;patia &longs;unt ut quadrata, &longs;cilicet ut 1 ad 4. Ponamus in uno
Secundo e&longs;&longs;e momenta 10000; &longs;unt igitur ultimo momento
10000 gradus velocitatis &longs;imiles & æquales primo gradui primi
momenti, & &longs;patium ultimo hoc momento decur&longs;um, ad &longs;pa­
tium primi momenti e&longs;t ut 10000 ad 1. Coge igitur in &longs;um­
mam omnia &longs;patia incipiendo ab unitate u&longs;que ad 10000, vi­
delicet ultimi termini dimidiato quadrato adde eju&longs;dem ultimi
termini &longs;emi&longs;&longs;em, & prodibit omnium &longs;patiorum &longs;umma.

Ultimi
termini 10000 quadratum e&longs;t 100000000, cui adde ip&longs;um ul­
timum terminum; & hujus &longs;ummæ medietas 50005000 e&longs;t
&longs;umma minimorum &longs;patiorum, quibus conflantur pedes 15. In
duobus Secundis erunt momenta 20000, & &longs;imiliter invenitur
&longs;umma 200010000 minimorum &longs;patiorum, quibus con&longs;tant
pedes 60. Non &longs;unt quidem duæ huju&longs;modi &longs;ummæ hìc
inventæ 50005000 & 200010000, omnino ut 1 ad 4, &longs;ed ut 1
ad (3 49995/50005): verùm tantula differentia (10/50005) quid officit allato ex­
perimento?
an potuit ob&longs;ervari?

Si 4. &longs;unt pedes 60, quid
&longs;unt (3 49995/50005)? utique pedes (59 49855/50005); dee&longs;t igitur pedis particula
(150/50005), hoc e&longs;t unciæ qua&longs;i pars vige&longs;ima &longs;eptima.

Quis autem
tam minutæ &longs;ubtilitati locus &longs;it in ob&longs;ervando motu?

Ut autem per&longs;picuè appareat hanc hypothe&longs;im incrementi
juxta &longs;eriem naturalem numerorum con&longs;entire cum experi­
mentis, & &longs;patia &longs;e habere ut quadrata temporum, &longs;tatuamus
eadem &longs;patia, ut primum &longs;it ad &longs;ecundum in Ratione 50005000
ad 200010000. Radix primi &longs;patij e&longs;t (7071 5959/14142), Radix autem
&longs;ecundi &longs;patij e&longs;t (14142 6918/14142); quæ &longs;unt ut 1 ad 2, &longs;i fractiones
contemnantur; nec repugnat experimentum; nam tantula
differentia temporum, ne &longs;it Ratio præcisè dupla, di&longs;cerni
non potuit: quarum enim partium (7071 5959/14142) e&longs;t unum minu­
tum Secundum horæ, dee&longs;t unius partis (5000/14142), ut &longs;int duo mi­
nuta Secunda, hoc e&longs;t unius pulsûs alteriæ pars una vicies mil­
le&longs;ima de&longs;ideratur, ut &longs;int planè duo Secunda.

Quære argu­
menta, &longs;i qua potes; an experimento revinces e&longs;&longs;e plani&longs;&longs;imè
duo minuta Secunda, nec vel unicum momentum defui&longs;&longs;e?

Hoc idem, quod exempli causâ in Ratione duplâ temporum
& quadruplâ &longs;patiorum explicatum e&longs;t, in cæteris pariter de­
prehendes.

Fac enim e&longs;&longs;e tempus quadruplum, hoc e&longs;t Secun­
dorum 4, hoc e&longs;t minimorum temporis 40000. Tota collectio
&longs;patiorum erit 800020000. Quare 50005000 ad 800020000
e&longs;t ut 1 ad (15 49925/50005), qua&longs;i ut 1 ad 16; e&longs;t autem defectus (60/50005).
Spatium igitur uno Secundo decur&longs;um cum &longs;it ped. 15, qua­
tuor Secundis erit ped. 240 minùs una ferè &longs;exage&longs;ima nona
particulâ unciæ.

Vici&longs;&longs;im ut tempora invenias in &longs;ubduplicatâ
Ratione &longs;patiorum, quære illorum tanquam quadratorum Ra­
dices; & primi quidem Radix e&longs;t, ut priùs fuit inventa
(7071 5959/14142), &longs;ecundi Radix e&longs;t (28284 8836/14142), quarum Ratio e&longs;t
quadrupla, &longs;i fractiones &longs;pernantur; at aliquid dee&longs;t, ut &longs;int
integra quatuor Secunda minuta horæ; qui defectus demum
vix major e&longs;t quàm (1/6667) unius pulsûs arteriæ.

Cùm itaque con&longs;tituta hypothe&longs;is incrementi &longs;patiorum,
velocitatis, atque impetûs juxta &longs;eriem naturalem numerorum
&longs;it naturæ con&longs;entanea, nequè Phy&longs;icè repugnet experimentis,
non debemus e&longs;&longs;e &longs;olliciti, ut aliam quæramus hypothe&longs;im ad
&longs;tatuenda incrementa exqui&longs;itè juxta numeros impares; cùm
maximè in aquâ ob majorem re&longs;i&longs;tentiam, quam in illâ divi­
denda inveniunt corpora gravia de&longs;cendentia, non exactè &longs;er­
vari eandem Rationem incrementorum, quæ in aëre apparet,
experimenta iterata declarent, quamvis ad illam Rationem
proximè accedant, ut apud Ricciolium tom.

1. Almag. lib.
9.
&longs;ect.4. cap.
16. n.
16. varia experimenta afferentem legi pote&longs;t.

Præterquam quod &longs;i tam in aëre quàm in aquâ adhibeantur in
experimentum corpora &longs;ecundùm gravitatem &longs;pecificam ab il­
lis minimum di&longs;crepantia, &longs;tatim apparebit non &longs;ervari illam
temporum atque &longs;patiorum Analogiam: id quod pariter ob&longs;er­
vabitur, &longs;i in diver&longs;is liquoribus eadem gravia corpora dimit­
tantur: varia &longs;cilicet e&longs;t re&longs;i&longs;tentia; hæc autem latet, quando
grave dimi&longs;&longs;um valde differt à gravitate, aut levitate medij.

His ita con&longs;titutis, percu&longs;&longs;ionis vires, quatenus ex velocita­
te oriuntur, proximè definire poterimus, &longs;i innote&longs;cant &longs;patia,
per quæ idem corpus grave liberè de&longs;cendit; nam hinc inno­
te&longs;cet Ratio inten&longs;ionum impetûs ultimo de&longs;censûs momento,
quo contingit percu&longs;&longs;io.

E&longs;t &longs;iquidem numerus graduum im­
petus in motu naturali libero concepti par numero momento­
rum motûs; at momenta, quibus con&longs;tant tempora motuum
inæqualium, &longs;unt in Ratione &longs;ubduplicatâ Rationis &longs;patiorum:
igitur &longs;icut Radices quadratæ &longs;patiorum indicant Rationem tem­
porum, ita pariter eædem indicant Rationem inten&longs;ionum im­
petûs.

Quare &longs;i alicujus gravis ex datâ altitudine cadentis per­
cu&longs;&longs;io manife&longs;ta fuerit, facilè inferemus, quanta proximè &longs;it
futura eju&longs;dem percu&longs;&longs;io ex majori, aut minori altitudine, &longs;i fiat
ut Radix datæ altitudinis prioris ad Radicem po&longs;terioris altitu­
dinis, ita nota percu&longs;&longs;io ad quæ&longs;itam percu&longs;&longs;ionem.

Neque hìc conabor dicta confirmare experimentis tùm à
Ricciolio loc.
cit.

cap.16. n.12, tùm à Mer&longs;enno tom.3. in Re­
flexionibus Phy&longs;ico-Mathemat. cap.
8. allatis, ex quibus proxi.
mé infertur hæc Ratio &longs;ubduplicata &longs;patiorum.

Nam cùm adhi­
bita &longs;it libra, ut in alteram lancem cadens pondus ex diver&longs;is
altitudinibus dimi&longs;&longs;um elevaret pondera inæqualia oppo&longs;itæ
lanci impo&longs;ita, res e&longs;t anceps & incetta.

Quandoquidem, ut
ob&longs;ervavi jam tum ab anno 54 labentis &longs;æculi &longs;criptis Romæ de
hoc eodem argumento publicè traditis, & funiculi, ex quibus
lanx percu&longs;&longs;a pendet, di&longs;trahuntur, & libræ jugum flectitur,
immò & lanx ip&longs;a ictum cadentis ponderis excipiens flexilis
e&longs;t; ac propterea impetûs vim retundunt, cùm maximè vi
ela&longs;ticâ &longs;e re&longs;tituentes conantur &longs;ur&longs;um.

Præterquam quod, &longs;i
pondus cadens non exactè incidat in lancis centrum re&longs;pon­
dens extremitati jugi, plurimum intere&longs;t ad varianda momen­
ta, prout libræ brachium aut decurtatum aut productum intel­
ligitur.

Quò autem majus e&longs;t pondus in oppo&longs;itâ lance attollen­
dum ex vi depre&longs;&longs;ionis lancis percu&longs;&longs;æ, magis re&longs;i&longs;tit, ac proin­
de locus e&longs;t flexioni majori ip&longs;ius libræ, aut funiculorum
di&longs;tractioni, præ&longs;ertim &longs;i lanx fuerit concava, & cadens pon­
dus illam tangens prolabatur in depre&longs;&longs;iorem lancis locum.

Ex
quo accidit, ut docuit experientia, aucto pondere elevando non
&longs;atis e&longs;&longs;e dimittere pondus cadens ex altitudine, quæ &longs;it ad prio­
rem altitudinem ut quadratum ponderis majoris ad quadratum
ponderis minoris initio elevati; percu&longs;&longs;io enim contingit in lan­
ce, cujus re&longs;i&longs;tentiam ad hoc, ut vi ponderis cadentis deprima­
tur, metitur re&longs;i&longs;tentia ponderis elevandi in oppo&longs;itâ lance: at
hæc &longs;i fuerit major quàm re&longs;i&longs;tentia jugi, aut lancis, ne flecta­
tur, aut funiculorum ne di&longs;trahantur, in hac flexione aut
di&longs;tractione in&longs;umitur vis percu&longs;&longs;ionis, quin oppo&longs;ita lanx attol­
latur.

Quapropter ex altitudine adhuc majori dimittendum e&longs;t
pondus cadens; nam adhuc majore impetu concepto tam validè
percutiet lancem, ut re&longs;i&longs;tentia jugi & lancis ad flexionem ul­
teriorem, atque funiculorum ad longiorem di&longs;tractionem, ma­
jor &longs;it quàm re&longs;i&longs;tentia ponderis oppo&longs;itæ lancis: atque adeò
lanx percu&longs;&longs;a non deprimetur &longs;olùm, quantum funiculorum
di&longs;tractio & ip&longs;a flexio permittit, &longs;ed adhuc ulteriùs; atque op­
po&longs;ita lanx attolletur, quatenus impetûs vires excedunt oppo­
&longs;itæ gravitatis re&longs;i&longs;tentiam.

Ex his, quæ de Percu&longs;&longs;ionibus corporum gravium naturali­
