flexo imprimere, atque in eo diminuti ex re&longs;i&longs;tentiâ impetûs
jacturam, aliquâ &longs;altem ex parte, re&longs;arcire.

Hinc, in rem præ­
&longs;entem di&longs;tinguere oportet, quid inter Compre&longs;&longs;ionem & De­
pre&longs;&longs;ionem inter&longs;it: quæ enim deprimuntur, ut plumbum, cera,
argilla, non re&longs;iliunt &longs;ecundùm &longs;uperficiem, ut pri&longs;tinam figu­
ram induant; ideóque quando huju&longs;modi corpora in aliud im­
pinguntur, vel aliud in illa impingitur, valdè debilitatur re­
flexio, &longs;i modò aliqua contingere pote&longs;t.

Quæ verò compri­
muntur, externâ vi deficiente &longs;e in pri&longs;tinam figuram ab&longs;que
cunctatione re&longs;tituunt concepto novo impetu.

Exemplum ex
folle pugillatorio peti pote&longs;t, ut res in apertum deducatur.

Ca­
dens in &longs;ubjectum pavimentum follis lu&longs;orius, ritè inflatus, im­
peditur, ne ulteriùs procedat; &longs;ed quia inclu&longs;i aëris particulæ
eæ &longs;unt, quæ per vim con&longs;tipari ampliùs po&longs;&longs;int, ideò ex illis
anteriores hinc urgentur à po&longs;terioribus, quæ vi acqui&longs;iti im­
petûs inchoatum iter pro&longs;equuntur, hinc tellure re&longs;i&longs;tente,
hinc alutâ continente, inter angu&longs;tias deprehen&longs;æ comprimun­
tur: id quod cùm motum exigat, certam aliquam brevi&longs;&longs;imi
temporis men&longs;uram requirit, quo fluente, terra à folle tangi­
tur, motú&longs;que aliquatenus impeditur (nunquam tamen ita, ut
ce&longs;&longs;et omnino motus illarum &longs;altem partium, à quibus anterio­
res urgentur ac premuntur) & quò diutiùs huju&longs;modi com­
pre&longs;&longs;io durat, eò magis impeditur motus totius follis, atque adeò
plus impetûs deperditur.

Sed quoniam &longs;tatus ille majoris com­
pre&longs;&longs;ionis aëri intrà follem con&longs;tipato contra naturam accidit,
ubi primùm, debilitato impetu urgente, re&longs;tituere &longs;e pote&longs;t
aër, impetum &longs;ibi imprimit, quo moveatur ad ampliorem lo­
cum occupandum, &longs;i facta fuerit conden&longs;atio, vel certè ad par­
tes in pri&longs;tino & naturali &longs;tatu con&longs;tituendas (quemadmodum
alutæ contingit, cujus partes aliæ compre&longs;&longs;æ, aliæ di&longs;tractæ &longs;e­
&longs;e re&longs;tituunt) cúmque id præ&longs;tare nequeat motu ad terram di­
recto, quippe quæ re&longs;i&longs;tit, in oppo&longs;itam partem motum dirigit;
novóque hoc impetu &longs;i non æquatur, qui re&longs;i&longs;tentiâ diminutus
fuerat, &longs;altem incrementi alicujus compen&longs;atione lenitur in­
commodum detrimenti, & major fit motus, quàm pro Ratione
re&longs;idui impetûs ante percu&longs;&longs;ionem & compre&longs;&longs;ionem concepti.

Hæc eadem proportione dicenda &longs;unt, quando non corpus
percutiens, ut follis in terram decidens, &longs;ed percu&longs;&longs;um com­
primitur aut di&longs;trahitur, & virtute ela&longs;ticâ &longs;e re&longs;tituit; impe­
tum enim concipiens, quo ami&longs;&longs;am figuram recuperet, etiam
percutienti impetum imprimit, quo repellitur.

Sic in &longs;phæ­
ri&longs;terio immi&longs;&longs;æ pilæ &longs;i reticulum ex contortis animalium in­
te&longs;tinis in plagas di&longs;tinctum objeceris, validiùs reflectitur pila,
quàm objecto batillo ligneo, intenti enim nervi illi, ex impetu
pilæ inflexi, validi&longs;&longs;imè &longs;e re&longs;tituunt, id quod ligno non con­
tingit, quippe quod vix ela&longs;ticam hanc virtutem exercet, &longs;i ta­
men à pilâ impacta quicquam inflexionis recipit, quæ compre&longs;­
&longs;io &longs;it potiùs, quàm depre&longs;&longs;io.

Quæ &longs;cilicet corpora eam par­
tium texturam habent, ut minùs ferant &longs;e à priore po&longs;itione &
figurâ dimoveri, illa &longs;e&longs;e majore impetu re&longs;tituunt.

Ex his con&longs;tat, cur partium depre&longs;&longs;io officiat reflexioni cor­
poris percutientis: quia nimirum à po&longs;terioribus illius partibus
urgentur anteriores contactui proximæ, quæ interim vel quie&longs;­
cunt, vel multò tardiùs moventur, vel ad latus &longs;ecedunt, &
idcircò vel totum, vel ferè totum, &longs;uum impetum deperdunt:
po&longs;teriores verò dum urgent ac premunt, moventur quidem,
&longs;ed reperiunt re&longs;i&longs;tentiam &longs;ub&longs;identium partium anteriorum,
atque adeò in illis pariter minuitur impetus; &longs;æpiú&longs;que tanta fit
impetûs diminutio, ut, depre&longs;&longs;ione ab&longs;olutâ, partes illæ po&longs;te­
riores reliquum non habeant tantum impetûs, qui vincere va­
leat gravitatem, & reflexionem efficere; neque enim aliquid
ami&longs;&longs;i impetûs compen&longs;atur ab impetu novo partium &longs;e re&longs;ti­
tuentium, quemadmodum fieri diximus in compre&longs;&longs;ione.

Quan­
do autem depre&longs;&longs;io partium accidit corpori, ad quod alliditur
corpus percutiens, ut cùm in arenam &longs;iccam ac pulverulentam,
aut in limo&longs;am terram decidit globus, tunc multum impetûs
deperditur, ut dictum e&longs;t &longs;uperiùs de ictu, qui eò infirmior e&longs;t,
quò mollius e&longs;t corpus percu&longs;&longs;um; reflexio autem eò major e&longs;t,
quò validiore ictu percutitur corpus reflectens.

Quòd &longs;i
utrumque corpus, tam percutiens, quàm percu&longs;&longs;um, patiatur
compre&longs;&longs;ionem aut depre&longs;&longs;ionem, aut partium attritum, tunc
multò minor e&longs;t reflexio, quia dum invicem cedunt, aliquo
tempore durat re&longs;i&longs;tentia, multóque magis minuitur impetus.

id quod adhuc magis contingit, &longs;i &longs;e invicem conterant, &
particulæ aliquæ majores re&longs;iliant.

Quapropter cum incerta &longs;emper, & varia &longs;it complexio hu­
ju&longs;modi re&longs;i&longs;tentiarum & ce&longs;&longs;ionum, juxta variam corporum
temperationem; ut reflexionis certæ regulæ &longs;tatuantur, &longs;emo­
tis iis, quæ percu&longs;&longs;ionis accidunt, con&longs;ideranda & a&longs;&longs;umenda
e&longs;t re&longs;i&longs;tentia ab&longs;que ullâ ce&longs;&longs;ione, perinde atque &longs;i duri&longs;&longs;imo­
rum corporum colli&longs;io fieret.

Cum itaque in reflexione, corporis duri in aliud decidentis,
aut impacti, motus ad novam lineam dirigatur, nova hæc di­
rectio oritur ex lineâ directionis prioris motûs quatenus compa­
ratâ cum plano reflectente, videlicet quatenus ad illud incli­
natur, & cum eo angulum con&longs;tituit in puncto contactûs.

Quando autem &longs;uperficies corporis reflectentis eo loco, ubi
percutitur, plana non e&longs;t, &longs;ed convexa (&longs;imile quid dicendum,
&longs;i cava fuerit) &longs;ivè &longs;phærica &longs;it, &longs;ivè Elliptica, &longs;ivè Conica, re­
verâ nullum ibi e&longs;t planum reflectens (ni&longs;i fortè huju&longs;modi
convexas &longs;uperficies ex plurimis planis minimis con&longs;titui fin­
gas, quemadmodum circuli peripheriam ex infinitis lineolis
rectis, quarum rectitudo &longs;en&longs;um omnem fugiat, componi opi­
nantur aliqui) &longs;ed communiter mente concipiunt planum,
quod in puncto percu&longs;&longs;ionis tangeret &longs;uperficiem con­
vexam; & ex illo angulos tùm Incidentiæ, tùm Reflexionis
definiunt.

Porrò planum reflectens (quod quidem &longs;pectat ad novam
directionem motûs &longs;tatuendam corpori percutienti, quem po­
namus e&longs;&longs;e globum) ita &longs;e habere videtur, ac &longs;i in globum
quie&longs;centem motu parallelo impingeretur ip&longs;um planum tanto
impetu, quanto impetu fertur globus adversùs planum: &longs;i enim
ex duobus colli&longs;is alterum quie&longs;cit, alterum movetur, ad ra­
tionem ictûs nil refert, utrum illorum quie&longs;cat, aut moveatur,
modò cætera omnia paria fuerint; ad rationem verò reflexio­
nis, quà reflexio e&longs;t, attenditur poti&longs;&longs;imum ordinatio novæ li­
neæ motûs, quæ ex ob&longs;taculi po&longs;itione de&longs;umitur, adeò ut no­
va linea directionis, quatenus à plano reflectente pendet, & à
centro gravitatis de&longs;cendentis, aut à centro Impetûs corpo­
ris impacti, certâ Ratione re&longs;piciat priorem lineam directio­
nis.

Eo igitur ip&longs;o quod concipimus planum reflectens mo­
veri motu parallelo, hoc e&longs;t &longs;ervatâ po&longs;itione priori po&longs;i­
tioni parallelâ, adversùs globum quie&longs;centem, manife&longs;tum
e&longs;t novam determinationem ex illo ortam e&longs;&longs;e versùs lineam
plano perpendicularem, ex puncto contactûs erectam: nam
impetus, qui ex illo plani motu imprimeretur globo
quie&longs;centi, hunc deferret per lineam jungentem punctum
contactûs cum centro globi: hæc autem linea ex centro
&longs;phæræ ducta ad punctum contactûs plani e&longs;t ip&longs;i plano per­
pendicularis, ut ex Sphæricis con&longs;tat.

Quamvis igitur res
contrario modo &longs;e habeat, &longs;cilicet planum quie&longs;cat, & glo­
bus moveatur, directio tamen, quatenus orta ex re&longs;i&longs;tentiâ
plani, eodem modo &longs;e habet, & e&longs;t versùs perpendicula­
rem ex puncto contactûs.

Sed quia cum impetu globi ut
plurimùm manet adhuc prior directio, ex his duabus mo­
tuum ordinationibus oritur tertia mixta; ita ut neque ad
perpendiculum reflectatur, ni&longs;i incidentiæ linea perpendi­
cularis fuerit, neque recta in&longs;titutum iter pro&longs;equatur.

Quoniam igitur ex puncto contactûs innumeræ lineæ exi­
re po&longs;&longs;unt cùm variâ inclinatione ad planum reflectens,
nec ulla peculiaris e&longs;t cau&longs;a, cur ad hos potiùs, quàm ad
illos angulos, reflectatur corpus percutiens, qui majores
&longs;int aut minores angulo incidentiæ, quem linea directio­
nis motûs con&longs;tituit cum eodem plano reflectente; reli­
quum e&longs;t, ut angulo incidentiæ æqualis &longs;it angulus refle­
xionis; hæc &longs;iquidem linea ad angulum priori æqualem re­
flexa unica e&longs;t, quæ inter innumeras alias lineas magis aut
minùs inclinatas potiori quodam jure exigitur à naturâ
prioris directionis leges, quoad fieri pote&longs;t, retinente.

Non e&longs;t autem nece&longs;&longs;e tyronem monere, duas lineas, di­
rectam & reflexam in puncto reflexionis concurrentes e&longs;&longs;e
in uno & eodem plano, ut con&longs;tat ex.

2. lib.
11. ab hoc
autem plano &longs;ecari planum reflectens, ac proinde ad lineam,
quæ e&longs;t duorum planorum communis &longs;ectio, referendam e&longs;&longs;e
linearum illarum inclinationem.

Quare &longs;it plani reflectentis, & plani, in quo fit motus,
communis &longs;ectio linea AB, & &longs;uper planum ad rectos angulos
cadat linea directionis prioris DC,
per quam movetur globus tanto
impetu, ut ni&longs;i planum ob&longs;taret,
ulteriùs procederet rectà versùs E:
Verùm quoniam à plano ob&longs;i&longs;ten­
te repellitur per lineam perpendi­
cularem CD, nova hæc determi­
natio ad motum e&longs;t omninò &
adæquatè oppo&longs;ita priori directioni DC, ideóque ictus e&longs;t va­
lidi&longs;&longs;imus propter maximam re&longs;i&longs;tentiam.

Hinc quia ex re­
&longs;i&longs;tentiâ oritur reflexio, maxima e&longs;t reflexio, quæ fit per li­
neam perpendicularem, nihil enim remanet de priori directio­
ne: in hoc quippe comparantur invicem reflexiones, ut illa
major dicatur, in qua nova motûs ordinatio magis minuit prio­
rem directionem, ut &longs;cilicet minùs pergat ad eam partem, ad
quam ferebatur motu directo corpus percutiens.

In reflexione
autem perpendiculari ita tollitur prior directio, ut nullo pacto
globus, qui ex D per DC movebatur, ampliùs versùs E ten­
dat.

Cùm ergo nova ordinatio &longs;it per perpendicularem CD
ad angulos rectos, manife&longs;tò con&longs;tat, angulum reflexionis e&longs;&longs;e
æqualem angulo incidentiæ; nam omnes anguli recti &longs;unt
æquales.

At moveatur corpus per lineam FC, & fiat incidentiæ an­
gulus FCB acutus: ni&longs;i planum re&longs;i&longs;teret, progrederetur cor­
pus juxta eandem directionem ultra C in G; quo motu rece­
dens à puncto C partim tenderet à C versùs A, partim à C ver­
sùs E, ita ut à lineâ CA di&longs;taret intervallo AG, à lineâ au­
tem CE intervallo EG; e&longs;&longs;et enim directio CG æquivalens
directioni mixtæ ex CA, & CE.

Verùm nova motûs ordina­
tio à plano reflectente, quatenus opponitur ulteriori motui, e&longs;t
per lineam perpendicularem CD; hæc autem priori directio­
ni FCG adver&longs;atur &longs;olùm, prout æquivalet Directioni CE
(nam quatenus æquivalet directioni CA, non illi opponitur;
globo &longs;cilicet, qui per CA moveretur, planum non re&longs;i&longs;teret,
nec illum reflecteret) ac propterea dat oppo&longs;itam directionem
CD, cujus longitudinem ponamus æqualem ip&longs;i CE.

Manen­
te igitur directione per CA, & directione CE mutatâ in CD,
e&longs;t ex utrâque mixta directio CH, &longs;ecundùm quam movetur
corpus reflexum.

Quoniam itaque directionum &longs;ingularum
men&longs;uræ &longs;unt CA, & CE, per A ducatur parallela ip&longs;i DE; &
per E, atque per D, ducantur EG & DH ip&longs;i CA parallelæ.

E&longs;t ergo rectangulum HE; & quia CD a&longs;&longs;umpta e&longs;t æqualis
ip&longs;i CE, etiam AH & AG &longs;unt illis æquales.

Quapropter cum in
triangulis CAH, CAG rectangulis, latera AC & AG æqualia
&longs;int lateribus AC & AH, atque angulus comprehen&longs;us ad A
&longs;it rectus, per 4. lib.
1. angulus ACH (qui e&longs;t angulus Re­
flexionis) e&longs;t æqualis angulo ACG: at angulo ACG æqualis
e&longs;t ad verticem angulus incidentiæ FCB, per 15. lib.
1: ergo
angulo FCB incidentiæ æqualis e&longs;t ACH angulus re­
flexionis.

Eâdem methodo, &longs;i angulus incidentiæ fuerit ICB, often­
demus angulum reflexionis KCA e&longs;&longs;e illi æqualem; quando­
quidem directio CM mutatur in CN, & manet directio CA; ac
propterea directio mixta ex CN, & CA, e&longs;t CK.

Atque ita de
cæteris.

Ex quibus ob&longs;ervabis, quò acutior fuerit angulus inciden­
tiæ, in reflexione ita mi&longs;ceri novam directionem cum anti­
quâ, ut magis prævaleat antiqua; nova &longs;iquidem ad anti­
quam, &longs;ecundùm id, quod de illâ remanet, &longs;e habet ut
Sinus Rectus anguli incidentiæ ad Sinum Complementi.

Nam &longs;i incidentiæ angulus &longs;it FCB, & illi æqualis
HCA, nova directio CD, hoc e&longs;t AH ad antiquæ
re&longs;iduum CA, &longs;e habet ut HA ad AC: Sin autem in­
cidentiæ angulus fuerit ICB, hoc e&longs;t illi æqualis angu­
lus reflexionis KCA, nova directio ad id, quod de anti­
quâ remanet, e&longs;t ut KA ad CA.

E&longs;t autem major Ratio
AC ad AK minorem, quàm eju&longs;dem AC ad AH majo­
rem per 8. lib.
5. Quare quandiu angulus incidentiæ mi­
nor e&longs;t &longs;emirecto, majus e&longs;t re&longs;iduum antiquæ directionis
(attentè ob&longs;erva me de &longs;olâ directione loqui) quâm nova
ordinatio: ubi fuerit angulus &longs;emirectus, &longs;unt æquales;
&longs;i angulus incidentiæ fuerit &longs;emirecto major, nova ordina­
tio major e&longs;t eo, quod remanet de antiquâ directione: ubi
demum fuerit angulus rectus in perpendiculari inciden­
tiâ, nova directio ad priorem &longs;e habet ut Radius ad
nihil, motus enim reflexus nihil retinet de priori di­
rectione.

Antè tamen quàm in hac di&longs;putatione procedamus, mentis
oculos tanti&longs;per in globum
C, à quo percutitur planum
AB, convertamus; hacte­
nus enim univer&longs;a contem­
platio in meris lineis ver&longs;a­
ta e&longs;t.

Et quidem &longs;i directio­
nis linea &longs;it RS perpendi­
cularis tran&longs;iens per globi
centrum C, & punctum
contactûs S, nulla e&longs;&longs;e po­
te&longs;t difficultas, quin per
eandem lineam SR re&longs;iliat
ad angulos rectos.

Sed &longs;i in
planum obliquè incidat li­
nea directionis globi per
centrum C deducta, & &longs;it MN; certum e&longs;t in plano AB
punctum N, in quod directionis linea MC producta incurrit,
non e&longs;&longs;e punctum contactûs; alioquin linea à globi centro
ducta ad punctum contactûs, caderet ad angulos inæquales ex
hypothe&longs;i, cum tamen angulos rectos con&longs;tituere demon&longs;tretur
in Sphæricis.

E&longs;t igitur contactus in puncto S, extra lineam
directionis centri, ideóque angulus reflexionis non e&longs;t BNQ
æqualis angulo ANM.

Propterea in globo attendendum e&longs;t
punctum S, à quo reipsâ percutitur planum; & &longs;icuti in circu­
lo globum bifariam dividente punctum I delatum e&longs;t per li­
neam MI, ita punctum S per lineam OS ip&longs;i MI parallelam
(pono hìc globum non rotari dum movetur, &longs;ed recto itinere
deduci) venit ad contactum & percu&longs;&longs;ionem plani.

Cum igi­
tur OS & MN &longs;int parallelæ, anguli OSA, & MNA &longs;unt
æquales: & &longs;icuti &longs;i punctum I &longs;olitarium e&longs;&longs;et, atque juxta
&longs;uam directionem veniret in N, reflecteretur per NQ, ut re­
flexionis angulus QNB e&longs;&longs;et æqualis angulo Incidentiæ
MNA; ita punctum S globi reflectitur per SP, & angulus
reflexionis PSB æqualis e&longs;t incidentiæ angulo OSA; ac pro­
inde anguli PSB, & QNB &longs;unt æquales inter &longs;e.

Centrum
igitur C cùm in directione MN haberet directionem mixtam
ex directione CS versùs planum, & directione SB, eum im­
pediatur à globi &longs;oliditate ne ad planum ulteriùs accedat, mu­
tatâ directione CS in CR, atque retentâ priore directione SB,
habet directionem mixtam CH omnino &longs;imilem directioni
puncti S; atque propterea CH e&longs;t parallela ip&longs;i SP.

Quod &longs;i
globus rotari intelligatur, loco linearum, de quibus hactenus
fuit &longs;ermo, concipe plana, in quibus puncta illa &longs;uas periodos
de&longs;criberent in motu rotationis, & plana illa e&longs;&longs;ent ad planum
reflectens &longs;imiliter inclinata, ut de lineis dictum e&longs;t.

In cæteris verò corporibus non rotundis idem de eorum re­
flexione dicendum e&longs;t, &longs;ervatâ analogiâ, quantum ferre pote&longs;t
anomala eorum figura, & di&longs;par partium po&longs;itio circa centrum
gravitatis aut magnitudinis: in multis enim huju&longs;modi æqua­
litas angulorum incidentiæ & reflexionis non exactè &longs;ervatur.

Sic ha&longs;tam &longs;i obliquè contorqueas in rupem, non modò inæ­
qualitatem angulorum deprehendes, &longs;ed vix reflexionem fieri
admittes; quia videlicet extremo ha&longs;tæ calce rupem tangente,
reliquæ partes habentes circa centrum gravitatis inæqualia mo­
menta, valdè turbant motum: &longs;olùm autem quando ha&longs;ta in
planum impingitur, aut cadit, ad perpendiculum, &longs;ervata re­
flexionis regulâ ad angulos rectos re&longs;ilit; quia tunc partes om­
nes circa centrum gravitatis paria habent momenta.

Hæc au­
tem momentorum diver&longs;itas in globo non reperitur, ni&longs;i fortè
aut deficiat à perfectâ rotunditate, aut centrum magnitudinis
non &longs;it idem cum centro gravitatis, adeò ut linea punctum
contactûs cum centro gravitatis, jungens non &longs;it plano re­
flectenti perpendicularis; tunc enim perturbaretur globi
reflexio.

Ex dictis &longs;atis apertè con&longs;tat reflexionem non ex impetu de­
&longs;umendam e&longs;&longs;e, &longs;ed ex directione motus, cui opponitur corpus
reflectens, juxta hu us po&longs;itionem perpendicularem aut obli­
quam: multus enim impetus aliquando officere pote&longs;t æquali­
tati angulorum, &longs;i ex colli&longs;ione corporis impacti cum corpore
reflectente, aut alterutrum, aut utrumque notabiliter cedat,
adeò ut non contingat &longs;incera reflexio.

Cæterùm cum &longs;emper
in reflexione &longs;it nova directio priori directioni oppo&longs;ita, ali­
quid impetûs perit pro Ratione oppo&longs;itionis.

Ex quo fit in re-
flexione ad angulos magis acutos impetum minori decremento
minui, quia nova directio minùs opponitur antiquæ, & minùs
impeditur motus; idcirco globus ad angulum valde acutum re­
flexus, &longs;i offendat in motu reflexo aliquem obicem, multò va­
lidiùs illum percutit, quàm &longs;i ad angulum minùs acutum re­
flecteretur, quia, cæteris paribus, majore impetu &longs;uper&longs;tite
ictum infligit.

Quapropter obvium e&longs;t cuique rationem reddere omnium,
quæ in pilæ ludo contingunt circa &longs;altus in pavimento, in quod
pila emi&longs;&longs;a decidit, & reflexiones ad parietem, in quem illa
impingitur.
Duo tamen poti&longs;&longs;imùm ob&longs;ervare placet.

Primùm,
quando pila cadit obliqua in pavimentum non procul à pariete,
&longs;æpè fit duplex reflexio, altera &longs;cilicet à pavimento, altera à
pariete: ex quo fit, ut pila aliquando longè altiorem &longs;altum
edat, &longs;i multum habeat impetus; quia videlicet à pavimento
re&longs;iliens, &longs;i in parietem non incurreret, lineam curvam in re­
flexione de&longs;cribens vi &longs;uæ gravitatis impetum extrin&longs;ecùs im­
pre&longs;&longs;um temperantis, citiùs deprimeretur, & magis à recto tra­
mite deor&longs;um deflecteret: at quia proximus ponitur e&longs;&longs;e paries,
linea primò reflexa nondum differt notabiliter à lineâ rectâ;
atque proinde in &longs;ecundâ reflexione altiùs pila a&longs;&longs;urgit, quàm
à pavimento di&longs;taret apex lineæ curvæ, quæ ex primâ reflexio­
ne de&longs;criberetur; nam directio illa &longs;ecunda magis elevata &longs;upra
horizontem minùs permittit pilam à rectâ lineâ declinare; ut
in bali&longs;tarum & bombardarum globis cum majori elevatione
emi&longs;&longs;is con&longs;tat.

Deinde quando reticulis luditur, non rarò re­
ticulum movetur in plano aliquo horizontali, aut valde incli­
nato (nos Itali dicimus Tagliare, ò Trinciare una palla) ita ut,
dum pilam rectâ expellit, illi etiam motum quendam imprimat,
quo ip&longs;a circa &longs;uum centrum movetur: unde fit, ut, ni&longs;i pilam
excipias, repellá&longs;que antè, quàm pavimentum attingat, fru&longs;tra
deinde &longs;altum illius expectes juxta regulas reflexionis, quia ni­
mirum pila terram tangens, dum pergit moveri circa &longs;uum
centrum motu orbiculari, nequit à plano impediente recipere
directionem illam, cujus e&longs;&longs;et capax, &longs;i &longs;olùm &longs;implici motu
centri mota fui&longs;&longs;et; motus enim peripheriæ globi contrarius e&longs;t
motui centri.

Idem accidit quando pila leviore affrictu funem
per&longs;tringit; tunc &longs;cilicet concipit motum circularem, adeóque
&longs;altus fallit.

Quantum autem in motu valeat directiones com­
mi&longs;cere, alteram centri rectam, alteram peripheriæ circularem
&longs;ed oppo&longs;itam, &longs;atis norûnt, qui minoribus orbiculis ludentes
globum qua&longs;i pendentem ex manu tenent, dúmque illum pro­
jiciunt, manu ei motum circularem communicant; unde oritur,
quod, ubi terram globus attigerit, vel &longs;i&longs;tit &longs;e, &longs;i directio peri­
pheriæ ad motum circularem e&longs;t æqualis directioni centri ad
motum rectum; vel tardiùs promovetur, quàm &longs;i &longs;olam centri
directionem haberet, prout directio centri major e&longs;t directione
peripheriæ, quæ cum primùm terram attingit, apta e&longs;t &longs;uá con­
ver&longs;ione retrahere centrum versùs projicientem.

Quandoquidem verò in ludicris philo&longs;ophamur, liceat hìc
vulgarem errorem retegere; quando &longs;cilicet rotundum verticil­
lum impre&longs;&longs;us impetus in gyrum agit, &longs;i verticillus corruat, mo­
vetur, quoad impetus extinguatur, &longs;ed ita ut videatur omnino
in contrarias partes agi, ac priùs: id quod communiter tribuunt
reflexioni, quia in pavimentum recidit.

Nullam hìc reflexio­
nem intercedere, & eandem permanere motûs directionem,
memini me aliquando a&longs;&longs;erentem vi&longs;um fui&longs;&longs;e pluribus, qui
aderant, paradoxum loqui: &longs;ed ubi inter nos convenit eundem
motum e&longs;&longs;e, quandiu circà axem ita fit convolutio, ut quæ par­
tes peripheriæ verticilli præcedebant axe in&longs;i&longs;tente, eædem axe
inclinato & procumbente præcedant; ju&longs;&longs;i aliquas notas peri­
pheriæ imprimi, ut priores à po&longs;terioribus di&longs;cerni po&longs;&longs;ent; de­
inde yerticillo corruente, & procumbente ob&longs;ervatum e&longs;t par­
tes, quæ priores erant in circuitione, ea&longs;dem &longs;ubinde altiùs at­
tolli à pavimento, atque circa axem eandem fieri conver&longs;io­
nem: & quia verticilli pes qua&longs;i centrum retinet inclinatam
peripheriam, illa eadem conver&longs;io circa axem facit, ut peri­
pheria &longs;ecundùm po&longs;teriores partes &longs;ubinde attingat &longs;ubjectum
alveolum, adeóque ratione habitâ alveoli videatur in contrarias
partes ferri ac priùs.

Quare cùm nulla &longs;it nova motûs directio
ex plani oppo&longs;itione, nulla quoque e&longs;t reflexio.

At &longs;i duo corpora &longs;ibi invicem occurrant, &longs;ibi mutuo ob­
&longs;i&longs;tunt, & diminuto ex re&longs;i&longs;tentiâ impetu, &longs;i quid adhuc re&longs;i­
duum fuerit impetûs, qui excedat in&longs;itam repugnantiam ex
gravitate ortam, fit reflexio, aut alterius tantùm, &longs;i in reliquo
impetus obtundatur, aut utriu&longs;que, &longs;i fuerint &longs;ibi invicem per-
cutiens & percu&longs;&longs;um: ut cùm duo globi &longs;ibi in motu occur­
runt aut æquali, aut non immodicè inæquali impetu acti.
Æquali inquam, impetu, non æquali velocitate; &longs;i enim inæqua­
les fuerint globi, fieri pote&longs;t, ut eorum velocitates &longs;int in Re­
ciprocâ Ratione gravitatum; tunc &longs;cilicet impetus æquales &longs;unt;
contingere &longs;iquidem pote&longs;t majorem globum tardè quidem
moveri, &longs;ed multo impetu re&longs;pondente ejus moli, adeò ut ex­
cedat minoris globi impetum, qui proptereà non præcisè re­
flectatur, &longs;ed à majore globo & impetum recipiat, & directio­
nem non ex &longs;olâ re&longs;i&longs;tentiâ definitam, &longs;ed etiam ex ip&longs;ius ma­
joris globi motu.

Id quod &longs;i contingat, minor quidem reflecti­
tur, &longs;ed qui majore impetu ferebatur, modicam inveniens re­
&longs;i&longs;tentiam non reflectitur, quia dum minor globus cedit, plu­
rimum impetûs deperditur à majore; & ubi re&longs;i&longs;tentia minor
e&longs;t ce&longs;&longs;ione, e&longs;&longs;e nequit reflexio.

Ponamus itaque globos duos tanto impetu actos, ut po&longs;&longs;it
uterque reflecti.

Non placet inter illos ad punctum contactûs
interjicere planum, ut ex angulis determinetur reflexio; hoc
enim planum cogitatione nobis ip&longs;i fingimus; &longs;ed, licèt in
idem res recidat, tamen ad veritatem &longs;inceriùs me acce&longs;&longs;urum
&longs;pero, &longs;i rem ex ip&longs;is motuum directionibus & re&longs;i&longs;tentiis de&longs;i­
niero.

Quare occurrant &longs;ibi
globi in puncto A; & illo­
rum directiones primò eæ
&longs;int, quæ &longs;ibi maximè ad­
ver&longs;antes in rectam lineam
BC coëant: haud dubium
quin globus V per rectam
AB, & globus R per rectam
AC re&longs;iliat, uterque per li­
neam, quâ venit, jungentem
cum puncto contactûs Centrum impetûs: &longs;implici enim di­
rectione alter adversùs alterum fertur, & &longs;ibi toto conatu re­
pugnant.

Deinde obliquus &longs;it morus, & globi R directio &longs;it DE:
quapropter RE directio quædam e&longs;t mixta ex lineâ maximæ re­
&longs;i&longs;tentiæ RA, & ex lineâ nullius re&longs;i&longs;tentiæ RI, ita ut partim
versùs A, partim versùs I tendat: priorem directionem versùs A
metitur linea RF, po&longs;teriorem versùs I metitur linea FE.

Cum
igitur globus V &longs;olùm priori directioni RF opponatur, hæc
mutatur in oppo&longs;itam RG, manet autem directio versùs I æqua­
lis ip&longs;i FE, & e&longs;t GH: propterea motus centri R e&longs;t RH
parallelus motui puncti A, quod per lineam KA incidens in
Tangentem MN, reflecteretur ad angulos æquales KAN &
LAM percurrendo lineam AL.

Simili ratione, &longs;i globi V di­
rectio &longs;it PO, à globo R occurrente in A reflectitur centrum
per rectam VS.
CAPUT XII.
Quomodo impetus in percu&longs;sione communicetur.

ANtè &longs;atisfaciendum e&longs;t Phy&longs;icis, quàm percu&longs;&longs;ionum con­
templationem dimittamus.

Quoniam percu&longs;&longs;io omnis mo­
tum antecedentem exigit; motus non habetur ab&longs;que impetu
concepto aut impre&longs;&longs;o; ex impetu pendet ictus, quo corporis
percu&longs;&longs;i re&longs;i&longs;tentia aliqua vincitur, &longs;ivè illud totum impellatur,
&longs;ivè expellatur, &longs;ivè concutiatur, &longs;ivè flectatur, &longs;ivè compri­
matur, &longs;ivè deprimatur, &longs;ivè di&longs;&longs;iliat in partes earum unione
&longs;olutâ, &longs;ivè quamcumque aliam vim &longs;ubeat; corporis percu&longs;&longs;i
partes, vel omnes, vel aliquæ &longs;altem, moveantur, & impetum
recipiant nece&longs;&longs;e e&longs;t, à quo motus ip&longs;e efficiatur impre&longs;&longs;i impe­
tûs inten&longs;ioni re&longs;pondens.

Quærat autem Phy&longs;icus, cuinam
tribuenda &longs;it virtus efficiendi impetum corpori percu&longs;&longs;o im­
pre&longs;&longs;um.

Exi&longs;timabit forta&longs;&longs;e non nemo à virtute eâdem, quæ in cor­
pore percutiente in&longs;idet, ut &longs;eip&longs;um moveat, effici novum im­
petum, quo corpus percu&longs;&longs;um impellatur, aut agitetur.

Sed
quid?

&longs;i percutiens neque animans &longs;it, cujus in pote&longs;tate po&longs;ita
&longs;it motio, neque juxta in&longs;itæ gravitatis directionem &longs;eip&longs;um
agat.

Huic certè inhærens facultas &longs;e movendi planè otio&longs;a e&longs;t,
quippe quæ pror&longs;us immota con&longs;i&longs;teret, ni&longs;i impetum extra­
neum reciperet.

Aliunde igitur quàm ex hac &longs;e movendi facul­
tate originem ducit impetus corpori percu&longs;&longs;o impre&longs;&longs;us.

Dein-
de certum e&longs;t corporis percutientis naturam non priùs imprime­
re po&longs;&longs;e percu&longs;&longs;o impetum; quàm illud attingat: at in ip&longs;o per­
cutientis appul&longs;u ea e&longs;t percu&longs;&longs;i re&longs;i&longs;tentia, ut eju&longs;dem percu­
tientis motum ex ipsâ naturâ provenientem imminuat: cùm
igitur natura percutientis vix &longs;eip&longs;a movere valeat, quàm te­
nues habet vires ad vincendam obicis re&longs;i&longs;tentiam?

Præterea,
ni&longs;i facta fuerit notabilis in longiore motu naturali acqui&longs;iti im­
petûs acce&longs;&longs;io, manife&longs;tò apparet valdè languida & enervata
percu&longs;&longs;io; &, quamvis &longs;ivè longior, &longs;ivè exiguus motus præ­
ce&longs;&longs;erit, eadem manens virtus movendi, nec &longs;ibi di&longs;&longs;imilis, va­
rietatem in &longs;e habet nullam: cum tamen ex di&longs;paribus incre­
mentis impetûs in motu acqui&longs;iti di&longs;&longs;imiles fiant percu&longs;&longs;iones:
Non igitur à &longs;olâ in&longs;itâ vi movendi producitur in percu&longs;&longs;o im­
petus.

Propterea, ut una atque eadem in percu&longs;&longs;ionibus omnibus
a&longs;&longs;ignetur producti impetûs cau&longs;a, &longs;ivè percutiens &longs;ponte &longs;uâ,
&longs;ivè per vim &longs;ibi illatam moveatur, percutientis impetum plu­
res cen&longs;ent dicendum e&longs;&longs;e principium & cau&longs;am effectricem
impetûs percu&longs;&longs;o impre&longs;&longs;i; ab illo enim, prout major fuerit, aut
minor, hujus men&longs;uram pendere &longs;atis innotui&longs;&longs;e videtur ex
quotidianis experimentis.

Verùm, ne raptim in hanc &longs;ententiam pedarius Philo&longs;ophus
curram, illud me remoratur, quod, &longs;icuti eam e&longs;&longs;e con&longs;tat im­
petûs naturam, ut illico pror&longs;us pereat, ac motus ce&longs;&longs;at omni­
no illius corporis, in quo priùs inerat motum efficiens, ita pari­
ter eodem momento impetum minui nece&longs;&longs;e e&longs;t, eáque Ratio­
ne, quo momento, & qua Ratione illius eju&longs;dem corporis mo­
tus ex parte impeditur.

Quò igitur magis impeditur percutien­
tis motus, eò magis eju&longs;dem impetum minui con&longs;equens e&longs;t:
propterea, quo momento à percutiente attingitur corpus per­
cu&longs;&longs;um, extenuatur in illo impetus, quia tunc illius motus im­
peditur; eóque minor evadit in percutiente impetus, quò ma­
jus invenit impedimentum motûs.

Cùm autem effectui tenui­
tatem importet cau&longs;æ imbecillitas, exiguum utique impetum
in corpore percu&longs;&longs;o efficere valeret attenuatus percutientis im­
petus, quo momento accidit appul&longs;us atque alli&longs;io; eóque mi­
norem impetum reciperet corpus percu&longs;&longs;um, quò magis re­
&longs;i&longs;tens plus inferret impedimenti motui percutientis, quippe
cujus impetus fieret languidior; neque enim quicquam juvat
antiqua virtus, &longs;i nunc e&longs;t effœta.

Quò igitur magis re&longs;i&longs;tit
corpus percu&longs;&longs;um, languidiorem ictum exciperet, cum levior
infirmiórque impetus in eo efficeretur à tenuiore & languidio­
re percutientis impetu.

Sed cum manife&longs;ta refragetur expe­
rientia validiores ictus à majore re&longs;i&longs;tentia ortos demon&longs;trans,
quæ&longs;o à Philo&longs;ophis, ut in hac causâ mihi dent hanc veniam,
ut patiantur me ab eorum placitis aliquantulum di&longs;cedere, nec
percutientis impetui tribuere facultatem effectricem impetûs
in corpore percu&longs;&longs;o, lyceo quamvis reclamante; cui &longs;ilentium
&longs;i tanti&longs;per indicere po&longs;&longs;em, dum me audiret po&longs;tulantem id,
quod æqui&longs;&longs;imum e&longs;t, ut ne quid huc præjudicati afferat, meam
forta&longs;&longs;e in &longs;ententiam volens deduceretur.

Cùm itaque nec à virtute movendi, quæ corpori percutien­
ti inhæret, nec ab impetu eju&longs;dem percutientis effici novum
impetum in corpore percu&longs;&longs;o, &longs;atis probabili conjecturâ dicen­
dum videatur, quænam demum erit cau&longs;a impetûs, & eorum,
quæ impetum con&longs;equuntur, in corpore percu&longs;&longs;o?

Ut quæ&longs;tio­
nibus &longs;atisfiat, quas percu&longs;&longs;iones excitant, nihil &longs;e mihi offert
vero propius, quàm &longs;i dicamus ex percutiente in corpus per­
cu&longs;&longs;um migrare impetum, aut totum, aut ex parte, prout alicu­
jus motûs capax fuerit corpus, quod motui percutientis re&longs;i&longs;tit.

Si totus impetus à percutiente recedat, hoc neque reflectitur
ab obice percu&longs;&longs;o, neque quicquam procedit in motu: Si quid
impetûs in percutiente remaneat, hoc aut juxta in&longs;titutam di­
rectionem pergit moveri unà cum corpore percu&longs;&longs;o, &longs;ive lentiùs
illud &longs;equitur, aut aliò reflectitur, pro re&longs;idui impetûs inten­
&longs;ione, aut vibratur, & concutitur.

Hinc quia gravi&longs;&longs;ima &longs;imul & duri&longs;&longs;ima corpora tantum im­
petûs obtinere à percutiente nequeunt, quanto opus e&longs;&longs;et, ut
motum aliquem con&longs;picuum ex percu&longs;&longs;ione reciperent, pro­
pterea validi&longs;&longs;imè re&longs;i&longs;tunt, & reflectunt, cùm univer&longs;us ferè
impetus in percutiente remaneat: in corpus enim percu&longs;&longs;um
non migrat ni&longs;i impetus, qui re&longs;pondeat motui, cujus illud
tunc e&longs;t capax.

Contra verò à corporibus, quæ leviter re­
&longs;i&longs;tunt, & facilè moventur aliquo motu, aut nihil, aut langui­
dè reflectitur percutiens; quia illa plurimum impetûs reci­
piunt, & exiguus impetus in percutiente reliquus e&longs;t.

Hinc
pariter globus æqualem in mole & gravitate globum percu­
tiens eâ directione, quæ per utriu&longs;que globi centra tran&longs;eat,
con&longs;i&longs;tit in loco, ubi percutit, & percu&longs;&longs;um globum vehemen­
ter excutit; quia videlicet globus æqualis &longs;atis re&longs;i&longs;tit, & capax
e&longs;t totius impetûs eum æquali inten&longs;ione afficientis, hic de&longs;ti­
tuens globum percutientem æquè velocem motum percu&longs;&longs;o
conciliat, & percutiens omni de&longs;titutus impetu con&longs;i&longs;tit.

Sin
autem percutiatur globus major & gravior; hic quidem (ni&longs;i
nimia &longs;it gravitatis aut molis differentia) loco cedit; &longs;ed quia ad
motum æquè velocem plus requirit impetus, quàm illi impri­
mere valeat globus minor, propterea minore inten&longs;ione af­
fectus tardiùs movetur, & minorem globum aliquando reflectit.

Si demum globus major minorem & leviorem percutiat, hic
languidiùs re&longs;i&longs;tens impetum recipit velociori motui congruum;
& quia in globo majore adhuc aliquid &longs;upere&longs;t impetûs, ille
pariter pergit moveri, &longs;ed tardiùs.

At, inquis, impetus ex eo genere e&longs;t, quod Accidentia tan­
quam partes complectitur: Accidentia autem ex &longs;ubjecto in
&longs;ubjectum non tran&longs;ire, ip&longs;i &longs;cholarum parietes clamant.

Mul­
ta i&longs;tiu&longs;modi, non diffiteor, dicuntur in &longs;cholis: verùm an &longs;atis
examinata, momentóque &longs;uo ponderata fuerint, ignoro: non
pauca quippe habemus de manu, ut aiunt, in manum tradita,
non ad aurificis &longs;tateram revocata, &longs;ed populari trutinæ per­
mi&longs;&longs;a.

In illis certè Accidentium generibus, quæ po&longs;tremis no­
vem Categoriis comprehenduntur, &longs;i &longs;ex demas, Relationem,
Actionem, Pa&longs;&longs;ionem, Ubi, Quando, Situm, quos alij (libera­
liter-ne?

dicam, an prodigè?) Modos certæ naturæ, à qua avel­
li nequeunt, affixos appellant, alij minimo contenti, & parciùs
philo&longs;ophantes, nihil e&longs;&longs;e præter mera nomina, aut ab&longs;tractas
à rebus inter &longs;e comparatis intelligentias exi&longs;timant; vix tria
reliqua genera Quantitas, Qualitas, Habitus con&longs;tituere con­
trover&longs;iam po&longs;&longs;unt.

Et quidem de Habitu nullus videtur re­
lictus ambigendi locus; quis enim neget potui&longs;&longs;e Ther&longs;item eâ­
dem Achillis galeâ, eodémque thorace armari, & regiâ chla­
myde &longs;ervum indui?

mutatâ &longs;cilicet armorum aut indumento­
rum Ubicatione comparatâ cum hominis, qui armatus dicitur,
aut ve&longs;titus, Ubicatione & po&longs;itione.

Quantitatem verò, qua
locus ob&longs;idetur (nam de Numero, qui præter individua cogita-
tioni ea complectenti &longs;ubjecta nihil e&longs;t, non attinet dicere)
quam multi à materiâ non dividunt?

quot Philo&longs;ophi &longs;uam &longs;in­
gulis corporeis rebus tribuunt quantitatem?

De &longs;olâ igitur
Qualitate oriri pote&longs;t quæ&longs;tio: cujus tamen &longs;pecies aliæ me­
ram membrorum aut terminorum corporis collocationem &
conformationem dicunt, ut Forma & Figura; aliæ particula­
rum in extimâ &longs;uperficie po&longs;itionem, ut a&longs;peritas & lævor; aliæ
earumdem toto corpore diffu&longs;arum complexionem, ut molli­
tudo & durities, raritas & den&longs;itas; aliæ non ni&longs;i intelligentiâ
&longs;ecretæ accidere dicuntur Naturæ, cuju&longs;modi non paucæ Na­
turales Potentiæ & Impotentiæ; aliæ Patibiles Qualitates aut
Pa&longs;&longs;iones immi&longs;&longs;ione corpu&longs;culorum effluentium communican­
tur, quemadmodum Odores & Sapores, & fortè etiam quas Pri­
mas Qualitates vocant.

Sed quicquid tandem de huju&longs;modi Accidentibus a&longs;&longs;erere
placeat (neque enim hìc de iis philo&longs;ophandi e&longs;t locus) ultro
demus ea e&longs;&longs;e, quæ licèt à &longs;ub&longs;tantiâ di&longs;tinguantur, per &longs;e ta­
men &longs;tare nequeant, & nece&longs;&longs;ariò &longs;ubjectam aliquam naturam
afficiant, in qua inhæreant: verùm Qualitates omnes (ni&longs;i ex
earum genere &longs;int, quos Modos appellant, quia Actuales De­
terminationes, cuju&longs;modi &longs;unt cogitationes, appetitiones, &
motus, quibus actio vitæ continetur) quid prohibet nunc huic,
mox illi &longs;ubjecto inhærere, quemadmodum in locum pereun­
tis Cau&longs;æ Effectricis, cujus virtute hactenus con&longs;ervabantur,
aliam &longs;ub&longs;titui cau&longs;am, cujus vi adhuc permaneant, omnes fa­
temur?

Nonne causâ effectrice magis indigent Accidentia,
quàm Materiali & Subjectivâ?

Divinâ &longs;iquidem vi accidentia
à Subjecto avul&longs;a permanere po&longs;&longs;e docemur ex My&longs;teriis Eu­
chari&longs;ticis; at &longs;inè ullâ causâ effectrice con&longs;i&longs;tere nullatenus
po&longs;&longs;unt: hanc &longs;ubinde permutant citrà Naturæ incommodum;
quidni & &longs;ubjectum?

Nihil igitur extra modum ab&longs;onum & ab­
&longs;urdum loquatur, qui impetum migrantem ex percutiente in
percu&longs;&longs;um ita &longs;ubjectum mutare dixerit, quemadmodum om­
nes novum impetum à percutiente malleo produci in percu&longs;&longs;o
& excu&longs;&longs;o globo opinantes, aliam eju&longs;dem impetûs, quandiu
durat, cau&longs;am, à qua con&longs;ervetur, ultro admittunt.

Quamvis autem hoc cæteris qualitatibus ratum ac firmum
e&longs;&longs;et, quod ita &longs;ubjecto, cui &longs;emel inhæ&longs;erint, affigantur, ut
aut in illo in&longs;idere nece&longs;&longs;e &longs;it, aut interire; impetui tamen
privatam legem à Naturâ irrogatam fui&longs;&longs;e non e&longs;t incon­
gruum, quippe qui motui efficiendo, & locorum commutatio­
ni, tamquam proxima cau&longs;a, de&longs;tinatus e&longs;t; &longs;i enim illi corpo­
rum tran&longs;latio tribuenda e&longs;t, quidni & ip&longs;e à corpore, quod
jam commovere nequit ob re&longs;i&longs;tentiam, in aliud corpus proxi­
mum faciliùs mobile tran&longs;mittat, ut &longs;ubmoveatur impedimen­
tum?

Neque mihi videor temerè in hanc &longs;ententiam di&longs;ce&longs;&longs;i&longs;&longs;e:
ob&longs;ervavi &longs;cilicet quàm multum inter&longs;it in vehementi brachij
projectione, &longs;i verè lapidem manu longiùs excutias, ac &longs;i tan­
tummodo, eâdem quidem contentione, &longs;ed manu vacuâ, te la­
pidem jactare mentiaris: hoc enim po&longs;tremum &longs;inè dolore non
accidit, quia impetus à brachio in lapidem jactandum transfe­
rendus &longs;i in brachio permaneat, hoc &longs;ecum rapit, & nexum
di&longs;trahit, quo tenetur cum humero colligatum.

At ne fortè
me potiùs opinionis commento, quàm re ductum &longs;u&longs;piceris
(quamquam & alij hunc eundem brachij dolorem experientes
non &longs;emel probârunt) bali&longs;tæ arcum chalybeum intento nervo
inflecte, ac &longs;æpiùs, nullo adjecto globo aut telo, quod explodat
& ejiciat, &longs;ubmoto nervi adducti retinaculo dimitte: an diutiùs
inani hoc ludo uti licebit?

&longs;excenties utique & millies bali&longs;tâ
hac globos argillaceos ejaculaberis citrà arcûs detrimentum;
&longs;ed non item &longs;ine incommodo &longs;æpiùs vacuum nervum dimittes,
quin arcus ip&longs;e in periculum ac di&longs;crimen vocetur, ne facilè
di&longs;rumpatur: impetus &longs;iquidem, quem mi&longs;&longs;ili imprimere opor­
tuit, in arcu, dum &longs;e&longs;e vi ela&longs;ticâ re&longs;tituit, permanens illum va­
lidiùs concutit, ac &longs;æpiùs labefactans demum diffindit.

Quapropter, cùm ex projectionibus &longs;atis habeamus argumen­
ti, po&longs;&longs;e impetum ex projiciente migrare in projectum, quo mo­
mento projicitur; cur non item poterit impetus ex percutiente
in percu&longs;&longs;um tran&longs;ire, quo momento percutitur, prout hoc mo­
tum aliquem concipere pote&longs;t pro impetûs Ratione?

Neque ut percu&longs;&longs;i impetum à percutientis virtute tunc pri­
mò productum ad&longs;truas, conferenda e&longs;t Percu&longs;&longs;io cum Impul­
&longs;ione; non enim par e&longs;t in Percu&longs;&longs;ione aut Projectione, atque in
Simplici Impul&longs;ione aut Tractione philo&longs;ophandi ratio: Poten­
tia enim corpori impul&longs;o aut raptato applicata quandiu cum
illo nectitur, & &longs;e, & illud movet qua&longs;i corpus unum ex utro-
que conflatum: propterea &longs;icut mu&longs;culi in animante o&longs;&longs;a &longs;ibi
cohærentia attollentes & &longs;e movent, & o&longs;&longs;a; ita potentia Vecti
applicata & &longs;e movet, & vectem, & pondus, atque equi cur­
rui adjuncti non modò &longs;eip&longs;i, &longs;ed & currum, trahentes movent.

At Percu&longs;&longs;io &longs;æpè corpus percu&longs;&longs;um procul à percutiente ejicit,
quemadmodum & Projectio.

Quod &longs;i cum Percu&longs;&longs;ione junga­
tur Impul&longs;io (quæ &longs;emper Projectionem præcedit) impetus in
Impul&longs;ione producitur à potentiâ impellente; &longs;ed &longs;icut momen­
to Projectionis qui erat in projiciente impetus, migrat in pro­
jectum, quod di&longs;cedit; ita in Percu&longs;&longs;ione primo Percu&longs;&longs;ionis mo­
mento tran&longs;it impetus in corpus percu&longs;&longs;um pro ejus capacitate:
quod &longs;i præterea impellatur à corpore percutiente, cujus motus
juxta &longs;uam directionem procedat, & urgeat partes corporis per­
cu&longs;&longs;i (ut in iis, quæ deprimuntur, aut comprimuntur contin­
git & cùm &longs;ublicas, dum panguntur, fi&longs;tuca ex ca&longs;u non re&longs;i­
liens impellit) impetum aliquem habet ab impellente pro­
ductum præter impetum ab eodem tamquam percutiente, ip&longs;o
percu&longs;&longs;ionis momento communicatum: &longs;ed qui ab impellente
efficitur, non admodum multus e&longs;t, &longs;i cum eo componatur, qui
ex percu&longs;&longs;ione habetur.

Simile quid Impul&longs;ioni, quæ Percu&longs;&longs;ionem &longs;equitur, habe­
tur in Tractione, quam Excur&longs;us præce&longs;&longs;it, in quo acqui&longs;itus
e&longs;t impetus: quo enim momento Excur&longs;us ce&longs;&longs;at, & incipit
Tractio, tran&longs;it impetus, & minuitur in trahente; ut &longs;i lapis in
pavimento jacens fune jungatur alteri lapidi paulò minori, fu­
nis autem orbiculo ver&longs;atili in&longs;ideat, & lapis ille minor cadens,
donec funem intendat, impetum ex motu acquirat; &longs;tatim ac
intentus e&longs;t funis, & lapis jacens de&longs;cendentis lapidis motui re­
&longs;i&longs;tit impetus acqui&longs;itus migrat ad vincendam jacentis lapidis
re&longs;i&longs;tentiam, atque acceptâ à trahentis motu directione cogi­
tur a&longs;cendere, quandiu alter de&longs;cendit, & hunc aliquantulum
trahit; &longs;ed impetu impre&longs;&longs;o langue&longs;cente in lapide graviore hic
de&longs;cendit, & &longs;ur&longs;um vici&longs;&longs;im rapit eum, à quo vim pa&longs;&longs;us fue­
rat.

Sic potentia velociter languidum funem intendens mul­
tum concipit impetum, quem ponderi adnexo imprimit,
dum illo de&longs;tituitur, cum primùm re&longs;i&longs;tentiam patitur, &longs;ed &
aliam impetûs particulam trahendo producit atque efficit in
pondere.

Cum igitur duplex &longs;it in motu &longs;ubmovendorum impedimen­
torum genus, alia, videlicet, quæ inchoatum motum ab­
rumpunt, alia quæ ob&longs;i&longs;tunt, ne fiat motus; illa tollenda
&longs;unt per impetum, quo motus continuandus fui&longs;&longs;et, ni&longs;i im­
pedimentum occurri&longs;&longs;et; hæc verò &longs;uperat pars impetûs pro­
ducta à potentiâ, quæ &longs;e tardiùs movet, quia vires dividit,
partem impetûs &longs;ibi re&longs;ervans, partem impertiens ob&longs;taculo,
quod removet impellendo aut trahendo.

Quare nil mirum, &longs;i
impetus, qui periturus e&longs;&longs;et in percutiente, cujus motus im­
peditur, tran&longs;eat in obicem percu&longs;&longs;um, quem &longs;ubmovendo
locum relinquit ulteriori motui, &longs;i facultas &longs;e movendi &longs;uppe­
tat corpori percutienti.
CAPUT XIII.
Cunei u&longs;us promovetur.

NE quis fortè Cuneum &longs;olis ru&longs;ticis ad findenda ligna u&longs;ui
e&longs;&longs;e &longs;ibi per&longs;uadeat, fontes aliquos indicare placet ex
quibus non levis utilitas derivatur.

Ad Machinarum &longs;cilicet
Rationem pertinet poti&longs;&longs;imùm motus corporis, cujus re&longs;i&longs;ten­
tia &longs;uperatur, &longs;ivè illa demum ex gravitate oriatur, &longs;ivè ex
nexu, quo colligatur cum proximo corpore; id quod iis con­
tingit, quæ in corpus unum coale&longs;cunt, & fi&longs;&longs;ione &longs;ejun­
guntur.
PROPOSITIO I.
Vectis vires Cuneo augere.

COntingit aliquando potentiam incommodè applicari
vecti, ut cum hominem valde curvari oportet ad
vectem &longs;ecundi generis ferè in &longs;olo jacentem attollendum;
tunc &longs;ub&longs;idium à Cuneo non incongruè peti pote&longs;t.

Sit
Vectis AB &longs;ubjectus foribus DC &longs;uis è cardinibus avellen-
dis, ut reficiantur: hypomochlium e&longs;t in A, & pondus in C.

At &longs;i potentiam adeò in­
clinari atque curvari opor­
teat, ut arripiat extremum
vectem B, &longs;atis manife&longs;tum
e&longs;t, quanto id incommodo
fiat.

Subjiciatur vecti in B
(&longs;iquidem &longs;olum æquo
mollius fuerit) a&longs;&longs;eris aut
lapidis pars, quæ compre&longs;&longs;ioni re&longs;i&longs;tat, atque inter illam &
vectem apex Cunei E immittatur.

Nam &longs;i tudite cuneum per­
cutias, vectem facilè attollet, ac proinde etiam valvas in C
incumbentes.

Quod &longs;i vectis &longs;ecundi generis FG habens hypomochlium
in G ita fuerit altiùs col­
locatus, ut ægrè brachio­
rum contentione attolle­
re valeas pondus in K ad­
nexum, utere cuneo in­
flexo FH, quem &longs;olo in I
incumbentem, & vecti in
F &longs;ubjectum, &longs;i propellas
lateri HI, arrepto manu­
brio LM, applicatus, prout commodiùs acciderit, vectem cum
pondere eatenus elevabis, quoad latus IH longius, &longs;olo ad
pendiculum in&longs;i&longs;tat.

Vectem autem, qua parte cuneum huju&longs;­
modi contingit, ita extenuatum e&longs;&longs;e oportere, ut cunei orbitæ ex­
cavatæ congruat, ne elabatur, res per &longs;e ip&longs;a loquitur.

Maximè verò opportunum duxerim huju&longs;modi cuneo in­
flexo uti, ubi tertij generis Vectis
adhibendus fuerit RS, & pondus
adnexum ex S in V &longs;u&longs;tollendum:
Nam &longs;i loco Potentiæ de&longs;tinato
in T &longs;ubjicias cuneum inflexum
TP, &longs;olo in X incumbentem, &
hunc urgeas ex latere XP, aut
trahas ex latere TX, ubi P venerit
in Q, pondus ex S erit in V.
PROPOSITIO II.

Vecte, aut Trochleâ, aut Succulâ, Cunei inflexi
vires augere.

IN&longs;trumenta pre&longs;&longs;oria varij generis excogitantur; &longs;ed ad &longs;ubi­
tum u&longs;um, & non &longs;inè compendio, uti aliquando po&longs;&longs;umus
Cuneo inflexo, cui, &longs;i validiùs premendum &longs;it, vectem adjice­
re licebit.

Sit cra&longs;&longs;ior tabula AB,
cui &longs;upponatur id, quod premen­
dum proponitur.

Paretur cuneus
inflexus DE, & pro illius motûs
centro &longs;tatuatur punctum C, cui
axis infigatur: Nam urgendo lon­
gius latus CE, aut trahendo bre­
vius CD, &longs;ubjectam tabulam AB
premes.

Quod &longs;i validiore pre&longs;&longs;u
opus fuerit, lateri longiori CE
Vectem FG adhibe: potentia &longs;i­
quidem in G majorem arcum de&longs;­
cribens circa centrum motûs C,
majora obtinebit momenta, quàm
&longs;i proximè illa applicaretur Cuneo: illa tamen momenta poten­
tiæ in G &longs;en&longs;im minuuntur, prout cunei partes tabulam con­
tingentes propiores &longs;unt extremo puncto E.

Ne verò ip&longs;a ea­
dem tabula AB impedimento &longs;it, &longs;i lateri CE proximè vectis
adhæreret, affigatur cuneo unum aut alterum Chelonion HF,
IK, in quæ conjectus vectis FG di&longs;tet à Cuneo citrà pericu­
lum incurrendi in &longs;ubjectam tabulam AB.

Vel &longs;i Vectem cuneo affigere non placuerit, ip&longs;ius vectis ca­
put hypomochlio re&longs;pondens ita collocetur, ut vectis horizonti
ferè paralleli longitudo tran&longs;ver&longs;a cadat in latus cunei DE,
séque non procul ab E decu&longs;&longs;ent: hac enim ratione vecti &longs;ua
con&longs;tabunt momenta, quibus momenta cunei augeantur.

At &longs;i fortè loci di&longs;po&longs;itio non ferat, ut vectis adhibeatur im­
pellendo cuneo, trahatur ille ex D, ubi aut annulus infigatur,
aut foramini in&longs;eratur funis, cui deinde trochlea &longs;ive &longs;implex,
&longs;ive multiplex adnectatur, prout opus fuerit.

Immò & Succula
addi poterit, ad quam funis caput religetur: erúntque momen­
ta potentiæ, quæ componuntur ex Rationibus Succulæ, Tro­
chleæ, & Cunei.
PROPOSITIO III.

Cuneum inflexum validi&longs;simum con&longs;truere ad
Vectem tùm trahendum, tùm repellendum.

AS&longs;umatur planum aliquod circulare circa axem per cen­
trum ductum ver&longs;atile, ita cra&longs;&longs;um & validum, ut in eo
in&longs;culpi po&longs;&longs;it profundiùs &longs;pira, quæ Vectis caput ferreo clavo
capitato, & in globum rotundato, armatum contineat, ne ela­
batur.

Hinc enim fiet, ut in &longs;piræ cavitatem immi&longs;&longs;um Vectis
caput aut propellatur, aut attrahatur, prout plani illius motus
in hanc aut illam partem dirigitur: tantus &longs;cilicet erit Vectis
motus, quanta erit Radiorum à centro ad &longs;piræ ambitum ducto­
rum differentia.

Ex quo orietur tractio, aut impul&longs;io; Radiis
enim decre&longs;centibus trahitur Vectis ad centrum, illis cre&longs;cen­
tibus propellitur à centro.

Potentia igitur certæ plani illius cir­
cularis parti applicata integrum circulum de&longs;cribit, dum vectis
caput per unum &longs;piræ flexum excurrit, & tot circulos potentia
de&longs;cribit, quot &longs;piræ flexus vectis caput &longs;ubinde complectun­
tur.

Quare comparanda e&longs;t di&longs;tantia à centro plani circumacti,
quam in motu caput Vectis mutavit, cum univer&longs;is circulis,
quos potentia interim de&longs;crip&longs;it, & &longs;tatim innote&longs;cet Ratio mo­
mentorum.

Hinc &longs;i plano huju&longs;modi, in quo excavata e&longs;t &longs;pi­
ra, addideris circa extremam orbitam Radios, quemadmodum
Axi in Peritrochio, motus potentiæ &longs;atis amplos circulos
de&longs;cribet.

Statuamus, exempli gratiâ, plani circularis a&longs;&longs;umpti diame­
trum cubitalem, hoc e&longs;t &longs;e&longs;quipedalem, &longs;eu digitorum 24; &longs;it
autem inter &longs;piræ excavatæ flexum & flexum intercapedo digi­
torum duûm, adeò ut, peractâ circulatione unâ, vectis caput
per &longs;piram excurrens digitos duos à primâ &longs;uâ &longs;ede dimotum
fuerit: at potentia in extremâ orbitâ plani circularis con&longs;tituta
&longs;uo motu integram peripheriam circuli, cujus diameter digi­
torum 24, de&longs;crip&longs;erit, hoc e&longs;t digitorum 75. Motus igitur
potentiæ ad motum capitis vectis e&longs;t ut 75 ad 2: cui &longs;i addatur
Ratio ad ip&longs;um Vectem &longs;pectans, quatenus cum pondere com­
paratur, fiet Ratio Compo&longs;ita indicans Rationem motûs poten­
tiæ ad motum ponderis.

Quapropter etiam&longs;i ad conciliandum ponderi motum paulò
velociorem, uteremur Vecte primi generis &longs;ed inver&longs;o, ita ut
ab hypomochlio plus di&longs;taret pondus, quàm potentia capiti
vectis applicata, adhuc haberetur non modicum momentorum
compendium.

Sit enim di&longs;tantia potentiæ in capite vectis ab
hypomochlio ut 1, ponderis verò ut 5; atque adeò, dum Vectis
caput deprimitur digitos duos, pondus attollatur digitos de­
cem: Componantur duæ Rationes 75 ad 2, & 1 ad 5; erit Ra­
tio 15 ad 2, & potentia &longs;piræ applicata movebit pondus huju&longs;­
modi vecti adnexum lib.150, quo conatu ab&longs;que ullâ machinâ
moveret pondus lib.
20.

Hanc propo&longs;itionem hìc potiùs afferre placuit, quàm in &longs;e­
quentem librum de Cochleâ re&longs;ervare, quia hìc caput vectis
excurrit per ip&longs;am &longs;piram, & proximè pertinere videtur hìc
motus ad motum &longs;uper faciem Cunei inflexi: in Cochleâ verò,
prout communiter illa u&longs;urpatur, pondus movetur ad motum
cylindri, cui in&longs;culpta e&longs;t Cochlea.

Dixi, prout communiter
u&longs;urpatur, quia aliquid &longs;imile contingit Cochleæ infinitæ, ut
videbimus.
PROPOSITIO IV.

Flatum vehementem non interruptum excitare
follibus adhibitis.

GLebam metallicam ex fodinis erutam valido igne exco­
quere oportet, ut metallum fluat, atque id, quod utile e&longs;t,
ab inutili &longs;ecernatur.

Ignis autem ut ex carbonibus excitetur
eâ vehementiâ, qua opus e&longs;t, etiam vehementem flatum, qui
ex follibus exprimatur adhibendum manife&longs;tum e&longs;t omnibus:
neque enim ubique commodum reperiri pote&longs;t conclave hy­
pogæum, in quod præceps delap&longs;a aqua aërem vapori mi&longs;tum
per tubum in camini focum impellat.

Quare præter vulgarem
& noti&longs;&longs;imam methodum folles alterno motu agitandi, ex his,
quæ hujus lib.
cap.
3. dicta &longs;unt, rationem aliquam mire po&longs;­
&longs;umus, qua plurimum flatus in carbones accen&longs;os immit­
tamus.

Quod ad folles ip&longs;os &longs;pectat, non illos &longs;implices vellem, &longs;ed
&longs;ingulos duplices, ita videlicet conformatos ut &longs;inguli ex binis
a&longs;&longs;eribus con&longs;tent invicem &longs;ecundùm alteram extremitatem in­
clinatis, qua&longs;i in angulum coituri e&longs;&longs;ent, qui omnino &longs;tabiles
permaneant.

In ip&longs;o autem tigillo, cui firmiter infixa manent
a&longs;&longs;erum illorum capita, excavatus &longs;it congruè ductus, per quem
flatus exprimatur in tubum adnexum, quo ad focum defertur:
atque opportuno loco in &longs;ingulis a&longs;&longs;eribus, ut moris e&longs;t, fora­
men excipiendo aëri de&longs;tinatum a&longs;&longs;ario muniatur.

Hos inter
immotos, planum aliud &longs;imile, ad extremitatem fibulâ ver&longs;atili
connexum cum tigillo illo communi, adjiciatur, & cum extre­
mis a&longs;&longs;eribus corio plicatili jungatur, adeò ut duo &longs;int conjuncti
folles, quorum alter clauditur, alter recluditur, cùm ex medio
hoc plano mobili exiens an&longs;a adducitur & reducitur: hoc enim
mobile planum e&longs;t diaphragma &longs;ejungens folles, ne ex altero in
alterum compre&longs;&longs;us aër effugiat, &longs;ed per infimum ductum in
tubum erumpat, per quem ad focum devehatur.

Quatuor pa­
rentur huju&longs;modi folles duplices, quorum bini &longs;ibi ex diametro
oppo&longs;iti ita &longs;tatuantur, ut inter illos di&longs;cus circularis congruæ
magnitudinis interjectus eorum an&longs;as &longs;ubinde propellere va­
leat: bini autem oppo&longs;iti funiculo jungantur aut loro, aut ca­
tenulâ, an&longs;as connectente longitudinis æqualis diametro cir­
culi: Ex quo fiet, ut operâ eâdem follis unius an&longs;a propellatur,
oppo&longs;iti verò an&longs;a trahatur.

Porrò attendendum e&longs;t, quantum &longs;patij percurrat &longs;ingulo­
rum follium an&longs;a ultro citróque remeando, quo loco illa tangi­
tur à circulo: hujus enim &longs;patij &longs;emi&longs;&longs;e definietur intervallum,
quo circuli centrum abe&longs;&longs;e oportet à centro, quod &longs;tatuendum
e&longs;t, ut circa illud fiat eju&longs;dem circuli convolutio.

Huic motûs
centro infigendus e&longs;t firmiter axis, &longs;ivè ille &longs;it communis exte­
riori rotæ ab aquâ fluente convolutæ, &longs;ivè cui vectis opportu-
næ longitudinis adjiciatur, ut ab homine, aut à jumento con­
torqueatur.

Sic an&longs;æ motus
univer&longs;us.
Sit ex.

gr. AB
circuli centrum &longs;it C: acci­
piatur intervallum CD &longs;ub­
duplum ip&longs;ius AB; & erit
in D infigendus axis, ex cu­
jus convolutione circulus pa­
riter circumagatur, & fol­
lium an&longs;as in quatuor oppo­
&longs;itis punctis A, E, G, F &longs;ubinde tangat, eá&longs;que vici&longs;&longs;im propel­
lat, & trahat: Cùm &longs;cilicet incipit propelli follis an&longs;a, quæ e&longs;t
in E, propellitur pariter ea, quæ e&longs;t in G (&longs;i quidem conver­
&longs;io fiat ex E in F) atque ex adver&longs;o tantumdem trahitur quæ
e&longs;t in A, quantùm propellitur quæ e&longs;t in E; atque &longs;imiliter
tractio ejus, quæ e&longs;t in F, e&longs;t æqualis impul&longs;ioni an&longs;æ, quæ
e&longs;t in G.

Si igitur circulus non &longs;it in plano Verticali, & axem in D in­
fixum non habeat communem cum rotâ, quæ ab aquâ volva­
tur, &longs;ed &longs;it in plano horizontali, axi infixo in D addatur vectis
DH, ut potentia in H vectem impellens aut trahens circum­
agat circulum.

Quo autem loco &longs;tatuendus &longs;it vectis, pendet
ex loci po&longs;itione, prout vel in &longs;uperiori, vel in inferiori, vel in
eodem conclavi folles collocantur; axis &longs;iquidem certam non
exigit longitudinem, &longs;ed ea illi tribuenda e&longs;t, quæ commodior
acciderit.

Vectis tamen longitudinem ita temperare oportet,
ut, dum potentiæ movendi facilitatem affectas, nimiam tardi­
tatem compre&longs;&longs;ionis follium effugias.

Ex his &longs;atis apparet, quantùm aëris impellatur in prunas à
quatuor follibus, qui clauduntur, dum quatuor reliqui reclu­
duntur, perpetuú&longs;que e&longs;t flatus nunquam interruptus.

Quòd
&longs;i potentia movens viribus abundet, & circulus fieri po&longs;&longs;it am­
plior ita, ut non quatuor &longs;olùm follibus duplicibus, &longs;ed etiam
&longs;ex aut octo &longs;imilibus in gyrum di&longs;ponendis commodus locus
&longs;uppetat, &longs;atis vides, quantus excitari po&longs;&longs;it flatus.

Quoniam verò ex dictis infertur folles e&longs;&longs;e erigendos, ut in
eorum an&longs;as circulus horizonti parallelus incurrat, ob&longs;erva po&longs;­
&longs;e illos etiam jacentes (modò a&longs;&longs;arium &longs;uperioris a&longs;&longs;eris foramen
claudens exactè fungi po&longs;&longs;it &longs;uo munere) u&longs;ui e&longs;&longs;e po&longs;&longs;e, &longs;i artificium
aliquod adhibeatur, quo an&longs;a attollatur, atque deprimatur.

Fiat
inflexus vectis, &longs;eu qua&longs;i vec­
tis RSG, cujus angulo S
addatur axis, circa quem fa­
cilè converti po&longs;&longs;it, & ad ex­
tremitatem G &longs;it regula GH
follis an&longs;æ adnexa; & &longs;imilia
omnia ex adver&longs;o parentur,
atque funiculo MP conjun­
gantur.

Nam circulus im­
pellens in R attollet extre­
mitatem G, ac proinde an&longs;am illi adnexam, trahendo autem
funiculum MP deprimet extremitatem O, & cum illâ an&longs;am
oppo&longs;iti follis: atque ita vici&longs;&longs;im impellendo N, attolletur O,
& deprimetur G.

Hinc colliges hoc eodem artificio, &longs;i ha&longs;tulæ
GH non follis an&longs;am, &longs;ed antliæ embolum adjeceris, fieri po&longs;­
&longs;e machinam, qua, multiplicatis antiis, plurimum aquæ &longs;ur­
&longs;um impellere valeas.

An autem di&longs;ci circularis exteriorem or­
bitam ferreo annulo polito & lævi munire, atque ferream lami­
nam pariter politàm an&longs;æ follis, aut vecti inflexo, apponere
præ&longs;tet, ut quàm minimo tritu inter &longs;e confligant, non e&longs;t opus
monere, &longs;i fuerit operæ pretium machinæ diuturnitati con&longs;u­
lere, & faciliorem motum exhibere.

Quòd demum &longs;pectat ad ip&longs;ius circuli collocationem, quam­
quam cylindrus illi infixus po&longs;&longs;it inniti polis, circa quos ver&longs;e­
tur; ut tamen &longs;ubter circulum liberrimè trahi po&longs;&longs;int funiculi,
placeret potiùs illum omnino &longs;u&longs;pen&longs;um pendere ex cra&longs;&longs;iore
(&longs;ive &longs;implici, &longs;ive ex duobus compacto) tigno, cujus forami­
ni in&longs;eratur cylindrus, ferreo annulo munitus tam in &longs;uperiori,
quàm in inferiori parte, qua foramini re&longs;pondet, ita ut neque
&longs;ur&longs;um agi, neque deor&longs;um de&longs;cendere valeat, &longs;ed intrà fo­
ramen illud convertatur, quod pariter utrinque circulis fer­
reis muniatur re&longs;pondentibus &longs;uperiori & inferiori annulo
cylindri.

Sit circularis di&longs;cus AB, in quo motûs centrum
&longs;it C, cui infigatur cylindrus CD convertendus à vecte,
&longs;ivè in I, &longs;ivè in H immittendo.

In inferiore tigni
facie &longs;imiliter &longs;it circulus

Si tignum quidem

at &longs;i exiguum fuerit inter­
